SPEECH.PARA: This amendment basically is asking that the annual report be more than just an economic report, that it does not just talk about expenditure but also looks at the efficiency and effectiveness of this expenditure—in other words, that it ensures there is actually some environmental assessment done as to what improvements and what progress we have made. I am pleased to say that this wording has been accepted by the government. Again, I think some of the way this was written was probably an oversight or perhaps not deliberately done in the drafting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government supports the amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the amendment and will make a further effort to ensure that this reporting does extend, as Senator Lees wants it to, to the efficacy of the spending of this money in terms of its environmental returns.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (14) Clause 33, page 18 (line 7), after "date", insert ", including details of all disbursements from the Reserve and the reasons for decisions relating to those disbursements".

This amendment is so that the annual report about the reserve—that is, about the fund—requires the ministers to include details of all disbursements from the reserve and the reasons for decisions relating to those disbursements. It is a pretty sensible and standard way of reporting here. It simply says, `Let us see what the ministers were aiming to do when they allocated the money.' They are the board. They are the total authority. Let us in the report find out whether they were successful in achieving that.

That brings me again to the matter of native vegetation. Under the scheme, according to the latest figures, the minister is allocating $328.6 million. Presumably that includes extra money from Senator Harradine's efforts. Of this, a fifth goes to stopping clearing of native vegetation in Australia—that is, $64 million—and four-fifths goes to revegetation, $254 million. What I would like to know from the minister is how many hectares of revegetation he expects that $254 million is going to create, how much of it is going to be planted as local native vegetation and how much of it is going to be commercial trees or other forms of plantation or tree growing.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have very ambitious goals in terms of extending vegetation cover. As I recall it, our goal is to achieve an expansion of vegetation cover in the figures of around 250,000 hectares over the course of the trust, Australia wide.

—The rest of my question was: what sort of tree cover? Of that 250,000 hectares, how much is going to be local vegetation types and how much is going to be non-local in the form of plantation, commercial crops or other forms of introduced tree cover?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —This program is not about in the main encouraging the expansion of crops. The very modest forestry program that is within it you can say is of that type, but that is only a very small fraction of the total fund. The natural vegetation initiative of some $318 million is to extend native vegetation cover primarily for the purpose of the environmental outcomes that most of us would like to see. There will be incidental benefits to agriculture because we believe that extending the native vegetation cover will enhance the productive capacities of the land. In other words, we think it will help restore basic health to the natural systems.

—The very modest commercial operations that the minister speaks about are, as far as I can ascertain, worth at least $22 million, which I think a lot of people would consider to be quite a lot of money. What conditions are applied to those millions of dollars of commercial operations as far as the environmental outcomes are concerned? What is the aim of the minister, in terms of the repair or restoration of the environment, in putting that money into commercial tree operations? What conditions will be placed on those commercial tree planting operations to enhance the natural environment?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —If you are talking about that forestry program, then I say it is modest in terms of the total expenditure. This is a public expenditure of $1.25 billion. Some $22 million is a large sum in itself, but it is not a large proportion of $1.25 billion. As I understand it, that program, which is administered by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, is in existence at the moment and will be continued. It has a regime of practice under which it operates and there is no secret about that. I really cannot see the point of the question. I cannot see that it has anything to do with this clause that we are debating either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The point of the question is that this is legislation to spend public moneys on the repair or the enhancement of the environment. I cannot see how commercial tree planting operations are covered by those aims. The minister says that this program has been in operation before. That immediately raises the question: are moneys from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund being diverted into other government programs? We had a long and unsatisfactory debate about that last night where the minister refused to accept an amendment from this side of the chamber which would prevent states from double shuffling money.

SPEECH.PARA: We now need to look at whether government is internally shuffling money in the Natural Heritage Trust Fund to give to the loggers, the tree planters, the plantation owners and goodness knows which companies. It is a blatant question up-front, but the minister simply has to answer it. How is commercial tree planting with a commercial imperative going to fulfil the desired outcome of environmental excellence and environmental enhancement? It is a pretty simple question.

It is a lot of money, no matter what the minister says, and it is money that ought to be going towards the prime objective of enhancing Australia's environmental future. I cannot see how you can justify putting $22 million of this fund into commercial tree planting operations which are for profit when there is so much to be done in terms of stopping the awesome destruction of native vegetation across the country with the loss of biodiversity, the destruction of native forests, including rainforests, and the loss of the environmental amenity.

BREAK.PARA: Could the minister also say why $4 is being spent on revegetation for every dollar that is being spent on stopping the destruction of current native cover? In other words, you are spending four times as much on repair as you are spending on stopping the damage. One has to wonder whether that is not simply a formula for a much bigger repair requirement further down the line. What is your answer to that, minister?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —My first answer is that we are debating the form of the annual report. We are not debating programs under the trust at all. We have had that debate, except Senator Brown will not acknowledge it. The farm forestry program is in existence at the moment and does have incidental benefits in terms of what flows to the environment from sustainable agriculture. For us to support and encourage sustainable agriculture will provide more environmental benefits than practically anything else we can do in this country as we apply it to regional and rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately, Senator Brown cannot get his mind around that. He keeps saying that this is for profit. Farmers who have profitable enterprises will be good for the environment. Farmers who are unprofitable are likely to be less good for the environment. If we can support farmers to conduct their farming in a sustainable way, which will include the capacity to harvest some timber, then we will be taking a positive step.

The landcare movement is a world that Senator Brown is not part of—a world of hundreds of thousands of Australians who are now trying to run their own lives and their own businesses in a sustainable way. They will be the people who will make the difference. They will be the people that we want to support. They are people that we are seeking to invest in. That is what this is all about. This has nothing to do with the clause that we are debating.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —It has got everything to do with the clause that is being debated because the clause is saying that an annual report will need to establish how the ministers are com plying with their obligations under the act, which has very specific aims of protecting the environment. I am at the outset saying that sections of tens of millions of dollars of spending here seem to flout those aims right at the outset.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is a pretty sensible thing for the committee to say, `Before we get to the first annual report'—if this amendment is passed—`we have got a contradiction in what the minister is saying because the obligations are for environmental and ecological sustainability and excellence, but here he is earmarking tens of millions of dollars for commercial forestry arrangements, which begin, of course, with commercial tree planting.'

The minister's national vegetation initiative includes a clause which says that a further amount, yet to be decided, will be invested in the farm forestry program—that is, plantations. I want the minister to tell the committee what that further unspecified amount is that the minister reserves unto himself to know. He may be able to tell the committee now what that amount is. Obviously it will go explicitly to plantation creation. I want to know from the minister if that plantation is going to be of exotic species and if there are going to be any restriction on it.

Again—and this is very particular—will the minister give a commitment to this committee that native vegetation clearance will not be allowed for those people who get funding under this Natural Heritage Trust Fund? I want to minister to give a commitment that it will not be allowed as a lead‐in to commercial farm operations, which he is spending money out of this fund for, and that farm operators who are clearing native vegetation on their farm will not be given money for repair of damage elsewhere on the farm. In other words, there has to be a whole farm plan which does not allow the damage to continue while government funds are put to ameliorating the effects of past damage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot add anything further to the debate that Senator Brown is determined to continue, because he seeks to obstruct the passage of this bill. This is the fourth day, I think, we have been debating it. Most of Australia is enthusiastic about wanting the bill to pass and for us to get on and implement the programs. Senator Brown and a very small band of stragglers want to oppose it because they feel in some way that their legitimacy in the environment debate is being overtaken by the hundreds of thousands of Australians who are out on the ground doing good works and actually improving the environment for themselves and future generations.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to Senator Brown's amendment we are addressing on the annual reports in which he is requiring further information to be provided, the response of the government is that the bill already requires financial statements on the operation of the trust to be included in the annual report. The annual report must also include the Auditor-General's report on those statements.

Details of all grants provided from the trust will be publicly available in accordance with the normal administrative arrangements for such grants. To include the requirements that he is seeking is, therefore, not necessary and would also create an unreasonable administrative burden, particularly if reasons for all disbursements from the trust must be included in the annual report, bearing in mind that there may be several thousand community grants given annually.

In relation to any particular project, the information can be supplied on request. If anyone wants reasons for a particular decision, they can seek those reasons. This is in accordance with the normal government decision making arrangements and responsibilities. Also they may be able to require it under the ADJR Act.
So the matters Senator Brown is seeking are in our view already adequately covered under the existing provisions in the bill. Therefore, we will not be supporting the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —That speaks for itself. It is further part of the cover-up that the government is already putting in place. It is a pretty simple amendment. It requires that the ministers in their annual report give the reasons for the allocation of money and how much money is being given. That is fundamental to this whole exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: We are not talking about tiddlywinks here; we are talking about hundreds of millions of dollars of public money. We are talking about accountability and we are talking about a responsible information system as far as the public is concerned. Of course, the minister says, `People have got other processes in the morass of government that they can pursue me on if they want to. I will make it as hard for them as possible.' That is the hallmark of a minister who is not being faithful to his task of protecting the environment.

It is pretty disappointing, to say the least, that the minister is going to obstruct again an effort by this committee to put in place proper accountability. In closing off further response to the matter of forestry alone, it is quite clear that the intent of this minister is to spend money on commercial tree planting operations which are harmful to the environment—not just small amounts of money, even relatively speaking, as the minister says, but tens of millions of dollars.

He will give no assurance that the money is not going to be spent on native vegetation clearance. In fact, he has made it clear to this committee that he intends to allow money under circumstances which he has in mind to be spent on the destruction of the environment, on environmentally inimical programs, including the loss of vegetation. He says he does not know what the loss of vegetation in this country is, but we know for Queensland alone that it approaches half a million hectares licensed to be lost as recently as 1995.

So it is a very poor performance by the minister. It is a very loose and fraught set up that we see here. He has just failed in an attempt to reduce the amount of spending that was committed to by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), but we have every reason—at least the Greens do—to be very sceptical about this program's outcomes.

The minister's record in general is appalling, but when it comes to the specific of spending this amount of public money, I predict now that he is going to be a defaulter. I predict now that much of this money is going to go to people who have connections with the government or with those people who are looking after advice to these two ministers as we go down the line for projects which not only are unworthy environmentally or second-rate when there is so much to be done in this country but also are going to be lining the pockets of people who have profit as an outcome, not environmental excellence.

So the opportunity is being lost. I hope the committee will vote for this pretty clear and fundamental amendment. I note that Senator Harradine is with us again. He has, as I have said before, a record of standing up for government accountability, for transparency and for the need for the public to be informed.

Here is another test as to whether he will stand by those principles, because his vote is pivotal in ensuring that the accountability that is essential for such a big program as this, where the government has denied the Greens' initiative to have an independent and expert committee disbursing the money but left it to these two ministers with their pretty poor record on the environment. I expect that Senator Harradine will see the clear merit in this simple amendment and support it in the interests of good housekeeping and public assurance that the outcomes are going to be in the interests of the legislation's design and in the interests of the environment of this country.
Amendment negatived

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 37, page 21 (after line 2), at the end of the clause, add:

PARA.TAB: (a) an advertisement solicits gifts or bequests for the purposes of the Reserve; and
(b) the advertisement is authorised by the Commonwealth; the advertisement must include a statement to the effect that the proceeds of the gift or bequest will be applied to a government program.

SPEECH.PARA: Note: The heading to clause 37 (page 20, line 25) is altered by omitting "Commonwealth not to accept conditional " and substituting "Acceptance of ".

This amendment relates to gifts and bequests which the government is encouraging, I presume, from business but also from individuals if they feel so moved. This intention has caused some concerns, particularly amongst those organisations that are already heavily reliant on gifts and bequests to undertake environment programs. I am sure we can all think of a range of environment groups that would be so worried.

All we are asking is that we make it very clear in large letters that the money is actually going to government programs. It is just a further clarification and it is making sure that the public, particularly individuals, know that this is a government fund and that is where the money will be spent.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition also supports this amendment. We think it is a useful improvement to the bill.
—I am wondering whether we can have a response from the government. The government is presumably supporting this.
—I said it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (8) Page 23 (after line 13), after clause 43, insert:

PARA.TAB: Unless repealed earlier, this Act ceases to have effect at the expiration of 5 years after the commencement of this Act.

SPEECH.PARA: I think this is an important amendment. It does insert a sunset clause into the bill to ensure that the parliament can assess the effectiveness of the trust in five years time. it is an amendment, I suppose, that goes to reaffirming the parliament's supremacy over the executive. Without this sunset clause, the parliament really might never again get the opportunity to examine the management and effectiveness of the trust.

BREAK.PARA: As I have said to the committee, the opposition believes that the management of the environment and the allocation of $1 billion is too important to never again be considered by the parliament. This amendment does put a check on the trust. I think this could be described as an accountability amendment. It gives the parliament an opportunity in five years time to make an assessment of whether the trust has met its objectives and whether it should continue. I commend this amendment to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is quite inconsistent with the whole scheme of the trust. As we have discussed earlier during this debate, what we have in mind is an ongoing commitment to the environment, an ongoing expenditure of public funds for the goals of the trust. In fact, as you are well aware, it is intended that at the completion of this term of the trust there will still be a base capital fund of $300 million for future investment under the terms of the trust. We would hope that by the time we reach that stage that $300 million will be supported by substantial new funds.

SPEECH.PARA: To wind the whole thing up after five years I really do find to be extraordinary. All the advice that we are getting such as that from the scientists who contribute to the state of the environment report is that not only do we need a national integrated program to achieve the best environmental outcome but that even in these terms of very substantial public expenditures it is going to take a very long time to achieve the goals that we are all seeking.

I would suggest, with respect, to Senator Faulkner that there are many ways in which you can hold the government responsible for its performance in management of the trust, but to wind it up after five years would be counterproductive to the interests of all of those who are supporting a better environmental outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —As yet, I am not convinced that we need to vote for this amendment. But I do have a series of questions to put to the government. We have just voted that we do not accept the budget announcement and that we want the money spent over the five years, as was indicated by the government both during the election period and since, until this budget arrived.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) read through some of the budget documents yesterday and talked about the year three figure being $290 million spent; in year four, $297 million; in year five, $279 million; and by year six it will drop to $150 million or so. Are you now going to revise that to ensure that the fund is spent over the five years—in other words, that that $152 million is divided by at least the previous two, if not three, years. If you are, when can we see the revision?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to rewrite the budget on the run. The committee has made an amendment. We will see whether this bill is passed subject to the amendment and that will be given consideration by the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My concern is that despite very clear action by this chamber and despite the Senate making it abundantly clear what it feels about expenditure, at the end of five years, you could have $300 million or $400 million left and there is no way that any of us can force the government to spend the money. So I am tempted to vote for the sunset clause in order to bring the bill back before this place for us to revisit these issues, unless we can get a very clear undertaking now from the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) that he will go away—obviously it will take some time—and ensure that we can have back before us—certainly by the end of this session, I would hope—a revised expenditure for the trust.

SPEECH.PARA: If he suggests that the government may have trouble meeting the obligation to spend this money, I certainly could give him a range of programs in South Australia and I am sure any state government could put in a range of projects. Having spoken to Landcare groups, I know their concern is that they have not had time, this time, to put in detailed submissions. So I expect that the submissions you will get in the second year from the on‐the‐ground organisations will be huge. I do not know what the current level of applications is running at but I cannot see how this government can possibly say that they cannot find sufficient funding. You have said there is an enormous need out there. I think all of us in this chamber agree with you. So what I need, Minister, is a commitment that you are going to come back to this place within the next month or so and give us the revised spending plans that the government has.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, I cannot rewrite the budget on the run. The committee has expressed a view. It has done more than express a view—it has amended our bill. We will have to consider that as the bill goes back to the other House. If Senator Lees wants to vote to wind up the trust after just five years, she will so vote. But I would have thought it would be an extraordinary decision for her to take and she can explain to her constituency why she does not want the trust to continue after a period of five years.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with her that as the public understanding of the potential of the trust grows and the public contribution on the ground grows, there will be more applications for support, and the government welcomes that. That is why, in the published figures, we did provide for an expenditure in this next year of $187 million but in the following year for $290 million. That is largely in recognition of what she just said.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not necessarily voting to scrap the fund. We are asking that parliament have another opportunity to revisit the issue to see whether or not it really is working, whether or not it is the best vehicle.
—But the amendment is that the act ceases to have effect.

—Obviously we need to have it back before this chamber to revisit. It is my understanding that the amendment gives us an opportunity to revisit the issue. If that is not the understanding, perhaps Senator Faulkner will make it clearer. As I said when I began this debate, this is not an issue on which we have a firm opinion.

SPEECH.PARA: I have a couple of questions which I will put to Senator Faulkner after Senator Harradine speaks. I ask the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill): what are your plans now for years six, seven and beyond? Obviously you have got your $300 million left in there. Assuming that you get few, if any, additional donations, what is the government's plan as far as funding for the environment is concerned? Where are we going in years six, seven and beyond?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the questions that have been asked by Senator Lees are important. I would like to know what is going to happen to that $300 million and what is going to happen in subsequent years—in the sixth, seventh and eighth years. Obviously, you will not be able to say what is going to happen in precise terms because you will not know how much will be in the fund, but you do know that there will be at least $300 million in the fund.

SPEECH.PARA: As I read Senator Faulkner's proposal, it is an attempt to at least keep a hands‐on approach to this matter. However, the government may have its way of keeping hands‐on control of what is happening. If we take, as I think we ought to take, the views that are expressed by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), that he is very keen to see the fund progress, I would like to hear from him—I am sure the whole committee would like to hear from him—as to what is his view. How will things operate in the sixth, seventh and eighth years?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not have a public position on how we might replenish the fund after a period of six years. We will have a base of $300 million, which is a good base. Obviously we will have a large knowledge base from the experience of the operation of the fund. We have committed ourselves to it being an ongoing program. We hesitate to even be so presumptive as to assume that we will be controlling the fund in five years time, Senator Harradine. If we are, if that is the will of the people, we will be seeking to continue it in accordance with the spirit that we have set it up.

SPEECH.PARA: We see the fund as an ongoing program. We have provided a way to commence it with an infusion of $1.1 billion, which would keep us going in terms of what we have published. We have said at the end of that period there will be $300 million left as a base, and our objective would be to see that base built upon. But we do not have a published plan—we talk about these things—for so far down the track.

It will frighten the Greens—and I hesitate to say it, Senator Harradine—but I am of the view that this program is going to be taken up with such enthusiasm by the community that we will find the community and, in particular, corporates in this country wanting to play a part too and contribute to the growth of the capital base in the years ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why would it do that?
—Because Senator Brown will assume that someone will make a profit out of it, and he would be opposed to that. I think there is growing—
—You are saying `the Greens' as a political party?

—His Greens. I think there are several political parties, but his Greens as opposed to environmentalists, Senator Faulkner. So I think there will be widespread community support and enthusiasm for this. There will be a number of different ways in which we will be able to build that public fund for the future, and I think that is very exciting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask Senator Faulkner a question. If the fund is successful, does he envisage that we would revisit this legislation, say, a month or two out of the deadline and simply remove the sunset clause—and perhaps the clerks would help with process; or, if the decision is that the fund has not worked—for example, perhaps nothing like the amount of promised money has been spent through it—what would he envisage would happen to the remaining $300 million at the end of it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —What I envisage would occur is that any government would bring legislation back. I am hopeful, given the timetable that we are speaking of, that we will be rid of the current government and a new Labor government will be in office, which will have a far more genuine commitment to the environment. I am hoping a newly elected Labor administration will be able to demonstrate that to the confidence of any future Senate committee. I would expect, regardless of the outcome of the next election, that the government in office would bring back legislation in relation to the Natural Heritage Trust Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: What I am interested in here is an accountability mechanism, Senator Lees. I am concerned that the parliament ought to have an opportunity to address these issues. I have to say to you that I am even more concerned—having heard the fact that the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) does not appear to have any vision at this time—about what happens in the year 2001 or 2002, which I think is the issue that both you, Senator Lees, and Senator Harradine raise with the minister. What opportunity does the parliament have to pass judgment on the trust? How does the parliament assess the effectiveness of the trust at that time? What does the government plan to do itself?

In the absence of any information from the government about its possible approaches at that time from Senator Hill—who is silent on these matters and unable to answer, I think, the proper questions that have been directed to him by both Senator Lees and Senator Harradine—I think the Senate is entitled to be alarmed and concerned about this lack of vision from the government. Given that there appears to be no answer from the environment minister on these issues, I think it gives me even greater confidence that the only sensible course of action on the part of the Senate is for us to ensure that there is a sunset clause so we can take the necessary action.

Senator Hill is either unable or unwilling to answer the questions that have been asked of him today in relation to the government's intentions on this matter. I think that ought to be a concern to the committee. The opposition's proposal to address this lack of commitment on the part of the government is the amendment that is before the chair in relation to the cessation of the act. The then government obviously will have a majority in the House of Representatives and a capacity to bring forward appropriate legislation, but we are dealing with this issue in the light of a complete lack of vision on the part of the government in office now as to how they might approach the issue of the trust after five or six years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also support the amendment. I hope that Senator Harradine does too. He has blocked almost every other amendment which would lead to good housekeeping and accountability as far as the disbursement of this money is concerned. Even at this late time, a little measure like this to give the parliament a complete opportunity of review five years down the line is worth while. It is something to be supported, all the more because of the lack of accountability at all levels that has been written into this legislation and defended by the coalition and Senator Harradine, despite the best efforts of the rest of this committee to make the ministers accountable.

—I ask the minister: if the government agrees with the amendments that have thus far been made in the chamber, would that mean that the government would then come forward with estimates different from those that are contained now in the budget papers for the expenditure of the moneys from the fund over a period of five years, as per our previous amendment? I am not asking the minister to say what the government is going to do and what it is not going to do. Obviously, he is not in a position to do that. But were the government and the House of Representatives to agree with that amendment, would it then be for the government to revise the expenditure estimates that are currently contained in the budget?

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, I cannot take it further than what I have said. The Senate has passed an amendment in relation to the years and expressed the basis of that change to be that it does not accept the government's argument that a better program can be delivered over the next five years—at least some believe that a better program can be delivered in the next four years; some just vote against the government because they always vote against the government's amendments. Obviously, if the bill passes with that change, we will have to consider the matters that I have mentioned and decide what is the appropriate course of action to take. I cannot talk about rewriting the budget forward estimates in the course of this debate. There are some very serious issues that would have to be considered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I did give a good deal of consideration to the amendments that the government proposed previously—the ones that have been dealt with. I look upon this measure not as a budget measure. It really is not a budget measure when you come to think of it. It is a measure that was announced by the government prior to the last election. It really stands or falls upon another measure; that is, the part sale of Telstra. And that did occur. That measure came before the parliament, and the parliament agreed to it on the basis that amounts from that sale would go into the Natural Heritage Trust. So I am looking at it as a matter separate from the budget.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has decided, thankfully, to include the measures in the budget, obviously in anticipation that the money will flow from the sale of Telstra—at least the money that the government has promised for this particular purpose. In my view, substantially more than the government stated may result from the third sale will be realised.

My difficulty now is in having some certainty about what is going to happen. It was announced that the billion dollars would be spent over a period of five years. I believe that was the government's commitment, and I think it is our responsibility to encourage the government by voting against that particular amendment that came forward from the government. I therefore ask the minister—I hope that he might be able to enlighten us a little bit more than he has—if the government accepts the amendment of the Senate, which is four square on target with the government's own promises to the electorate, would the amounts that are contained in the budget paper dealing with forward estimates of expenditure have to be amended? If that is not the case, I would feel that I would have to vote for the amendment that is put forward by Senator Faulkner, because that surely would require the government to act in that manner.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is your choice, Senator Harradine. If you choose to wind up the trust after five years, you vote that way. There has been, of course, a bit of water under the bridge since the election in that the fund has increased by an extra $100 million, which does not seem to have been taken into account in this debate at the moment. The other factor that I would ask the committee to take into account is that because we do not have the capital contribution from the sale of one‐third of Telstra—it has not occurred yet and will not for a while, and then there will obviously be considerable accounting thereafter—we have had to draw on $42 million of public revenue for this year for all of the preparatory work. We are going to have draw on another $187 million of public expenditure—these are on the figures we have published—for this year. Within our accounting there has been no charge for the trust doing so. So, in effect, it is an extra contribution from public revenue to meet that earlier commitment.
—It's not a bad dividend you got from Telstra recently though, was it?
—I am sorry, I cannot hear.
—Three billion. Your recent dividend from Telstra was an extraordinary dividend.

—It will presumably be reflected in the ultimate capital sale price, but I hear what you say. You could say it similarly out of drawing on dividends of Telstra. It is just in the normal business of managing a government asset at the moment, Senator Harradine.

BREAK.PARA: On the figures we had published, as I said, the expenditure over the next two years will be pretty much just what we had promised it would be. It is just that there will be less in this coming year than the following year because there is still a lot of work being done out there within the community, within the regions, and within state governments, to ensure that we get the maximum ultimate environmental benefit for the public expenditure. It just seems to me to be sensible planning and planning that I would have thought that this chamber would support.

Be that as it may, this amendment before the committee really has very little to do with that; this amendment is the opposition's attempt to wind up the trust through repealing this legislation after a period of five years. Goodness only knows what is supposed to happen to the $300 million. I suppose Senator Faulkner's intention is that it should go back into public revenue. I do not know if Senator Brown accepts that; I would have thought he would believe that it ought to be spent on the environment.

It just seems to me to be extraordinary, when all the enlightened advisers say that what you need is a trust in perpetuity—what you need is a long‐term program—for this Senate to decide that it wants to wind it up after five years. I do not know what will happen as a consequence of that; you are talking about new legislation and new attitudes. It may never be re‐established. I do not know. It is in the hands of this Senate. If it takes as long as this debate, a future government might be reluctant to bring a bill back again.

It just seems to me to be crazy, when all the work has been done and the debate has been had here—literally hundreds and hundreds of hours spent on debating the detail of this legislation in this chamber and out of this chamber, legal advices, state government involvement and the like—that after five years you simply want to wind it all up. But, if that is the will of the Senate, so be it. The government will obviously be disappointed because we believe in a trust in perpetuity. That was our commitment and that is why we have provided for a starting point of $300 million at the end of the stated period that we had prescribed.

I must say that, apart from Senator Faulkner saying that in some ways this would hold the government accountable, I have not really heard any other argument for this provision. But it does not hold the government accountable; it winds up the trust. It repeals the act and winds up the trust at the end of five years. If that is what the Senate decides, if that is what the Greens and the Democrats and the Labor Party believe, that there should not be a natural heritage trust extending beyond five years, then the parliament is in control of its own destiny. But, certainly, the government will be very disappointed, and I suspect most of Australia will be very disappointed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I had not intended to enter this committee stage debate again, but given that the minister brings into question the motivations of the opposition in moving this amendment, let me set the record straight. You see, this is an issue of credibility and Senator Hill does not have very much credibility on the environment. This is an issue of accountability and it appears that Senator Hill is not very interested in accountability on the environment because, of course, what Senator Hill's party did—what the coalition did—before the election was to say to the Australian people with hand over the heart, `We will spend $1.149 billion on the environment.'
—And we changed it to $1.249 billion.

—He also said, `We will spend that money over five years.' He also said, `We will ensure that this spending on the environment is over and above all that record spending that the previous Labor government had budgeted for.' Senator Hill makes the aside to me across the table that they are spending more than $1.15 billion. It is true; I acknowledge that, Senator Hill. I also acknowledge the fact that, in relation to the spending and the heritage trust, the reasons for the change in the quantum of money are something that have been much speculated on in this place, and by many who have been interested in the political process for some time.

SPEECH.PARA: This is where Senator Harradine and I have a fundamental disagreement. I did not like the nature of the arrangements with Senator Harradine and Senator Colston in relation to what I have always described as the Telstra environment fund—the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. I think the opposition has been very clearly on the record in relation to that. So let me make that absolutely clear.

I acknowledge that there is more money in the trust fund, and I understand why. But the government breached its commitment to provide this level of funding over five years; it stretched it out to six years. The government breached its commitment to ensure that this environment funding would be over and above the funding voted in the forward estimates of the previous Labor government. It broke that promise lock, stock and barrel. That has been the achievement of the coalition government in relation to the environment. It has also sold out the strong position Australia had both nationally and internationally in terms of environment protection in a whole raft of areas that I do not want to canvass again today.

Do not question the motives of the opposition on this issue, Senator Hill. Our motivations are to hold you accountable. Our motivations are to ensure that this Liberal government does something to protect the environment in this country. Our motivation is to try to ensure that you do not continue to sell out the protection of Australia's natural environment. They are our motivations, and you know it. Our motivation is to try to ensure that you and your successors have the same level of commitment as the Labor Party has had to protecting Australia's environment. That is what we are serious about. They are our motivations.

TALK.START.PARA: —We'd want to do better than that.
—You cannot do better than that. You can only ever dream on and aspire to what the Labor government was able to achieve, and you know it.

BREAK.PARA: We are serious about ensuring that it is not the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy in a coalition government who is responsible for environment protection in this country. They are our motivations. I will not have Senator Hill come into this committee and misrepresent what I am trying to achieve through this amendment. Whether the amendment is successful or not, that is what the opposition is trying to achieve.

It is for those proper concerns that we have to use whatever mechanisms are available to us to ensure that we keep this government up to the mark on the protection of Australia's environment. They have sold it out in the 14 months that they have been in office. There are so many examples, and they grow as a result of the disgraceful environment budget that was brought down the day before yesterday.

This may not be all Senator Hill's fault. It may just be that time and time again he gets rolled in the cabinet by his colleagues. Maybe he is fair dinkum when he goes in. Maybe he is taking up the case for the environment, carrying the cudgels into cabinet and with his colleagues. But he is not delivering. We are concerned. This appears to be the only mechanism we have available to us to protect Australia's environment, to ensure that there is reasonable funding for the protection of the environment in this country, to see not all the environment programs that have been hard fought and hard won over a long period of time cut, slashed, changed, rebadged or delayed. We do not want to see that.

We are fair dinkum about the protection of the environment. I will not have sell‐outs like Senator Hill and the coalition government question the motivation of the Labor Party. Even Senator Brown has now acknowledged that he was conned by the coalition prior to the last election. Many of his colleagues in the Greens were conned by the coalition. I do not want to see the Australian people conned. I want to see a government held accountable. This is a mechanism that will achieve that. They are the motivations of this amendment, and I will not accept any misrepresentation on Senator Hill's part.

I commend the amendment to the Senate. If it fails, we will use whatever other mechanisms we can to hold the government accountable in terms of both its environment spending and its environment policy. I can assure the committee that we will not slack off on that important role that the Labor Party considers is a high priority while ever the Liberals remain in government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the sentiments just expressed by Senator Faulkner. We are trying to get this government to commit to its promises. I believe what the Senate did by removing the government's attempt to stretch this fund over six years was to try to bring it back to its basic promise.

SPEECH.PARA: My problem with this amendment is that I am not sure that it is watertight. We could get five years out and find that we are still $500 million or $600 million or $80 million short. Who knows what this government is going to do? What Senator Hill is asking us to do is to trust him; to trust that the government abide by the wishes of this Senate; to trust that they will abide by their original statements and spend the money as they have forecast—and now as we have said over five years.

In weighing up whether or not there is any point in a sunset clause, I am weighing up the fact that this chamber cannot force a government to spend money. It is beyond the powers of this chamber. We have to trust that the government is going to abide by the wishes of this chamber and the wishes of the Australian people who elected the government on the promise that it would spend $1.15 billion over five years. Winding it up is probably not—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a wind-up. The act ceases to have effect.

—I do not quite agree with Senator Hill that it is a wind-up; it is a chance for this chamber to revisit it. Senator, we can very easily remove the sunset clause at some time previous to the date upon which it would come into effect.

SPEECH.PARA: I am inclined not to support this amendment but to make it very clear to the government that the Democrats will be watching every step of the way, leaving no stone unturned as to both the amount of money you are spending through the trust as well as how it is being spent and whether or not it is achieving anything. I have great hope—and indeed I believe, from what I have seen so far of the work on the ground—that we really will achieve something with all of this. So I am of a mind at this time not to support a sunset clause but to acknowledge that, even with a sunset clause, we cannot force the government to spend money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat disappointed to hear what Senator Lees has said. I understand her difficulties. She has brought forward a package of very worthwhile amendments in the face of the government having the numbers, through Senator Harradine, to do almost anything it wants to, as far as this legislation is concerned.
—I would have thought I lost the big one, actually.

—Yes. That having been said, the point of what Senator Lees had to say is that there is not accountability, there are not proper mechanisms and there is not transparency—and we are talking about $1¼ billion of public money as well as the Australian environment. Any mechanism which allows us to revisit what is being done concerning the expenditure of that huge amount of money ought to be entertained. That is why the Greens will be supporting the amendment from Senator Faulkner.

SPEECH.PARA: On the face of it you can argue, as Senator Hill will, that it is a wind-up; it is not. It is the ability for this chamber, and the parliament as a whole, to review totally the expenditure of this huge amount of money from the partial sale of Telstra, with there being no other proper review mechanism.

We are not to get a proper outline in the annual reports of what the ministers are doing and what the results of the expenditure of this money are. We have been blocked from finding out as a matter of course the instructions that the minister will be giving to the advisory committee. The minister himself has refused an amendment from Senator Lees which would have ensured that he had a veto if his fellow minister on the board, the minister for primary industries, was to spend money in a way which was inimical to the environment.

We have had the minister fail to say that he will not be allowing money to be spent on native vegetation clearance. He has failed also to give any good explanation as to why four times as much money is to go into restoring native vegetation as is to go into preventing further destruction of Australia's native vegetation cover and damage to its biodiversity, with the loss of wildlife and rare species of flora and fauna which will result from that enormous damage and which is occurring right now in front of our very faces.

The minister leaves this fund open to the potential for money to be spent to enhance that damage rather than to put a stop to it. He is not going to use any leverage whatsoever through the hundreds of millions of dollars of this fund going into projects through state governments, or state government guidance, to ensure that that rapid destruction of native vegetation coverage and loss of our prime forests, including rainforests, is halted.

The leverage is there in this legislation to make sure that the state governments put an end to native vegetation clearance before it is necessary to spend $200 million‐plus in restoring the damage of past vegetation clearance. So, on the one hand, we will have hundreds of millions of dollars out of this fund being spent to repair the damage and loss of native vegetation coverage; on the other hand, this minister's fellow governments—governments of National or Liberal parties around this country—will continue to authorise wholesale destruction of native vegetation. What sort of accountability is that?

Anything that we can do to try to put a check on this, to try to see how it is going, ought to be supported, certainly in terms of public accountability for the huge amount of public funds being expended. Senator Hill says that Telstra is a government instrumentality. Senator Hill, it is a public instrumentality. It does not belong the government; it belongs to the people of Australia. The semantics give you away. It is necessary for public accountability here.

On that alone, Minister, we need some ability to review what you or consequent ministers for the environment and primary industry will be doing further down the line. But in terms of the environment itself, of course, the imperative becomes even greater. So I will be supporting the amendment.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Clause 44, page 23 (line 21), omit "fishing or".
(19) Clause 44, page 23 (line 22), omit paragraph (d) of the definition of agriculture , substitute:

PARA.TAB: (d) the planting and growing of trees for commercial purposes (but not the commercial exploitation of native forests).

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments redefine the definition of `agriculture'. The difficulty we have with that definition as it stands in this legislation is that, if you look back at `sustainable agriculture' in an earlier clause, it would allow for fishing operations with a commercial viability outcome to be given funds from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund, and for forestry operations with commercial viability as their prime outcome—nothing else required—to be defined as `agricultural operations' which would get money from the Telstra Natural Heritage Trust Fund.

I reiterate: this is an environmental fund. It ought to be going to environmental repair. Even more importantly, it ought to be going to preventing environmental damage. It is not about enhancing the profitability of fishing or farming operations; it is about enhancing the environmental outcomes. Very often you can achieve those two things together, but, as this legislation is formulated, these two ministers—the Minister for the Environment and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy—would be able to direct money into fishing or logging operations because their economic viability would be enhanced. That is how sloppy the legislation is. That is how loose it is.

As Senator Lees said a while ago, we are left in the position of this minister saying, `Trust us.' I won't go through it again, but he has an appalling record on the environment. He cannot be trusted; it cannot be left to him. I am moving these amendments to ensure that we do not have money simply going into fishing and forestry operations for the enhancement of their profitability but to ensure that the money does go to agricultural operations which are environmentally sound and, hopefully, are going to enhance the environment rather than just allow us to tread water, particularly in relation to forestry operations which are not involved in the destruction of native forests.

We know that the minister sitting here has licensed the wholesale destruction of native forests in Australia. He has been part of that process. We know that he is part of the move by government to remove restrictions on destruction of native forests of national estate value and even world heritage value in states like Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania.

We know that he is currently in the business of licensing the destruction of pure rainforests in Tasmania so that they can be woodchipped and sent to Japan to ultimately end up on the rubbish dumps—and, by the way, to increase the problems of disposal of garbage, because the prices of Australian woodchips are undercutting the recycling programs in Japan. That is creating an environmental problem not only for Tasmania and other states of Australia but also for Japan itself and other countries which are recipients of our forestry operations.

Moreover, the minister has now become part of a process of allowing companies to export whole logs from Australia's forests—and, very shortly, whole logs from Australia's native forests, without any further licensing requirements. So you export not only the environment amenity here in Australia but also the jobs and the downstream processing.

Senator Lees, I am afraid I am not one of those folk—I suspect you are in the same group—who will trust this minister. We need to tighten up the legislation wherever we can. I recommend to the committee the Greens amendments which are going to tighten up the interpretation of the definition of agriculture in clause 44 to ensure that money is not helped to go, through the looseness of that definition, to commercial operations which do not have environmental considerations but which have economic considerations as their primary outcome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully understand and indeed totally respect Senator Brown's motives in moving these two amendments. But I must say at the outset of the comments I am about to make that I need to ask that we vote upon them separately. I think what he is doing with amendment No. 19 is exactly the opposite to what he and I are trying to do. I want to put to him a scenario, and this is from my visit not so long ago to Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: If we prevent farmers who have large amounts of native forest on their land from having access to this fund because they may, in the future, wish to selectively log a bit of it or perhaps—as one of the chaps I spoke to in northern Tasmania said—take about one log per hectare, particularly for furniture, then they will look at the other alternatives that this government has put in place which Senator Brown has just outlined. They could woodchip the whole lot with no second questions—with no environment impact statements and with no recourse in Tasmania or, as we said already, in Queensland and some parts of New South Wales, even to native vegetation clearance legislation. There are no controls.

Suppose you have a farmer who has—and I have seen several farms in Tasmania—quite a bit of native forest and the farmer wants to do something with his or her land. The alternative this government has given them so far is, `Woodchip the lot, take the cash and run and then we will help you put in a plantation.' There is a chink in this bill for them to actually get some money to fence that to keep the cattle out, to start some regrowth that, hopefully, will not get chewed back down to the roots if it manages to get its head above the grass anyway, to have a forest that is reasonably biologically intact and to nurture that and not to take the easy way out of trashing the lot which, as I have already said, is something that this government is encouraging.

What is in the bill is not tight enough. This is why the Democrats have tried, through a series of previous amendments, to stop wholesale land clearing, which this government apparently is unconcerned about and which it is certainly not prepared to take the states on about. Obviously the last thing the Democrats want is any more clear‐felling of native vegetation, whether it is woodland, whether it is forest or whether it is, as I have seen recently on the Errinundra plateau, rainforest. The way this particular amendment is worded—that is, `commercial exploitation'—means that that farmer would, I presume, have to sign up to never commercially exploit that area of forest in any way whatsoever.

Turning to Tasmania—because it is an area I have visited; I have walked through some of the forests there and looked at the state some of them are in—generation after generation has gone in and taken timber out here or has flattened it there without even bothering to do some of the basic work that some forestry departments have managed to do in some spots. They are looking seriously at this government's option of clear‐felling. We have to do everything we can to stop that. I believe one way would be to give them the opportunity to selectively log, to carefully log to maintain biodiversity, but to be able to sell a selection of logs each year, to the furniture market in particular.

Honey producers in Tasmania are also concerned about what is happening. They are losing the very trees on which their bees depend. They do not want hectare after hectare of Eucalyptus nitens. To begin with, they all come into flower at the one time of the year, so the bees sit in their hives and live off the honey for the rest of the year. So, in a way, with this amendment we are caught between a rock and a hard place. Both of us are trying to achieve the same thing: both of us are trying to reduce the amount of felling of native forest and, with this amendment in particular, of native forest on private land.

Unfortunately, I do not think this amendment will help. We need clear guidelines as part of the agreements under this trust for state governments to abide by. The guidelines should start by saying that, if it is a heritage forest, if it is next to or within sight of world heritage forest, it does not get touched; if it includes rainforest or remnant species, it does not get touched. But then the farmer will need money from this trust to make sure that it is fenced, that cattle are kept out, that there are no `accidental' fires. They will need some incentives to protect it. But some of these farmers will have other bits of forest on their land that they will want to exploit—and I use that word deliberately—but on the basis of selective logging, carefully managed, with the environment as a very high priority.

I am not able to support the amendment in the way it is worded, unfortunately, and nor will I be able to support the government's intentions. Having listened to the debate between Senator Hill and Senator Brown, I have no great confidence that this government understands the urgent situation we have in this country where little is left of many of these forest types.

I hope, Senator Hill, as we watch this trust in action, that you will get agreements with the states that really mean something and that, in those agreements, there are acknowledgments that farmers will need support to keep those heritage and old‐growth forests and to keep remnant vegetation in particular—and there is some in the mallee in South Australia that is virtually the last of its type.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason we have included this definition is, firstly, to be consistent with the income tax act. Agriculture includes both fishing and forest operations. I think it is a sensible legislative practice to try to keep definitions consistent across various pieces of legislation. Secondly, there is the reason we have tried to emphasise during this debate—which of course is not accepted by Senator Brown—that sustainable agriculture is vitally important to achieving best environmental outcomes. In `sustainable agriculture' I include sustainable fishing.

SPEECH.PARA: I actually look forward to us having the environment side of this debate, Senator Brown, and to having a greater opportunity to influence sustainable fishing practices. That would be a good outcome for our environment, so why you would want to exclude it I really do not understand. You seem to think in some ways that we will simply be therefore using this public fund as some sort of industry support for the fishing industry as such. That is not the purpose. The purpose is to support sustainable agricultural practices because that leads to a good environmental outcome, and that is what we all should be aiming at.

The same argument applies in relation to forestry, which was taken up by Senator Lees. It is very important that we at the environmental end of the debate have a greater influence on agricultural practices that include both fishing and forestry. That is the purpose primarily of including it within the definition. I trust that after the debate on this clause we will still have the opportunity to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I reiterate that the looseness of this definition is a matter of concern from an environmental viewpoint, because we are left to fall back on the `trust me' line of the minister. And he cannot be trusted. He says he has sustainable fishing and the environment in mind, but recently he gave the go‐ahead for fishing in eight areas of the Great Barrier Reef that were hitherto totally protected as part of an experiment to see what the damage will or will not be. When we look at his record, we cannot have faith in his disbursement of funds for what he says is ecologically good management because he does not know what that term means.

SPEECH.PARA: I heard what Senator Lees had to say. I am afraid the problem here is that I have an amendment which says, `Let us not put this money into commercial logging operations in native forests', because that is what will happen as the definition stands. It simply talks about forestry operations—any sort of forestry operations. There is no exclusion there.

Senator Lees pointed to a case where somebody might come in and take a tree here and a tree there. If there is to be some measure of restriction on what the minister can interpret as agricultural forestry operations, then it is incumbent upon the Democrats to come forward with that definition.

BREAK.PARA: If you are concerned about biological viability and biodiversity, the most problematic area and the area of worst threat at the moment in Tasmania is that of woodlands in particular and forests on private land. If you look at the congregations of species which are rare, endangered or facing extinction, both animal species and plant species, you will find that these are on private lands which are in the midlands and elsewhere in Tasmania. This is a matter of enormous concern to us.

If some restriction was put on spending of money out of this fund for the logging, selective or otherwise, of those private lands, which was going to ensure that environmental enhancement was the outcome, I would be supporting it. But that restriction is not there. If Senator Lees and the Democrats vote against this amendment, they are allowing this minister to determine which areas will be logged and which will not.

Last week we had a very surprising and major criticism of the regional forest agreement process, which is occurring in Tasmania at the moment, by one of the greatest experts in the country on the plight of native species, on biodiversity, on logging and forest operations and, in particular, on the woodlands area of Tasmania, where there are a large number of operators who see money in the trees in the back paddocks which previously were not a commercial operation. With the imminent lifting of restrictions by this minister for the environment and his government, there is going to be very little restriction at all on the clearance of those woodlands for woodchipping and/or for other purposes on the altar of the current logging industry arrangements, which are almost open slather as they stand.

Senator Lees says that there are exceptional cases where there may be people who are going to carefully, selectively, take trees out of their woods for furniture making purposes. That may be so, but they are the exception, Senator Lees. By not supporting this amendment, you are allowing this minister to make the determination as to what is ecologically good and what is not. I warn you that the outcome is not going to be good.

I warn you again that the determinant of who gets money from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund in Tasmania, the advisory committee, is not in the department of the environment; it is in the department of the Premier's office and it is headed up by a logger from Forestry Tasmania—a logger who has a record of opposing vehemently the Wilderness Society, the Conservation Trust in Tasmania and other organisations who have been working to get good environmental outcomes as far as logging in Tasmania is concerned. He is going to be the determinant of the disbursement of these funds in Tasmania.

We need to make sure that we tighten up the guidelines to prevent wrong environmental outcomes. I do not trust the process and I do not trust this definition of logging operations as part of agricultural operations which are acceptable to this minister to be passing on funds to. You can find the exception, Senator Lees, but there is much more to it than that. There is much more at stake.

A recent survey in Tasmania, which asked property owners whether they would be in the business of protecting what is left of their native forests if offered an opportunity for commercial exploitation, showed that 83 per cent would go in for the commercial exploitation. The other 17 per cent fall into the category you are talking about, Senator Lees, but it is the 83 per cent that I am concerned about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I hesitate to take this point of order, but it seems to be the custom of Senator Brown to not address his remarks through the chair as he should do so.
—I was a little bit diverted, but I am sure Senator Brown will address his remarks through the chair.

—I will do that. I was doing that, in effect, but I am addressing the point that Senator Lees was making. I find Senator Harradine's contribution there to be one of the more constructive ones he has made during this debate. I think Senator Lees should consider again not supporting this important amendment that the Greens are proposing to this particular clause of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I realise that time is of the essence, but I do have to make it abundantly clear that at the moment farmers have two options. They can leave their forests untouched—by `untouched' I mean probably open to stock—and get nothing from them. Maybe there is a small percentage who are prepared to keep on doing that, but I believe that, unfortunately, that percentage is reducing.

SPEECH.PARA: There certainly are some out there who are prepared to set aside their land for wildlife. Many of them have stickers to that effect on their front gates. But some of those who have some of the most important areas are looking at a second option; that is, to clear-fell all or most of it and put in plantations. In Tasmania, hectare after hectare is going under blue gums and nitens.

All I am saying is that we should give them a third option; that is, some money to conserve—hopefully with a decent state government program that involves locking some of it away, yes, but allowing other areas to be selectively logged, with the environment as the highest priority. And that will need some money for things like fencing and, hopefully, money towards some proper management advice also. While Senator Brown and I obviously have the same end in mind—that is, conserving our native forests—when you are looking at forests on private land, it often unfortunately comes down to economics.

This government's incentives are to clear-fell—they have removed the restrictions on woodchipping from private land—or to plant plantations. They are even putting in plantations in forestry areas in Tasmania now—pseudo‐plantations, because you are getting some regrowth coming back—and with the rest of it they are trying to hand plant selected and chosen species. Unfortunately, I am not able to support this amendment, but I hope that is not twisted around to mean in some way I am not trying to do everything I possibly can to protect what forests remain on private land.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the opposition, I indicate that we have not been persuaded to support amendments Nos 18 and 19 standing in the name of the Australian Greens.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I am happy to do as Senator Lees requested and put these two amendments separately, if the committee is agreeable. Secondly, I reiterate that if there is a third option then the Democrats should have it before the committee. As it is there are two options—one that the Greens put forward and one that the government put forward. In the absence of a third option from the Democrats, it is their choice which option they take up.
—I propose to put the amendments separately. The question is that amendment No. 18 moved by Senator Brown be agreed to.
—I now propose to put amendment No. 19 moved by Senator Brown.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Brown's ) be agreed to.
