TITLE.XREF: EXPORT FINANCE AND INSURANCE CORPORATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 20 March, on motion by Senator Hill:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Export Finance and Insurance Corporation Amendment Bill before the Senate today brings into effect a measure that was announced in last year's budget. It has the effect of transferring the DIFF loan liabilities from EFIC to the government's national interest account and for the consequent payment to the Commonwealth of a portion—$40 million—of EFIC's reserves.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill means that the Commonwealth will assume contingent liabilities of some $1.7 billion in respect of the DIFF loans. The removal of DIFF loans from EFIC's account removes the difficulties which EFIC has faced through concentration of exposure on the fairly narrow range of countries assisted through DIFF.

The opposition does not oppose the legislation. In itself the legislation is non-controversial. However, I point out that the DIFF scheme and the potential for loans under it have been far from non-controversial. I remind the Senate of the circumstances we got ourselves into last year when, unilaterally, the government announced the ending of the DIFF scheme.

We remember the embarrassment that was caused to the nation and specifically to the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) in his telling the parliament that not one country had complained to him about the abolition of the scheme. It was shown in a very short space of time that it was true that not one had, but that many had. The minister was forced to come into the parliament and indicate he had misled it.

It was in direct contravention of the code of conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—a code of conduct which has been honoured in the breach, not in the application, because this was not the first time that there had been scant regard paid to it. The only circumstance in which people are ever ultimately required to honour it is when they are forced to—when they are caught out.

The decision of the government and the foreign minister in particular, embarrassing as it was for him, was also a very significant setback for a lot of Australian companies which had come to rely on the DIFF scheme. At the time the minister said that every formal offer for DIFF would be honoured. However, that formal offer only covered seven projects worth some $186 million. In addition to that formal offer, there were 50 other projects worth $1 billion which were effectively scuttled because they had received letters of advice to proceed, but not the technicality of the formal offer.

The circumstances of this were that this scheme had been in existence over a long period of time. Not only did it have bipartisan support but there was a commitment during the election campaign to maintain it. No doubt it was one of those promises that has hit the fence because it was not a core promise. The government went to the election saying that the DIFF scheme would be retained. Not only is this scheme important for our bilateral relationships but also it has been an important driving force for industry devel opment, because it has been through this scheme that our heavy engineering industry has actually positioned itself into export markets.

If we think back a decade, at that time heavy engineering in this country did very little by way of exports. The difficulty is that it was very hard to get into export markets, particularly in developing countries where you have to compete against other companies bidding for projects where their governments are prepared to back them.

Essentially, the backing of those companies comes in the form of either assistance with soft loans through the aid budget or else through a cushioning of the impact, a lessening of the risk. There is risk associated with these things, sovereign risk, but there is also the risk in the sense that there is a fairly long lead time before you get payment for the completion of the product.

The nature of the DIFF scheme was not just an essential part of our aid program but also a sensible use of aid, the leverage of government money, to assist Australian investment, Australian manufacturers, Australian expertise and Australian services being exported. The heavy engineering sector has seen a huge growth in exports due in no small measure to the fact that many of the companies were able to rely on the DIFF scheme.

There were 52 projects in the DIFF pipeline when the foreign minister created this mess. There were 52 projects but they involved something in the order of 600 Australian companies. There is a multiplier effect in terms of the companies that can be brought into the network. That is what we talk about when we say we should use the leverage of government assistance—assistance which both parties agreed to—which is important for the countries to which it is directed.

Why can we not have it both ways? Why can we not at the same time say, `We are prepared to give you that assistance. We are prepared to assist you in your developmental projects. But, provided our own contractors, our own businesses, are up to the mark, then they should be able to use this assistance and get themselves into the marketplace'? They could be the most efficient producers in the world. They could have the best expertise in the world, but without this assistance they would not be competing on a level playing field. They would have to compete in circumstances where the companies against which they have to bid have the backing of their governments.

The point we are making here is that whilst this technical change in terms of the transfer of the DIFF loan liabilities from EFIC to the government national interest account is taking place we want to take the opportunity to urge the government to rethink its position on this scheme.

I understand that the Simons report recommends a scheme which bears marked similarity to the outgoing DIFF scheme. That is in itself an indictment of the government's short‐sightedness on this issue. The government scuttled the DIFF scheme and commissioned a report; the report reports that a scheme like DIFF should be reinstituted. The government has not used the occasion of this budget to do anything about it. As a consequence, a number of Australian companies will miss important market opportunities, particularly in developing nations in Asia. That will not only be money lost to those companies; it will mean jobs are lost in Australia because our aid does not support development in those countries and does not support the opportunity of Australian companies to win positions in those markets.

As I have said, this measure is consequential upon the earlier measure of the cancellation of DIFF. That was a national tragedy. We do not oppose this bill, because to do so would be to badly affect the EFIC operation, but it is consequential on the earlier crime. Now that that crime has been committed, the only thing that can be done is to mop up effectively after it. We support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALKER.NAME: Senator PARER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank Senator Cook for his contribution. I am aware of your criticisms, but I think it is particularly refreshing, Senator, for those comments to be made in the way they were, compared with the farcical situation we have seen over the last two days from certain minorities in this place, which are, I believe, holding this Senate up to contempt.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator, I thought I would correct a small item in your speech. I think you said that the government had said that the DIFF scheme would be retained. I think you mean that the opposition said that, because in fact, as you are aware, it was an election commitment by this government to scrap the DIFF scheme. This honours that commitment and reflects the budget decision last year. Again, Senator Cook, thank you for your contribution.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 March, on motion by Senator Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a bill to facilitate the transfer of the responsibility of the University of Canberra from the Commonwealth to the Australian Capital Territory and it amends various other acts consequential on that. It will also allow the Maritime College to make regulations concerning traffic control—parking. We support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stott Despoja, Sen Natasha

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Carr has outlined the nature of this bill. I just point out that the proposal regarding the transfer of the responsibility of the University of Canberra to the ACT is something that was agreed to by previous governments and it is a transfer that the Australian Democrats support.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that section 50 of the bill actually enables the first principal of the Canberra College of Advanced Education to become the first Vice‐Chancellor of the University of Canberra. Obviously, that is redundant, given that they have their second vice‐chancellor, Professor Don Aitken.

BREAK.PARA: I have actually received a letter, as I am sure many colleagues have, from the vice‐chancellor, urging that this bill be passed without delay. For that reason, the Democrats are happy to support this legislation. The vice‐chancellor argues that this bill is important not only for the University of Canberra but also for the community of Canberra and the ACT as a whole.

This move will be more than a symbolic recognition of the role of the University of Canberra in the local community. It will allow the university to work more closely with their region. I do not think we can afford to underestimate the importance, especially at this period of time, of universities having the support of—and working closely with—their local communities.

A recent survey actually shows that the vast majority of Australians believe that universities are vital to our future as a nation. In light of the government's somewhat short‐sighted and misguided cuts to university operating grants, support from the community, if nothing else, is essential.

While the University of Canberra may be pleased that at long last we are passing this bill, many at the university are not so pleased about other pieces of legislation regarding higher education that have passed this place and have had a profound impact on the University of Canberra.

Currently, the University of Canberra has a target student load of 12,750 EFTSU. Had the coalition not made the cuts and downsized, as it has done, this target EFTSU load would have been increased by 140 places this year. So contrary to the claims by the minister that in fact the coalition has increased the target student loads for universities and will continue to increase them each year, a careful look at the target loads, as tabled by the department at estimates, shows that the University of Canberra plans to enrol 45 less students next year—that is an EFTSU of 12,405. Between 1996 and 1999, the total number of EFTSU that the University of Canberra plans to enrol falls by 500.

So the minister's claim that she has increased HECS‐liable student places refers only to the undergraduate load. What has been neglected in this debate by the government is the fact that the minister's insistence that universities maintain undergraduate places has not served universities or the students who had planned to undertake postgraduate loads particularly well.

Despite the cuts, the minister has forced universities to maintain their undergraduate loads but this has created a chasm in the opportunities available to students. The minister consistently talks about course work places as being MBAs, but that is not actually where the cuts are hurting most. They are hurting students with degrees who need to do postgraduate studies to give some kind of vocational focus to their general studies, for example, to be accredited for professions such as social work.

Postgraduate course work places are not expendable. They should not be shifted to the outpost of up-front fee paying places putting them out of the reach of potential students. These postgraduate course work places are not, simply as the minister would have us believe, the second bite of the cherry. They are necessary for students to their first bite of the cherry—the real cherry being a real job. There is a lack of entry level jobs and we have recognised that our future is in having a clever country. Young people know that if they want a career and they want to contribute to their society then that often entails a commitment upon them to undertake studies of a tertiary nature.

This is the commitment they are making to this nation. They are committed to creating a better society, to enter into professions that further our nation socially, economically and intellectually. Yet the Prime Minister says to young people of this nation, `You owe us.' The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has upped the ante by slugging students with vastly increased HECS fees and, of course, more postgraduate up-front fees. So the rhetoric that students and the young people of this country owe us is an insult to those who understand the real meaning of social contract and mutual obligation.

The University of Canberra understands the meaning of social contract and social justice. I note that at this stage the University of Canberra has chosen not to implement up‐front and full cost undergraduate fees and that any university who is listening to the community on this issue would be making the same decision. I congratulate the university on its restraint, on its boldness for not taking up this so‐called option of up-front full cost fees.

It is a brave move supported by the community. It is a move supported by the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats will continue to oppose, as we have done, the introduction or entrenchment of user pays education in this country. We congratulate the University of Canberra for their contribution to that fight for a publicly funded higher education system.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purposes for the amendments to the Therapeutic Goods Act are set out in the second reading speech given by Senator Campbell on 26 March. I am happy to indicate on behalf of the opposition that we support the bill. I might indicate that a couple of issues of clarification have been sought from the government, particularly in respect of the issue dealing with the recall of batches under the Therapeutic Goods Act. I understand Senator Ellison is going to make a statement in that regard. On that basis, we support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris

TALKER.NAME: Senator ELLISON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services and Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney‐General)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Forshaw for his contribution. Yes, I do have a statement here which I wish to incorporate. It deals with the recall of batches under the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989. It is an answer in response to a question put to the government by Senator Crowley. I seek leave to have that statement incorporated.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
THERAPEUTIC GOODS AMENDMENT BILL 1997
RECALL OF BATCHES UNDER THE THERAPEUTIC GOODS ACT 1989

The Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 does not provide a mechanism for the recall from the market of specific defective batches of particular therapeutic goods. There is, however, currently a mechanism provided for in the Trade Practices Act whereby a company can agree to voluntarily recall a batch of therapeutic goods which fail to meet applicable standards.

In the case of companies which refuse to voluntarily recall such products, the changes proposed will enable the secretary to require such companies to remove from the market only the batch, or those batches, of therapeutic goods that fail to meet the applicable standards under the Act.

Currently, if any therapeutic goods fail to meet applicable standards, and the company refuses to participate in a voluntary recall, the only available legislative option under the Therapeutic Goods Act is for the secretary to cancel the registration or listing of all the products from the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods and prevent any of the goods being supplied.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Did the Prime Minister inform the ERC of his decision to forgo the $450 savings rebate? Did the Prime Minister inform budget cabinet of this decision? Did he inform the joint party meeting during the budget briefing of this decision? How many of his colleagues also offered to forgo the savings rebate? Or is it a fact, Minister, that this decision was made on the run in response to public pressure arising from the fact that this measure is not means tested? Doesn't it just reinforce the chronic ad hockery that characterises decision making by your government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly would commend the savings initiative. It is really time in this country for some incentive to be provided to Australians to save more. Year after year, we have heard that one of the major challenges that this country faces is concerned with lack of national savings—inadequate public savings and inadequate personal savings. We have got a government that, for the first time in Australia's history, decides to give an incentive to Australians to save, and all that Labor can do is condemn it. Finally, a government tries to address the issue of private savings and provide some incentives and all that Labor can do is condemn it.

ANSWER.PARA: This is a good initiative. In terms of the tax benefit, a lower level taxpayer will actually get greater benefit from it, contrary to what Labor has been saying. All Australians have an opportunity to benefit from this initiative, unlike Labor's proposals, which were never delivered, despite 13 years in government. What about some thought for the retirees? They have had that consideration from the Howard government. They did not get it from the Labor government.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Will senators on my left please stop shouting. Those listening to question time are also entitled to hear.
—All that Labor intended to do was to take the savings of Australians across the board that it had collected through the taxation system and give some back to a select share of Australians.

—Madam President, I take a point of order. I asked Senator Hill a number of questions—whether the Prime Minister had informed the ERC, the budget cabinet and the party room of his decision to forgo the rebate. I also asked whether he made this decision on the run. I ask you to direct the minister to answer the question that has been asked of him.
—There is no point of order. The minister is answering the question and he may do so in his own way. It may not be to your liking and you can follow it up afterwards.

—The Prime Minister has explained his decision. He, as an individual, gets certain tax‐free benefits that no other Australian gets and he has decided to make an individual decision in relation to it. Fair enough; that is a reasonable thing for him to decide. He is entitled to do so. As to what occurs within the party room, within the cabinet, within the ERC, of course, you would not expect me to confirm that here. That is just a try‐on, Senator Faulkner, and you know that.

ANSWER.PARA: The important thing is that this is a good initiative for Australia. It will encourage private savings. That is in the national interest. It is against the background of a very progressive taxation system. Those who earn more overall pay a lot more tax, and so it should be. You have got to look at the taxation system as a whole. Some allowances are means tested and some are not. There is nothing unusual in that. When Labor brought in its child‐care cash rebate, did it provide a means test for that? No. It said that the very wealthy should take the same advantage as the poor. What hypocrisy from Labor!
This is a good initiative. It is a good start towards encouraging private savings, a good contribution towards building national savings, and ought to be applauded by all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Do you acknowledge, Minister, that anyone who earns as much as we all do does not need this rebate?

—You are a silly fellow. Don't you understand the principle of progressive taxation? You pay a lot more tax per dollar than somebody on a lower income. That is the background to this. Some allowances are means tested and some are not. When you were in government you brought in some which were means tested and some which were not. You need to look at the taxation system as a whole. This is an incentive for the lower income earners; it is an incentive for higher income earners. It is an incentive for all Australians, and that is good public policy.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. One of the key themes in both coalition government budgets has been fairness and equity. Will you please outline for the Senate some of the measures in the social security portfolio which provide assistance to those most in need?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't it a shame that the opposition is not interested in fairness and equity and important measures for Australians? They are destructive and anti anything good that is done by this government. They are negative on everything. They seem to see that as the role of an opposition. I can tell them that it will not get them into government.

ANSWER.PARA: The key themes in this year's social security budget are measures to assist carers, assistance to retired people, greater consistency and simplification, improved customer service, further compliance and targeting measures and assistance to families. One of the major initiatives in the 1997-98 budget is providing a better deal for older Australians. People who qualify for the age pension but delay their retirement and keep working will receive a tax‐free—

TALK.START.PARA: —Till they die.
—That is a bit on the level of the `silly old bugger' story. That is all you think of older people—that they are too silly to make intelligent decisions for themselves.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on my left.
—Isn't it silly? They really do not like this, do they? It is so good. It is choice for older Australians.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, if the bullies opposite would stop bellowing, then older Australians would know precisely what is involved. It is choice for them. It is an option. It is not compulsory. For up to five years before they actually take up the pension entitlement, they could work on in a job that they want to be in. If they do not want to, if they want to retire, they can. For many people, the choice of having a lump sum on retirement is very attractive. To not recognise that shows that you do not understand the needs of older people.

ANSWER.PARA: The longer that older people stay in the work force, the more work they, through spending their money, engender for others. If a single person defers their retirement for five years and qualifies for the maximum rate of pension, they will be entitled to a $21,251 tax‐free lump sum. A couple in the same situation would be entitled to a tax‐free lump sum of $35,450. That is a choice for them. Do they want to upgrade their motorcar on their retirement? Do they want to have money for repairing the spouting, if it becomes necessary, on their retirement? These are practical things that older people will value.

The simplification of payments has also been a key theme in this year's social security budget. The introduction of a parenting payment, amalgamating the sole parent pension and parenting allowance, recognises the responsibilities of all parents in caring for their children. That will also streamline claim and payment procedures.
The Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission has issued a press release saying that this initiative:

. . . is an example of recognising the need to balance equity with the efficiency that comes with greater simplicity. These measures indicate that Minister Newman has been listening to the community welfare sector with open ears.
Put that in your pipe.

One of the measures in the social security budget package of which I am most proud is the carers package. This package builds further on the government's election commitment in the national carers action plan, which was implemented in last year's budget. The Carers Association of Australia has issued a press release saying:
The budget is a clear indication that carers are a priority for this government. The Howard government has listened to carers.
Press releases along those lines came from the Council on the Ageing and also from the Catholic Social Welfare Commission. No wonder you do not want to ask questions and be interested in that.

As part of the carers package, the government has announced a 28 per cent increase in the rate of domiciliary nursing care benefit from July next year. It has also extended eligibility criteria to enable the carers of profoundly disabled children under the age of 16 to access the carers pension for the first time, and I could go on if I had the opportunity. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister care to continue to outline the initiatives for the carers package?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be delighted to. In 13 years of Labor government, no attempt was made to look after those carers of profoundly disabled children under the age of 16. So from 16 on you could get a carers payment, but some of the most demanding years of care were ignored. So that has been welcomed as well.

ANSWER.PARA: The government has also recognised the huge amount of stress that caring engenders and has increased the amount of respite care allowed for people on domiciliary nursing care benefit, carers payment or the child disability allowance to 63 days in a year, which at least gives you a Sunday off and a few days annual leave. That is more than can be said for what the previous government did.

There are some children who need to go overseas for medical treatment. Some of the children who are dying have a last wish to go to Disneyland. They were prevented by the Labor government from getting more than the minimum family payment. That has been redressed. They can be away now for up to eight weeks and get that family payment. There is much more, Madam President. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from Thailand led by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and President of the National Assembly. —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, where in the budget papers does the government identify and quantify the level of anticipated increased savings which will result from your savings rebate measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, as you know, national saving is a central feature of the budget. Can I draw your attention, Senator Sherry, to a paper Savings: Choice and Incentive —
—I have it.

—I am glad you have it. Senator, what we are seeking to establish is to address a major issue which Labor comprehensively failed to address. Under the 13 years of Labor, under those miserable 13 years, with all these failed ministers still hanging around—
—What page number?
—Not you, Senator, but the failed ministers hanging around. Under those 13 years, national savings fell to almost their lowest level on record.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Sherry, our approach to saving is twofold. First of all, it is to repair public savings. You will be aware that one of the reasons for the catastrophic fall in savings under your government was the massive deficits that the Keating government racked up. You would be aware that in the last five years some $70 billion worth of deficits were racked up by the Keating government. One of the major efforts to repair national savings has been to restore public sector balances, and that is precisely what this government has done.

Another leg to our savings plan is to encourage private savings. You will be aware of the rebate for savings, Senator Sherry, which I thought was very effectively outlined in the first question by my colleague. We have released a whole paper on national savings.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There is far too much noise on my left.

—Thank you, Madam President. The government has a policy to repair the structural problems in national savings which were dramatically left to us by the Labor Party. This is a central feature of the budget. The measures that we are proposing to undertake are outlined comprehensively in the budget papers.

—Madam President, everyone has looked through this paper. No-one can find the increase in savings as a result of the rebate. No-one in Australia can find it, Senator Kemp. Given that you claimed on Lateline that Treasury and the Taxation Office had calculated that the bulk of your savings rebate would benefit those who earn under $40,000, what will be the contribution to national savings over and above the $3.8 billion cost of your plan? Why were these figures not presented in these budget papers if this is so beneficial for national savings? When will you table these calculations in the Senate, and why are you trying to conceal these important economic figures?

—That must be one of the silliest questions I have heard, even by Senator Sherry's standard. Senator Sherry, I know there is a view around that you were demoted in the last reshuffle to shadow Assistant Treasurer, but I would never allege that. What you seem to miss is that we are providing an incentive for savings, and there is no doubt that the advantages that we are offering in this budget will certainly over time assist savings. There is no problem, Senator Sherry.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and the Minister for the Environment. Minister, as you know, Australians are vitally concerned about the state of the environment. Will you inform the Senate what measures the government has announced in the budget to help conserve and restore Australia's environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —Australians are vitally interested in the environment; there is no doubt about that. They are interested in the environment and they are interested in jobs, and they will get both from this government. This government realises that both have got to be looked at together. Basically we support the principle of sustainable development. When we get that, we realise that economic growth and jobs that will be created from it will be consistent with conserving our environment and in fact restoring the health of that environment and passing on the environment in a better state to future generations. That is a big commitment but we think it is long overdue. We did not get it from 13 years of Labor—13 years of lost opportunity. Finally there is a government in office that will face up to its national responsibility in this regard.

ANSWER.PARA: It is our intention, in fact, to provide through the Natural Heritage Trust, but out of current expenditure, some $187 million this year, which will be in addition to the ordinary current expenditure environment programs and will provide on the ground benefits approximately double that which was provided by Labor. That is good news for the Australian community which, as I said, is equally concerned with the issues of environmental health as it is with economic growth and economic gain.

In a little bit more detail let me touch upon some of the key initiatives. It is our intention this year to spend some $47 million on vegetation programs—an increase of $25 million over Labor's expenditure. We recognise that conserving native vegetation and revegetating is a vital matter in the Australian national interest.

Secondly, we are investing further funds in biodiversity, particularly in relation to world heritage areas. That was neglected by Labor. Labor thought that listening was an end in itself. We accept that there is a responsibility after listening to properly manage these assets that have great international as well as Australian environmental significance. So we will be putting $11 million into the national reserve system—an increase of $9 million. We will be putting $7 million into endangered species and $18 million into world heritage management over the $10 million of Labor in its last year of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have slashed the environment.

—You would be embarrassed by that, Senator Faulkner: our $18 million as opposed to Labor's $10 million. We will conclude such matters as the Willandra Lakes compensation package—issues that Labor was unable to conclude.

ANSWER.PARA: Furthermore, we intend to put more money into conserving our land resources, with $35 million going into the national landcare program—the largest environmental program in Australia. It is a program of cooperation, where landowners work with the community at large to produce a better outcome on the ground. We are putting $5 million into a national weed strategy, $4 million into national feral animal control, and $3 million into advanced property management. This is all good expenditure in the national interest. We are putting money into not only land resources but also our river system.

TALK.START.PARA: —There will be a 450 per cent increase in investment in the health of our river systems—something really to be applauded, even by you, Senator Bolkus. This includes $30 million towards delivery of our promise on the Murray-Darling Basin.

ANSWER.PARA: This government is a government committed to the environmental health of this nation. It is a government that does not just talk about it but is committed to action, a government that is prepared to work with the community, to help support the community, to provide a funding base in which the community can achieve the benefits and outcomes that it wants in this critically important area. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Childs, Sen Bruce

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Has the minister's attention been drawn to the response of Australia's leading savings expert, Dr Vince Fitzgerald, that the savings rebate will have a negative impact on savings? Is it a fact that any benefit to private savings will be more than offset by the scheme's $2 billion cost? Is it therefore a fact that it will simply diminish public savings without a concomitant increase in the level of private savings? Does Dr Fitzgerald also say that savings would be more substantially improved had the money been directed to compulsory superannuation? And I ask whether it is a fact that Dr Fitzgerald concludes:

QUESTION.PARA: I think there is little doubt that the cost to the budget may be greater than the net effect on private savings.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I read in the press the comments of Dr Fitzgerald and they do not surprise me because he has a vested interest in the previous scheme. He is an architect of the previous scheme. He supported the compulsory scheme. We have a different philosophical basis. We actually believe that if you support the community to save through a voluntary savings scheme you will get a better bottom line. That is the difference: Labor has compulsion; the coalition government has a voluntary scheme. We give people some incentive.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many senators interjecting.

—Give the community some help and incentive to save and you, Senator Childs, might be surprised at the outcome. That is what they have been crying out for for years: a government that recognises the shortage in national savings, not just public savings, which was your preoccupation, but private savings as well. This will contribute to the development of a new culture—a savings culture. That is what we are all about. This is a good start.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise on my left is far too high and intrusive.

—It is extraordinary that they knock a non‐compulsory scheme that simply encourages ordinary Australians to save. How could you condemn that? This scheme is long overdue. It will be taken up, I am sure. We estimate that six—
—How much are you going to save?
—Senator Sherry: cease interjecting.

—Senator, we estimate that it will be taken up by six million Australians. If that is right then there will be six million Australians who believe that we were right and Labor was wrong. Let us wait and see.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. If the scheme is so good why can't you quantify the figures in the budget papers?

—I urge the honourable senator to give it a go. Right? Incentives have been provided through the tax system for all sorts of other things; why shouldn't they also be provided for savings? Why shouldn't they be provided to encourage Australians to save and build up the national bank—not only through Labor's methods of tax and public borrowing, but through individuals being able to save? We will give them a taxation incentive to do so. There is nothing compulsory in it. They do not have to take it. It is an opportunity for ordinary Australians and if they take it up that will benefit the nation as well as benefit them individually. That has to be a worthwhile scheme. It is disappointing to see such a negative, carping attitude from the Labor Party.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. The secretary of the coalition's backbench communications committee, Mr Gary Hardgrave, is quoted in today's Sydney Morning Herald as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: The committee was more determined than ever that it has a viable role in determining media policy. We will have continuing discussion over the next weeks and months.

How does this sit with your reported push to have cabinet make a decision on cross‐media laws as early as next week? Are backbench fears that the issue will be railroaded through cabinet realistic? Can you confirm or deny a report in today's Financial Review that you are considering a grandfather clause to allow Mr Rupert Murdoch's News Ltd to retain its cluster of newspaper titles? How does this sit with your campaign commitment:
. . . our policy is fundamentally different from the Labor Party's in that we are not mogul‐specific.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot of speculation in the newspaper and I am not about to confirm any of it. The fact is that we do have established policy processes on our side of politics. They do not involve doing what Mr Keating used to do—make the odd phone call and then announce it as a matter of course. We consult with all the interested parties and that includes the backbench committee and in due course the party room. So there will be very significant input into all of these decisions, and I very much welcome that because clearly there are people who have different perspectives around Australia and they need to be taken into account.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that any changes that you make in this area are always going to be construed in a way that reflects the interest of the contributor. We saw that in the submissions that were presented and—

TALK.START.PARA: —What submissions?

—It is interesting you say that because I often hear people pretending that somehow no‐one knows what is in these submissions. If you want to know what every last word in each of these submissions is, all you have to do is call them up on the Net. They are all there. You can read them. If you want me to, I will send you a summary. They are all there. Every last word is there. I would caution you though: you will need to read the papers fairly carefully because a couple of the people who made submissions at that time have actually changed their views since then. That often happens.
—They followed your lead. You change your mind all the time.

—I presume that if they have changed their minds it is for good reasons, as they saw it. The fact is that each and every submission is pretty much predictable from the vested interests that prevail. That is not anything we need to be surprised about, nor, indeed, is the reaction that one gets from those who might fear that any change to the rules might not actually advantage them or would somehow alter the status quo in ways that might provide greater challenges.

ANSWER.PARA: At the end of the day, we have made it very clear what we regard as the fundamental principles to be espoused in this area. We are committed to having a policy that does not simply direct itself at the interests of particular proprietors but, rather, enhances the quality of media in this country. That includes not just the traditional media but also new forms of media about which I am sure many senators are already aware—not just developments on the Internet—

TALK.START.PARA: —You can see what has happened in rugby league. Convergence has been a great success in rugby league.

—You probably know a bit more about it than I do, Senator Kernot. I am still struggling when the rules are explained to me, but I am doing my best. Undoubtedly, there will be many pay television channels that will specialise in those services. Maybe one day you will get a specialist league channel in the way that we already have a specialist AFL channel. What is much more important is that in the not too distant future—
—You told us you weren't connected.

—I am still not, despite some heavy requests, I must say. The fact is that with the introduction of digital television and radio in the not too distant future we are looking at a plethora of diverse sources of information. These matters all need to be reflected in an ongoing policy that can take account of the necessity for diversity of editorial opinion and to ensure that people have access to differing views on issues of major significance.

—Minister, does `due course' mean to you some time within the next couple of weeks? Can you explain to us and to the Australian people what emergency or crisis or instability there is in the current ownership of Australian media that would justify you cutting short considered debate within your own party on this important issue? Can you also tell us who is clamouring for change in this policy area?
—If you look at those submissions—and I urge you to take some time to do that—you will find that almost of them without exception—
—Are clamouring for change?

—They all, without exception, say the cross‐media rules are obsolete, out of date and serve no useful purpose. Indeed, you will find many commentators saying that and many of my colleagues saying that. That has been our consistent position from well before the last election. So you ask yourself, `Why are they there?' I am sure that I do not need to remind you, Senator Kernot, that they were conceived in malice. They were there very deliberately on the part of Paul Keating as a means of punishing and rewarding. They do not serve the purpose that even their most ardent advocates—
—You won't do that. You won't punish or reward anyone, will you?

—Absolutely not. There are principles that ought to be applied. I have just told you that the single most important principle is to ensure that there is diversity of editorial opinion so people are able to understand all sides of important arguments. (Time expired) .

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Minister, do you stand by your statement in the Senate yesterday, referring to the views of Mr Knowles, the New South Wales housing minister, that `a cut of the order of $50 million will be pretty OK by him'? Are you aware that Mr Knowles roundly condemned your housing cuts in the New South Wales parliament yesterday, describing them as `shameful, disgraceful and treacherous'? Are you aware that he accused the Prime Minister of lying to the people of Australia in betraying a cut of $197 million as a $50 million productivity saving? Minister, how do you explain your malicious and deliberate misrepresentation of Mr Knowles's views?
—Senator Faulkner, you should withdraw those imputations.
—I withdraw, Madam President. I ask how the minister explains her outrageous misrepresentation of Mr Knowles's views.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very difficult to know what Mr Knowles's views are. Mr Knowles has a subterranean manner of conveying his views. That was the report that I gave the Senate yesterday. However, since I answered questions in the Senate yesterday, I discovered that Mr Knowles has been putting some more views on the table—some on radio and some on paper. They do not add up at all.
