If he is suggesting that he is not going to build very many more houses because of something like a 25 per cent cut out of the $50 million for the whole nation—something of that order—then he is misleading Australians.

There is no question that Mr Knowles has within his budget, if he administered it effectively and efficiently, the ability to not even notice at all the small change that he has had in his funding. The state governments were concerned that the federal government would make much more substantial cuts than this, and so were other people who were interested in housing reform. The reality is that that was the outcome of the Premiers Conference. As I said yesterday, I think it is old news.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister said that Mr Knowles expressed these so-called subterranean views to her—that is not subterranean, I would have thought. I can tell you that Mr Knowles was not the least bit reluctant to express his private views to me, and they are identical to the views that he has had consistently on the public record. Why did you deliberately mislead the Senate yesterday, or did you just put your foot in your mouth again, as you regularly do?
—Senator Faulkner, you should withdraw the implication that Senator Newman deliberately misled the Senate.

—Madam President, on a point of order: I would have thought that it is perfectly proper and parliamentary for a questioner to direct a question to a minister asking why, in their view, a minister has misled or deliberately misled the Senate. That is a question that has never been ruled out of order or as unparliamentary before. It will change the nature of question time in this chamber if you are to consistently rule that a question in that form is not in order. So I ask you to reflect on that ruling, Madam President, because I believe that it is both in order and common practice.

—Madam President, on the point of order: that was not the proposition that Senator Faulkner made. He actually made a direct accusation which was, `Why did you deliberately mislead?' Senator Faulkner, in taking the point of order, is actually seeking to mislead both you and all other senators.

—Madam President, on the point of order: there is the world of difference between suggesting that someone `misled the chamber' and that someone `deliberately misled the chamber'. The latter is a hanging offence. Madam President, as you well know, rule of debate 193(3) precludes a senator from any imputations of improper motives. That is clearly what the suggestion of `deliberately misleading' is all about. The rules of debate certainly allow a high degree of latitude. To suggest that someone has misled provides the opportunity to debate whether or not, in due course, you want to suggest that somehow it might have been deliberate. But to say that up front is clearly contravening that provision.
—`Deliberately misleading' in the way that it was used, Senator, has been ruled as unparliamentary and out of order, and it should be withdrawn. I would ask you to withdraw.
—I withdraw it, Madam President. I ask: Minister, did you mislead the Senate deliberately yesterday, or did you just put your foot in your mouth again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I did not mislead the Senate deliberately, and I do not believe I misled the Senate at all. The housing ministers over the last few months, as you can well imagine, have been particularly concerned at the prospect that there may be substantial cuts in the Commonwealth-state housing agreement funding. It has been a matter of some moment in correspondence, in telephone conversations, in face-to-face meetings between ministers and also with meetings—
—So you have correspondence from—
—Do you want the answer, or do you want to give the answer? Which is it to be? You are not a minister now. Just sit and be quiet. You are not here in terms of answering questions.

ANSWER.PARA: It was made very clear to me that there were several ministers who believed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you apologise?

—I have nothing to apologise for—and don't you dare suggest it! It was made very clear to me that the states expected savings in this budget. After the Premiers Conference, they were certain that there were—(Time expired)

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security. Could the minister give an absolute guarantee to the chamber that no family which is currently receiving the child disability allow ance will be adversely affected by the budget measures if their children are found to be requiring substantially more care and attention than other children of the same age?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it is an important question you have asked. What is going to happen is that new disability tables, it is proposed, are to be introduced in July next year. In the meantime parents applying for child disability allowance will be treated and assessed under the current regime, and those who have been on it for some time will also be medically reviewed and/or reviewed on the papers, as has been the case in the past.

ANSWER.PARA: Any child who is eligible for child disability allowance, who is receiving it as at the date of the introduction of the tables, would continue to receive that allowance for five years without medical review, although there could well be a review on the papers. But there will be no further requirement for medical reviews for those children who are eligible and who are receiving it at the date of the introduction of the tables. All new applicants will, of course, be assessed according to the tables.

If there are children, new applicants, in the future who would be ruled out of eligibility under the tables because of the level of disability, the impairment, they may well still have an eligibility for a health care card on the grounds of chronic medical condition requiring substantial medication. I hope that answers your question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am just referring to the savings. Is it better targeting in the medical sense, or are you intending to apply an income and assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

TALK.START.PARA: —It is essentially a result of what appears to have become an abuse of the system. When the previous government introduced the program, it was anticipated that it would apply to children with serious disability. Over recent times it has blown out. I think in the last few years there has been something like 11 per cent growth in the take‐up rate where the children of that age are only two per cent of the population. So the relativity between the number of successful applicants and the number of children in that age cohort have diverged quite dramatically. The savings are the estimation of it not blowing out any further. Basically, Senator, that is the answer to your question.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, in view of your strong support for the abolition of the media cross‐ownership rules which will allow Mr Packer to acquire the Fairfax newspaper group, are you aware that Mr Kroger, former state Liberal president in Victoria and his merchant bank, J T Campbell, will be paid a success fee of $7 million if the government's plan to allow Mr Packer to acquire Fairfax is successful?
—No, I was not.

—My question is also to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. Minister, have you read the schedule to Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1997-98, which states that the ABC's budget for broadcasting for the coming year is $458.7 million of which $7.7 million is for international broadcasting and $451 million is for all domestic broadcasting? Minister, did you state yesterday on ABC radio that the ABC had been allocated $500 million in this budget and, if they cannot run a broadcasting network on $500 million, there is something wrong with them—or words to that effect? If so, how do you propose to make up that extra $50 million, which you promised ABC listeners yesterday? Finally, as there is no mention in the budget of whether the ABC will now be forced to pay their own transmission costs out of their reduced budget allocation, despite your promise in the media release of 12 April last year that this would not be the case, how do you propose to make up that extra expenditure so that the ABC will have $500 million—(Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Bourne would probably learn a bit more if she read the actual budget papers rather than poring over the schedule. The most important single figure missing from that equation is the $32 million which will go to Symphony Australia, formerly—
—You said `broadcasting'.

—Look, I am sure you realise that the ABC has, for many years, maintained the orchestras. That has been part and parcel of its funding. The Mansfield recommendation proceeded on that basis; we all proceeded on that basis. Indeed, it has been quarantined and they still get their $32 million. So you cannot have it both ways. You cannot say, `It used to get it and while it was getting it guarantee $500 million, take it away but still give it $500 million.' That would be a $32 million windfall. Even the ABC does not argue that one.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that the ABC has done very well in a tough budgetary climate. If in fact we had simply given it the $500 million that I promised in my press release of 16 July last year, subject to inflation adjustments, which have been a feature of life for the ABC, then it would have got something in the order of $493 million. But, in fact, it gets in excess of $500 million—just—and it will get more than that in succeeding years. As I say, you have to include that $32 million to make any sense of the comparisons. If you want to take it out, take it out before Mansfield, take it out of the equation permanently, but do not leave it in for one purpose and not for another.

In addition to the base level of funding for domestic services, they get a $4.8 million loan deferral and $4.7 million for English language and Tok Pidgin Radio Australia programming. The ABC itself accepts responsibility for additional funding to provide foreign language services for a number of countries in the region for Radio Australia. There are revised indexation arrangements which the ABC itself estimates will save something of the order of $3.2 million in the next financial year. Any transmission costs are borne by the NTA.
The net result of that is that the ABC will be able to retain $11.2 million in Radio Australia programming savings. They will also continue to be exempt from—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dazzle us, Richard. That is not the point. You are not answering the question about broadcasting.
—Broadcasting is the point.

—I am not quite sure what you mean by saying `broadcasting' as though the ABC is not getting money for broadcasting. It is getting precisely what we promised it would get back in July last year. I am very confident that the ABC will be able to adapt to that. There will be no significant reduction—
—We saw you on television, in a tally room.
—After the election, so what are you on about? You cannot possibly claim any breach of election commitment based on something said after the election, surely.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that the ABC will be able to cope well and truly with the $55 million cut that was foreshadowed many months ago. We have already seen that there has been no significant interference with programming, and I am very confident that that will continue to be the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, orchestras do not equal broadcasting and never have. The point is that you promised $500 million for broadcasting yesterday. At the moment, there is $451 million for broadcasting. We are talking about broadcasting here, which is what you said. Where is that extra $50 million coming from?

—I suppose you can only lead a horse to water, Madam President. This is a semantic argument. The ABC was promised $500 million. Are you seriously suggesting that that was in addition to the $32 million being set aside?
—You said that yesterday on the news.

—Let's not play games. The ABC was going to get $500 million. The ABC still has responsibility for the orchestras. The ABC is getting $500 million. To the extent it uses some of those funds for commercial activities, you would say to me, `That's not broadcasting either.' To the extent it uses them for research and development, you would say, `That's not broadcasting either.' Let's not play games. The ABC was expecting to get less than the $500 million. It actually got it. We delivered on our promise. You cannot do any better than that. If you tell me that the ABC is telling you that it expected an extra $32 million, I will be absolutely amazed. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can you confirm that Charles Sturt University will have to close its Goulburn campus as a consequence of your decision to abolish 4,700 undergraduate industry places, a decision that hits regional universities the hardest? Are you aware that the New South Wales police royal commission has today recommended support for the tertiary police courses at the Goulburn campus, courses that will now not be able to go ahead because of the closure? How can you possibly claim that the loss of 1,600 industry places in regional New South Wales, 850 places in regional Victoria, 400 places in Western Australia and 150 places in Queensland are, in the words of the Prime Minister, `good for jobs, good for the regions'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Carr for the question. No, I cannot confirm that and I do not believe Charles Sturt University is in a position to confirm that at this stage either. The abolition of the CIP scheme is a pretty clear recognition from this government that what the federal government was doing was subsidising the training, as you rightly identified, of state public servants. That is a little bit of cost shifting on behalf of the New South Wales government and other governments for the state government related CIP scheme places, obviously.

ANSWER.PARA: My office has been in touch with CSU and some of the other universities that might be affected by the closure of the CIP scheme—the orderly closure of the CIP scheme; not the overnight slash and burn which is the sort of thing you would have done—and has indicated a willingness to discuss with them and assure them that we are willing to sensibly discuss a phased withdrawal of it so as to minimise the impact on those institutions that would be particularly affected, of which Charles Sturt University is one.

Until Charles Sturt have participated in those discussions and seen what we are prepared to discuss with them, I do not think they are in a position to say that they want to close Goulburn either. I do think it is about time state governments footed the bill for the training of their own public servants that they want to go to it. I think that is appropriate.

I also want to make the point that we have provided other mechanisms by which industry can participate in higher education. That is an aim that we have in common with the previous government; we simply have a different way of pursuing that path. I remind you, Senator, that the previous government, when universities over‐enrolled, took HECS from those students and put the HECS in the government's back pocket leaving the university to teach the over‐enrolled students without further money. I remind you that, next year, this government will give back the basic HECS contribution to those universities that over‐enrol. That is one mechanism. Fee‐paying places is another mechanism, and there are others.

If Charles Sturt University, knowing that we are prepared to discuss an orderly and phased withdrawal with them, are indicating that they do not want to discuss that and they simply want to close Goulburn and get out of CIP places, well and good—we will not have discussions with them. But I doubt that that is the case, Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, are you trying to advise the Senate that your department—which publishes the figures as to the impact of this particular scheme on regional universities; it published them in March this year in the higher education funding report—did not advise you of the likely consequence of the removal of this amount of money from this particular university, and that you were not aware of the Australian Vice‐Chancellors Committee press release that drew to your attention the impact on this program? Are you also trying to advise the Senate—and I ask you directly—that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development and Goulburn's representative in this parliament, Mr Sharp, did not lobby you to prevent these cuts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I do not know whether you need some disability assistance for a hearing aid, but I am not advising you of any such thing at all. Anyone who reads the transcript of what I have said will make that abundantly clear to you. Of course the figures particularly involved in the CIP scheme were available to and considered by the government, and that is precisely the reason that I have indicated to you that a number of universities have been contacted. It has been made plain to them that we are very keen to ensure an orderly and phased withdrawal from the CIP scheme so those universities can move into the other mechanisms that we have provided—unlike the previous government—in order to continue industry's increasing involvement in the university sector. That is what I have told you—nothing more, nothing less.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. I ask Senator Alston: for 13 years the Labor government promised to build a fully‐fledged national museum but, as all of Canberra knows, it failed to do so. What is the coalition government doing to implement its election commitment to finally make the national museum a reality?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted that Senator Ferris asked that very important question, Madam President, because not only was all of Canberra expecting this particular monument to be built, but all of Australia was led to believe, prior to the 1993 election, that Australia would have—
—It is not a monument, Senator.
—It will be a monument to the centenary of federation, Senator Collins. It was indeed the centrepiece of your distinctly Australian policy back in 1993.

ANSWER.PARA: It is very relevant indeed because there is an acute symbolism to this national museum. It was indeed the centrepiece of your policy. After you sneaked back into government after that election, your then Prime Minister ratted on the deal—which was symbolic of his treachery when it came to elections. He then described it as yet another mausoleum, made it perfectly plain it would be another hugely expensive building on the shores of Burley Griffin, and was not prepared to fund it in any shape or form, except subsequently, and at the last minute, to talk about breaking it up into little pieces and spreading it around Australia. I think the Aboriginal art collection was going to go to South Australia, various other parts were going to go to Old Parliament House and another section to Yarramundi. In other words, it was an absolute disgrace—it was a deliberate walking away from a very significant promise. It is the fact, of course—

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with South Australia?

—They retrieved it afterwards, Senator Schacht, because of the outcry. The fact is that Australia is the only nation in the Western world that does not have a national museum. The construction of this was first promised back in 1981—indeed it was legislated for at that time.

ANSWER.PARA: I have not yet seen Senator Lundy's press release congratulating us on this initiative but, as you would know, the latest shadow arts minister, former Senator McMullan, at least had the grace to say up‐front that he welcomed that commitment. I know that Senator Lundy is very keen to see the national museum go ahead in Canberra as well. It will be going ahead as a permanent reminder that, unless and until you come clean with the Australian electorate and walk away from the Paul Keating approach to politics, you will never get anywhere.

The fact is that this was regarded by the electorate as one of the most fundamental promises of all because all Australians recognise the great cultural sensitivity of a national museum that combines not only the environment but also Australia's social history and the best aspects of our indigenous culture. All of these will be combined on the shores of Acton Peninsular. There is $7 million in the current budget and an indicative planning figure of $133 million. The funds will come out of the to‐be‐established Federation Fund—in other words, it is all there, properly costed and ready to go.

There will be an international design competition to be announced shortly which will result in the selection of architects for the project. The $7 million will be used for the selection of the architect, for design work and for documentation so that tenders for construction can be called for early next year.

This will provide a major boost to tourism in the ACT with something of the order of 1,000 jobs over the next few years and, certainly, 200 jobs during the design stage. It is a major step forward, Madam President—probably the most significant single aspect of the centenary of federation celebrations. It is something that all Australians ought to be proud about, and it is something the Australian Labor Party should be very much ashamed about walking away from over all of those 13 years.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade. On page 2‐14 of budget paper No. 1, Treasury says:

QUESTION.PARA: Taken together, the trade forecasts imply that net exports are likely to detract modestly from GDP growth in 1997-98 . . .

Is this not a concession that export growth will be stagnant and the gap between exports and imports will continue to widen? In the face of this, why have you taken the incomprehensible decision to cancel the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference in this year's budget? Are you aware that that conference has generated $7 billion in export and investment opportunities for Australian companies in the last two years alone? Why have you made this cut, on top of a $400 million cut to trade promotion last year?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is our view that we will help Australia's trade performance by getting the economic fundamentals right: keeping interest rates down, keeping taxes down, keeping inflation down and improving infrastructure, the waterfront and labour relations—all those fundamentals. That will best help our exporters and ultimately help our current account. I think the view was that the Trade and Investment Outlook Conference had grown a little tired and there may be other and more innovative ways to help promote the interest in that regard.
—What?

—You wait patiently and you will hear those. I think it has been a good conference in the past. Certainly the view of recent times is that its best days are probably past. Just because it once was useful does not mean that you continue it forever. You think of new and better ways of doing business and that is what we will seek to do.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I am interested to hear that a $7 billion opportunity for exports and investment is regarded as a `little tired'. What are the other ways you have in mind to innovatively promote exports? Given the tremendous value that the National Trade and Investment Outlook Conference has been for Australian exports, is this not clearly a case of cutting off your nose to spite your face? Finally, what is the Treasury estimate of the number of jobs that are at risk or will be lost because of those budget cuts?

—No, it is not. Just because you once had a project that was worth while and may have served a useful purpose does not mean that it always will, and you should have responsibility to look for new and innovative ways. That is exactly what this government is doing.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Will the minister inform the Senate what budget measures were announced that reinforce the government's commitment to access and equity within education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for this question. Unlike the opposition, of course, this government is genuinely committed to expanding access to education for young Australians. Students from isolated areas, as Senator Macdonald well knows, are underrepresented in terms of participation rates at tertiary education. There fore, this government will double the value of the concession under the Austudy means test where a struggling rural family sends two or more tertiary students away to study for the second and subsequent child. This is on top of our 4,000 equity scholarships announced last year, which are already available to isolated young people to access education. This, of course, means more Austudy for hundreds of isolated and rural families. The benefit will be paid quickly. It will be paid in October and backdated to 1 July this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The other measure that will provide real assistance is the discount for partial up-front payment of HECS, removing an obvious inequity in the system inherited from the Labor Party. Until now, under Labor, somebody has had to have the full amount of HECS in order to take advantage of the 25 per cent discount. It is important to recognise that the size of that discount is very large so as to equate to the very substantial benefit people can receive from deferring their payment. So they get a benefit if they defer; they get a benefit from paying up front.

Nevertheless, under Labor the all‐or‐nothing aspect of the discount was unfair because it favoured the well off. We hear them chanting over there `helping the rich'. That is exactly what their previous discount on HECS did. The new arrangement will allow those who are less well off to take advantage of the 25 per cent discount. Those who do this will not be the wealthy. The wealthy will pay up front.

I was disappointed to see Senator Stott Despoja attacking this measure as being designed to help the rich. Clearly, the really rich are going to pay up front and we are trying to give a discount to people who cannot pay the whole lot up front. She says that it is to help the rich. The potential beneficiaries of this number over 400,000 or more students.

Senator Stott Despoja will have the opportunity to put her vote where her mouth is and vote against it if she chooses to do so. No doubt when she has to come and put her vote where her mouth is, she will think twice about it. I hope she will rethink very carefully the manner in which she throws around words like `wealthy' and `rich' when we are talking about paying for education.

As much as anyone else, Senator Stott Despoja ought to know that, simply because you went to a wealthy private school, as she did, does not mean that you or your parents are wealthy. It does not mean that, and Senator Stott Despoja knows it. Many parents scrimp and save to give their children extra advantages, and so it will be with the fee paying students next year at Australian universities. However, Senator Stott Despoja, having had the advantage of a parent who was prepared to scrimp and save to put her through a private education and to give her more, will now seek to stop, using any avenue she can, other students having that opportunity at tertiary level. This is a very selfish attitude on behalf of Senator Stott Despoja and the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a little further information for Senator Margetts, pursuant to an answer I gave recently. Unfortunately the Greens do not seem to have graced us with their presence.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Faulkner interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I can't, unfortunately, but I will be very brief. This is to do with the Giblett block in Western Australia. The AHC was represented on the Commonwealth team of officials which negotiated the draft DFA, which was the officials' DFA with Western Australian officials. As part of the Commonwealth team, the AHC was represented at meetings with WA officials and played an integral role in the development of the Commonwealth officials' position on the draft DFA for Western Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: The officials' DFA did not include the Giblett block. The reason, it seems, is that in the southern forest region, where the Giblett block is located, the area of old‐growth in National Estate places considerably exceeded the area required to meet the Commonwealth benchmark, so decisions on the inclusion of National Estate places in the deferred forest areas were made on the basis of representativeness and reserve design principles and known variation in the jarrah and karri old‐growth.

The AHC was also, however, involved in previous considerations. In fact, it was part of the AHC‐CALM regional assessment of national forest values in the southern forest region in 1992. It might have been that matter to which Senator Margetts was referring. I am not sure. The AHC—the CRA—has given advices over the years, both well before the matter that was the subject of Senator Margetts' question and subsequently, and it is the practice of the AHC to provide its section 30 advices as requested.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Bolkus asked me questions in my capacity as the Minister representing the Attorney-General. The Attorney‐General has provided me with an answer. I seek leave to have that answer incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Yesterday Senator Bolkus asked me on behalf of the Attorney-General the following questions:

My question is to the Minister representing the Attorney-General and part of the answer Senator Brown wants might be in this question. Minister, last night's budget contained an annual $24.7 million cut to the Australian Federal Police compared to Labor's last budget. Is it not true that, on Monday night at the estimates committee hearing, the AFP's Commissioner Palmer advised that, for every $1 million cut to the AFP budget, approximately 20 officers would lose their jobs? Your cuts amount to a loss of up to 500 jobs in the Australian Federal Police.

Minister, why have you also cut the Director of Prosecutions' budget by some $14.6 million over the last four years? Won't this reduce the DPP's capacity to prosecute the ever decreasing number of criminals that the AFP will be able to catch? Why has your government so dramatically cut the budgets of the AFP and the DPP, sacrificing the safety and security of Australians and their families?

Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the minister that just two days ago she was at the estimates committee where Australian Federal Police Commissioner Palmer gave evidence. Minister, wasn't it true that you were also there when the AFP gave evidence that they were in crisis and that they were facing a $7 million shortfall because of the cuts of your government in last year's budget? Minister, how can you begin to explain to the Australian public and Australian families that they will be adequately protected when your government's response to this crisis is to cut the AFP's funding even further? You were there. You must be aware of it. Try to answer this question.
The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the Honourable Senator's questions:

The Australian Federal Police as part of the Attorney's portfolio will contribute annual savings equal to 4% of running costs and a 1% efficiency dividend in 1997/98, as part of the Portfolio's contribution to the Government's fiscal targets.
Delivery of those saving will be through administrative efficiencies not the AFP's important priority operational work.

The Government has also commissioned a review of the financial practices of the AFP. The review will provide a solid foundation for future resourcing considerations and it will assist in overcoming the problems associated with financial management experienced this financial year.
Additional funding has been provided in the budget to the AFP with $0.505 million to allow it to undertake preliminary work on security for the Sydney 2000 Olympics.

And, an additional $0.944 million in 1997/98 and $0.993 million in 2000/1, will be provided to the AFP for the AFP Adjustment Scheme, a scheme supporting innovative and broader anti-corruption measures.
The Commissioner has advised the Attorney that the reductions will have no impact on community policing functions provided by the AFP in the ACT which are funded by the ACT Government.

The Attorney-General rejects completely the Opposition's claim yesterday that the necessary contribution by the AFP to the Government's ongoing task of reducing the budget deficit will impact significantly on the operational capability of the AFP.
And he reiterates his statement made yesterday, the Government and the AFP are working together to ensure that the AFP resources are effectively utilised.
Similarly, the Attorney-General rejects completely the figure produced by Senator Bolkus in relation to the Director of Public Prosecution.
The figure is incorrect.
The savings measures are in line with savings measures sustained throughout the Attorney's portfolio.

The Director of the DPP, Mr Martin QC, has advised the Attorney that he has reviewed and will continue to review the efficiency of its operations. Mr Martin will advise the Attorney if he believes those constraints are having unduly adverse effects upon the capacity of the DPP to properly discharge its function.

Finally, I note that Senator Bolkus is silent on the Government making available to the National Crime Authority over the next three financial years a significant increase in funding totalling $20.4 million.
We have done so because we believe the Authority has a capacity to successfully investigate significant taxation fraud, money laundering and major organised crime

And in doing so, the Government believes that there will be an increase in recovery by the Australian Taxation Office of $60 million in revenue and another $20 million under forfeiture provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act.
Honourable Senators will appreciate that it would be inappropriate and counterproductive if I were to outline the operational activities which will be undertaken.

This commitment by the Government to the National Crime Authority reflects the importance the Government places in the fight against organised crime and importantly, also addresses the insidious drain on Commonwealth revenue that major taxation fraud has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to standing order 74(5), I ask the Minister for Communications and the Arts for an explanation as to why an answer has not been provided to question on notice No. 518 which I asked on 25 March 1997.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator West did give me notice of her concerns yesterday and I did relay them to my office. All I can say is that there seems to be no reason why we cannot get that answer to you now so I will ensure that that is done immediately.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the explanation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill), to a question without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the savings rebate plan announced in the 1997‐98 Budget.

Let me commence my contribution by stating again that we now have more proof that the Prime Minister, Mr Howard, is the weakest Australian Prime Minister since Sir William McMahon. He has managed single‐handedly to comprehensively sink his own federal budget. Mr Howard has managed single‐handedly to expose this budget for what it is—a cash grab for the rich. Mr Howard let the cat out of the bag himself in terms of his own budget. Of course, he has only got himself to blame. He was sunk by six little words in question time in the House of Representatives yesterday—`I will not be claiming it.' What leadership from Mr Howard!

We know that the savings scheme is not in the interests of national savings. It is only in the interests of saving Mr Howard at the next election. Mr Howard's so-called battlers will have to battle on while I am afraid Mr Howard's own constituency, the traditional Liberal supporters, will be laughing all the way to the bank.

I am quite sure that Treasury advised Mr Howard against this scheme. I do not really know the view of the Treasurer, Mr Costello. I do know that Mr Costello and Mr Howard had an enormous number of disputes and disagreements through the ERC process. But what we do know is that the John Howard scheme rewards the rich who may or may not bank their tax cheque.

Mr Howard promised that this would be means tested. It looks like he got rolled by his own party. The rebate got the thumbs up from Mr Costello who said that his tax affairs are private. It got the thumbs up from Mr Black Jack Moore, Mr Katter and Senator Boswell. Those people will have their hands out at tax time. Mr Howard was caught on the run in the House of Representatives yesterday.

Look at the weak, miserable excuse that Senator Hill came up with in Senate question time today. The best defence that Senator Hill could muster for Mr Howard about this scheme that will cost $3.76 billion over three years is, `Give it a go.' Look at what the reaction has been in the community. There is a very interesting article in today's Sydney Morning Herald by Mike Seccombe entitled `Howard's hoax on the poor lets rich get richer'. He wrote:
But what about the "mob" as Howard calls them, who can't afford to salt away $60,000 at 5 per cent interest, of a pay $3,000 annual contribution to their superannuation?
Well Peter Costello, when he was asked about this a couple of times yesterday, gave the answer that the tax benefits there, even if you only had savings of $1.
By our calculations, the tax break on a $1 investment for someone in the lowest tax bracket, would come down to 0.75 cents per year .
What a joke of a line!
What a joke of a policy.

He is right. What a joke of a line. What a joke of a policy. What a joke of a Prime Minister, Mr Howard, really is. What we have seen recently from Mr Howard, who lacks leadership and who is the weakest Prime Minister in Australia's history since Sir William McMahon, is utter dereliction of his duty to the workers and their families in Newcastle. We have the Wik shemozzle from Mr Howard. We have got the spinelessness of Mr Howard in regard to Pauline Hanson. We have indecision from Mr Howard on media policy. We have the National Party in open revolt thanks to Mr Howard. We have the gormless, directionless, shapeless budget courtesy of Mr Howard. We have the grubby opportunism of Mr Howard and the double standards of Mr Howard in relation to Senator Colston. That is what Mr Howard has delivered. TALK.START.PARA: —I find that contribution amazing. TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong, wrong, wrong!
—Senator Mackay says, `Wrong, wrong, wrong!' The facts speak for themselves. Senator Mackay was not here, but if she had been here when Labor took over, she would know what the foreign debt was.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It may have been an interesting contribution from Senator Patterson, but we are taking note of an answer relating to the effect of the savings initiative rebate in the budget. One of the two central defects of this rebate is it benefits, predominantly, high income earners. We had yesterday the spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) in the House of Representatives having to declare that he was going to give back his $450. We did not hear one word from Senator Patterson about the issue we are debating here today.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have mentioned, Prime Minister Howard in question time yesterday in the House of Representatives got caught out. It was pointed out to him that, as a high income earner, he gets this $450 a year—tax free, I might say—yet a low or middle income earner earning less than $33,000 or $34,000 a year does not get the $450. They might have the potential to get $450, but what low or middle income earner has the potential if they are earning less than $35,000 a year to put $60,000 a year in non-super savings and collect a 15 per cent rebate worth $450? I say again: what low or middle income earner who earns less than $35,000 can put $60,000 into non-superannuation saving to collect a $450 a year tax free rebate?

Yet the Prime Minister can. By virtue of our very generous superannuation fund, he can collect the full rebate of $450 a year. But it gets worse. The Treasurer (Mr Costello) bungled again today in question time in the House of Representatives. When trying to bag Labor's fair initiative to contribute three per cent to workers superannuation the Treasurer asserted that our former cabinet ministers were going to receive this three per cent and a benefit of $1,252 a year. That is what the Treasurer claimed in question time today.

But it was a real own goal for the Treasurer, because Labor's three per cent contribution to superannuation was means tested; it was not to apply to anyone earning more than $46,000 a year. The Treasurer struck a real own goal; he got it wrong. The Treasurer was wrong when he said that Labor's three per cent would have applied to cabinet ministers, because they clearly earned more than $46,000 a year. Labor said that no‐one got its three per cent contribution into superannuation if they earned more than $46,000 a year.

But the Treasurer has a habit of getting it wrong time and time again. I noticed today that he said that the basic pension is $9,000 a year. It is not; it is a little over $8,300 a year. The Treasurer has to start getting his facts right.

The best example of the Treasurer getting it wrong is this fandangled rebate scheme. It is wrong for two reasons. The fact is that it does apply to high income earners, and that is grossly unfair. If it is supposed to apply to lower and middle income earners, people earning less than average weekly earnings—$35,000 a year—the big problem is that they do not have a lot of spare cash. They do not have $60,000 to put into a non‐super product to get back $450, and they do not have $3,000 in spare cash to put into superannuation to get the $450. In fact, very few lower and middle income earners will benefit substantially from this new rebate system. It is skewed in favour of higher income earners.

The other essential problem with this new rebate savings scheme—aside from the fact that it delivers only half what Labor had committed to do and half of what was in the forward estimates that Mr Costello himself had committed to do—is that it does very little for private saving. When we asked Senator Kemp today, `Where are the estimates in this document about the increase in private saving that will result from this initiative?', there is none. All Senator Kemp can point to is the increase in private saving from Labor's initiative.

But they did not put the figures in this document for one good reason: there are none. There will be very little if any increase in private saving as a result of this rebate, because it is primarily going to higher income earners and to people who are already saving. It will do very little to encourage additional new saving. The Treasurer has got it wrong. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coonan, Sen Helen

TALK.START.PARA: —Labor's attack on the budget savings initiative really is a case of people in glass houses throwing pebbles. It is interesting that today in question time Dr FitzGerald was called, in aid of Labor criticism, `Australia's leading expert on savings'. Of course, Labor had commissioned Dr FitzGerald to prepare a report on national savings in Australia and to recommend how the national savings problem could be addressed. It is interesting to look back to his report of June 1993 where he said that `The Commonwealth should seek to return its general government overall deficit to persistent surplus.'

SPEECH.PARA: What did Labor do? Following Dr FirzGerald's report, they ran up $40 billion of deficits in the next three years. No‐one seems to have mentioned that yet.

Dr FitzGerald was quoted today as saying that Mr Costello could still argue that the overall mix of policies was positive for national savings. Dr FitzGerald was also quoted as saying that voluntary savings were an attractive and necessary part of a national savings regime. So it lies ill in the mouth of those opposite to talk about equity.

Labor have opposed the biggest move by a government in recent history to improve the equity of Australia's retirement income system by their opposition to the superannuation surcharge, which of course vastly improves the equity of the super system. The bulk of the savings rebate will flow to people earning less than $40,000 per annum. In contrast, not one of these people needs to pay the super surcharge.

The opposition has been highly misleading in its comments about the benefits that battlers will get from the rebate. About one‐third of wage and salary earners earning less than $40,000 make personal super contributions at an average of around $1,300. That is, they already pass the test for getting a $195 rebate. Of course, the coalition government has given them the opportunity to get an even higher rebate if they wish to increase their contributions. Those who are not making personal super contributions certainly have a big incentive to do so. Each dollar they put in will give them back 15c. Also, six million Australians will benefit from the rebate, the vast bulk of whom are low and middle income earners.

It is nonsense to suggest that this initiative does not assist the battlers, the low income earners. For a person in the lowest tax bracket, the rebate means that that person pays just five per cent tax on their saving income up to the cap. Not only is it going to assist low income wage earners; it will also assist individuals such as self‐funded retirees who have previously had absolutely no access to this sort of savings income. Labor's scheme, of course, was limited, in that it applied only to individuals who are currently in the work force. Not only was Labor's scheme limited to those in the work force, but the coalition has ensured that other net income from savings and investments will also be eligible to attract the savings rebate. This will include items such as interest, dividend income, net rental income, net capital gains, privately funded pensions and annuities, assessable bonuses from life insurance companies and friendly societies, partnership income, trust income and attributed foreign income. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Prime Ministerial Visit to Singapore and China

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a statement on behalf of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on his overseas visit to Singapore and China, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
I would like to report to the Senate on my recent visits to Singapore and China between 26 March and 2 April.

Both visits were part of a deliberate pattern of visits I have made as prime minister to key regional countries in the Asia Pacific region. They follow my visits during 1996 to Indonesia and Japan, and my participation in the APEC leaders meeting in Manila.

The message I conveyed during my visit was that my government was committed to building Australia's engagement in the region. There can be no doubt that Australia's political and economic future is closely bound up with the future of the Asia‐Pacific region.
Our success in our economic partnership with our region will be vital to our economic prospects, and to our capacity to generate worthwhile jobs in Australia, especially for our children.

My government is committed to ensuring that Australia's economy is equipped to compete for a share of the spectacular growth in the region, that adequate frameworks are in place at a government level with our regional partners to facilitate business and other links and that Australia plays an active part as a member of the regional community in shaping its future.

I would like to extend my deep appreciation to my hosts in both Singapore and China for the warmth and generosity of the hospitality they extended to me and to my party. This was a compliment to Australia, a measure of the regard with which Australia is held in both countries and a recognition of the great benefits which flow to both sides from our relationships.

Madam President in Singapore, in meetings with President Ong, the prime minister, Goh Chok Tong, and the senior minister, Lee Kuan Yew, I reaffirmed my commitment to Australia's partnership with Singapore.

In an address to a major business lunch hosted jointly by the Singapore Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry and the Singapore Australia Business Council, I outlined the strengths that Australia brings to its economic engagement with the region and the benefits of my government's reform program in this regard.

Australia's relationship with Singapore is one of the most diverse and active we have in the region. I marked an important element in the history of that relationship in laying a wreath at the Kranji Commonwealth War Cemetery where 1,100 Australians are buried and the deaths of 1,640 others are commemorated.

Singapore is our largest trade and investment partner in ASEAN, with total bilateral trade worth $5.8 billion last year. It is one of the principal sources of visitors to Australia, and the second largest foreign investor in Australia's tourist industry. About 11,000 young Singaporeans studied in Australia last year.

We cooperate very closely with Singapore regionally and internationally. We have very similar views on the importance of APEC. The government is working closely with Singapore to consolidate APEC's role as the pre‐eminent structure for regional cooperation and to ensure that the momentum of trade and investment liberalisation is maintained within APEC. Singapore's own economic success is a testament to the benefits of liberalisation.

I expressed my appreciation to the prime minister for Singapore's strong and consistent support for Australia's membership of the Asia Europe Meeting, noting the appropriateness of Australia's participation in this body.

We have strong defence links with Singapore and Malaysia through the Five Power Defence Arrangements. The Singapore government expressed to me its appreciation for the training facilities that Australia provides for Singapore's armed forces.

Given the breadth and depth of our links it was particularly pleasing to be able to announce with the Singapore prime minister a new aviation agreement which provides for nearly a 40 per cent increase in services between Australia and Singapore, meaning about 30 extra Boeing 747 services between the two countries every week. The agreement will also result in a doubling of the number of air freight services between Australia and Singapore.
Madam President my visit to China had as a principal objective establishing a good working relationship with the Chinese leadership and suggesting new horizons for our economic partnership.
I underlined the continuity of Australia's commitment to a strong relationship with China, acknowledging the contributions made by previous governments from both sides of politics.

Reflecting the strength of the bilateral economic relationship and the priority Australia attaches to it, some of Australia's most senior business leaders participated in my delegation. I would like to thank those business leaders who accompanied me for their contribution to the visit's success. Their participation sent a very positive signal to the Chinese government about the commitment of the government and the business community to work together in strengthening the relationship with China.

Given our mutual interests and the importance to the region of cooperation between us, good communication between Australia and China is crucial. I proposed—and Premier Li Peng agreed—that we should strengthen dialogue at a political level. We agreed that we would meet regularly at head‐of‐government level. I also proposed that the ministerial framework for discussion of economic cooperation be upgraded and broadened in order to ensure our economic complementarities achieved their full potential.

In short, my government is seeking a partnership in growth with China. I am pleased that we will have the opportunity to continue our discussions on this when the Vice Premier, Zhu Rongji, visits later this month.

China is already our fifth‐largest trading partner. In the past decade, Australia's trade with China has grown twice as fast as our trade with the rest of the world. By the year 2000, China could be our third largest trading partner after Japan and the United States.

Australia will maintain its track record as a reliable supplier of mineral and agricultural commodities. China is already our largest wool market—taking about one quarter of our wool exports—and we supply about 60 per cent of its iron ore imports.

I drew the Chinese leadership's attention, however, to the much greater role that Australia could play in fuelling China's economic growth. President Jiang Zemin responded well to this. Australia can play the part in China's economic growth that we played during the rapid industrialisation of Japan and Korea. Possible areas for expansion include LNG and directly reduced iron (DRI). China agreed during my visit to send a feasibility study team to Australia to look further at the prospects for DRI.

Investment from China could play an important role in consolidating this economic partnership. I reaffirmed that Chinese investment would be most welcome. According to Chinese figures we are already the second largest destination for Chinese investment after Hong Kong. Australian investment in China is also growing fast.

The composition of the business group that travelled with me reflected the scope for this partnership to expand into new areas, including manufactures, construction and services. In particular, my visit highlighted Australia's strength in financial services.

During my visit I participated in a ceremony to mark the issuing to the ANZ Bank of a licence to operate a branch in Beijing. I opened a seminar sponsored by the Australian Stock Exchange in order to explain the benefits for Chinese companies of listing in Australia. Just before I visited, AMP received a licence to open a representative office in Beijing. I supported the applications Colonial Mutual and National Mutual have made for licences to operate in China.
I also opened Ansett's new office in Shanghai.
Madam President closer political cooperation between Australia and China is also important.

There will, of course, be differences from time to time between us, reflecting our different traditions, cultures and political systems. My government's approach to China will be based on the principles of mutual respect and recognition of our mutual interests. It is better that any differences are discussed openly and directly in a non‐confrontational way—in the context of a mutual recognition of the value of our cooperation to each other and the importance of it to the region.

I reiterated in my discussions that Australia did not regard China as a threat. China's economic growth was to be welcomed, not feared. Rather, we wanted to see China constructively involved in regional institutions and beyond. I underlined our shared interests in APEC. I promoted publicly the benefits for China itself and for the rest of us of early Chinese accession to the World Trade Organisation on reasonable terms.

Dialogue with China on regional security issues is important. President Jiang Zemin's ready response to my suggestion that our respective defence forces should have regular talks was therefore pleasing. These talks should help provide a clearer understanding of our respective outlooks and promote stability in our region.
I reaffirmed the Government's commitment to the one‐China policy. Australia will pursue its legitimate economic interests in Taiwan with due regard to the sensitivities involved.

China has agreed to regular consular talks and my government has agreed to discuss a possible consular agreement. I raised the case of James Peng, and Li Peng undertook to pass on my concerns to the relevant authorities.
Li Peng assured me that China would respect all the freedoms of Hong Kong after 30 June as laid down in the Basic Law agreed by the UK and Chinese governments.
Since my visit, China has agreed to my proposal for a human rights dialogue. We see such a dialogue as a constructive and potentially productive way of engaging China on this issue.
Madam President finally, I want to say something about the importance of the human ties that bind us with the countries of the region.

In Singapore I attended a meeting with Singapore alumni of Australian educational institutions. In Beijing I held a reception for Australian students in China and Chinese students of Australian studies. These were significant and very enjoyable parts of my programme.

The store of knowledge of Australia that these links constitute is hugely beneficial to Australia. The understanding of Australia that they generate—its qualities and values, its economic, intellectual and physical attributes—is invaluable.

Likewise, the communities within Australia who trace their origins to Singapore and China play a significant role in our relationships with these countries. These communities have made an invaluable contribution to Australia. Their success in our country and the esteem in which we hold them are important measures of the sort of society we are and the sort of relationship we want with our neighbours.
Let me take the opportunity to reiterate on behalf of all Australians that they are very welcome and highly honoured parts of our society.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is a report on the Prime Minister's visit to Singapore and China. I cannot allow the opportunity to go past without bringing up the issue of Tibet. We have in today's Sydney Morning Herald a letter from the President of the Australia Tibet Council, P. McGurk. I would like to read that to the Senate. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Heaven forbid that I upset the Chinese Government by criticising its continuing abuses of the people and the land of Tibet, but the report on the six-year prison sentence given to a senior Tibetan monk . . . prompts me to go public—
That was in the Herald on 10 May—
How is it that we Australians can value our freedoms so much, yet let our Government condone these human rights abuses by the Chinese Government of a gentle, peaceful people?

In the eight years since the military crackdowns in Tibet and Tiananmen Square, human rights groups around the world have reported that abuses by the Chinese Government have increased, yet politicians such as Mr Fischer and Mr Downer would have us believe that things have improved and, by not criticising the Chinese Government, that we can positively influence them.

By turning a blind eye, our Government believes it will be rewarded with trading dollars. Anyone who is critical risks China's financial wrath: the Chinese Government has been making these threats less and less veiled.

If this is Australia's policy, when will we ever speak up against human rights abuses? It is clear that our Government will do so only when there is little financial risk. We will condemn Burma, but not China or Indonesia—there's too much money at stake. How could we explain this policy to the more than 700 Tibetan monks and nuns who are in jails in Tibet?

That is an adequate response in itself to this prime ministerial statement. The fact is that the Prime Minister went to Beijing, but he did not adequately raise the issue of Tibet. He has now sidelined that issue into an ongoing dialogue between governments to ensure that the public demand for it here in Australia does not lead him to be embarrassed each time he meets with Chinese leaders to discuss this important issue.

I note that the fifth ranking Chinese government official is coming to this country a week or so from now. I would draw the government's attention to the need to raise with him the issue of the hundreds of people imprisoned in Tibet, the total clampdown on human rights, the failure of the Chinese authorities to allow people to even wear cultural dress on national days and the continuing apparent house arrest, at least, of the Panchen Lama, who is the world's youngest political prisoner. It is an horrific position in Tibet. It is one that we Australians cannot turn a blind eye to and must not allow trade dollars to get in the way of. The government, in particular the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Downer) need to lift their game on this because it is something the Australian people are not going to let go of.
