SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling, together with the submissions received by the committee, the transcript of evidence, minutes of proceedings and other committee documents.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to advise that the report has only just been delivered to the printer. The printer has advised that it is unlikely that the report will be available until mid next week. In the interim, limited copies of the executive summaries to the report are available on request from the committee secretariat. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

It is my pleasure to present the report of the Senate Select Committee on Uranium Mining and Milling. The committee was established just over a year ago to report to the Senate on uranium mining and milling, especially with reference to environmental protection, health and safety of employees in the industry and affected communities, and the effectiveness of the international safeguards regime, whose purpose is to ensure that uranium designated for civil purposes, especially electricity generation, is not diverted to military purposes.

It is indeed essential that Australians understand that in the past two decades uranium has been mined for export strictly on condition that it will be used only for peaceful purposes. At the outset it is essential to stress that the select committee's charter expressly concerned policies and administrative arrangements for ensuring that, if and when uranium is mined, the impact on the environment is minimised and the health and safety of employees in affected communities is properly protected. Our inquiry was not about whether uranium should be mined, either at existing or expanded levels.

The committee received more than 100 submissions and we were able to take public evidence at hearings in Canberra, Jabiru, Darwin, Perth, Cotton Creek, Roxby Downs and Adelaide from more than half of those who wrote to us. Both the submissions and the public hearings embraced a full range of community opinion on this important topic, from the mining companies themselves, government agencies responsible for administering mining policy and export of uranium, and a range of environmental, conservation and peace groups.

BREAK.PARA: The modern era of uranium mining and milling in Australia commenced in the mid‐1970s, with discovery of uranium deposits in the Kakadu and West Arnhem Land area of the Northern Territory. Some years later the rich Olympic Dam deposit was identified in South Australia, north of Port Augusta. Mining eventually commenced on the basis of a policy framework which derived from a thorough study of the implications of uranium mining by a commission led by Mr Justice Fox. The Fox inquiry's fundamental finding was that:
The hazards of mining and milling uranium, if those activities are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to develop Australian uranium mines.

Our report is above all a confirmation of the continuing validity of that proposition. For two decades it has formed the foundation of a regime of uranium mining and milling which has had only a minimal impact on the environment and which has ensured a strict health and safety regime. Time does not allow me to canvass the full range of evidence which overwhelmingly supports these propositions. The following comment from the Supervising Scientist for the Alligator Rivers Region is indicative:
The co‐existence of a uranium mine with a major national park for over 16 years, with no adverse impacts on the ecological integrity of the park, has to be considered a notable achievement.

South Australia's Olympic Dam mine is an example of the high level of responsibility which modern mining companies take towards health and safety. Dr Keith Lokan, Director of the Australian Radiation Laboratory, informed the committee that he had:

. . . considerable respect for the quality of the Olympic Dam operations in the way in which they have managed radiation safety over the years. They are quite dedicated. They take it seriously. It is not something that they go through because they have to. They genuinely believe in it and do it quite well.

The level of accomplishment is high—very high—but it is not without blemish. Readers of the committee's report will indeed be able to peruse the detailed list of incidents at Nabarlek and Ranger, reported over the years by the Supervising Scientist. Everything is documented, because this was a serious committee systematically examining the whole picture, not just parts which suited our personal predilections. It is only when the whole picture is examined that readers will appreciate just how good is the record. Of Ranger, the Supervising Scientist told the committee of his opinion that:
. . . there are no lasting environmental impacts as a consequence of the operation of the mine that can be detected away from the mining lease.
Even a critic of the mine told the committee that:
Ranger . . . is certainly run safer than most mines.

There were 15 reported incidents at Nabarlek over a decade's activity. The Supervising Scientist's view is that none—I repeat, none—are expected to have any lasting effect on the environment. The committee believes that this record is a matter of good management rather than luck. Our view is that it is a deliberate consequence of the constructive, purposeful, research based public policy whose development had its genesis in the Fox inquiry and which has been diligently fostered over two decades by such institutions as the Supervising Scientist, the Australian Radiation Laboratory, and, in the international field, by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Australian Safeguards Office.

It also owes a great deal to the responsibility of the mine proprietors, managers and their staffs. They recognised what uranium mining involves for themselves as well as for other Australians. The committee's report stands as the vindication of the Fox philosophy and our recommendations are about endorsing it and modernising it for the next two decades. Current achievement represents the minimum standard which we would expect any new mine which is allowed to open to meet.

Concern similar to that shown for protection and study of the environment should be given to the impact of mining on affected communities, and this will often mean Aboriginal communities. We support the concept of social impact statements to complement environmental impact studies. We have some proposals to ensure health and safety matters retain their high priority. We want to see Australia maintain its record in the application of, and support for, strict safeguards, both national and international.

Among the overwhelming majority of senators in the committee who have endorsed this report, that is, Liberal, National and Labor, there is only one area of disagreement. Labor senators, with the support of those in the minority on the overall report, that is, the Green and Democrat senators, have endorsed a larger Commonwealth role manifested in a proposed new Commonwealth Uranium Authority. Its advocates, no doubt, will pursue that in due course. Government senators Alan Ferguson and Sandy Macdonald and I have serious reservations about this proposal, though we readily recognise the good intentions behind it. Our view frankly is that the present arrangement has provided rigorous and robust administration. There is no need for new bureaucratic creations.
The second finding of the Fox inquiry was that:

. . . the hazards involved in the ordinary operations of nuclear power reactors, if those operations are properly regulated and controlled, are not such as to justify a decision not to mine and sell Australian uranium.

I understand that there is a minority report being tabled by Senators Margetts and Lees. That dissent claims to be based on the evidence presented to the committee. This is deception No. 1. The committee's report provides a comprehensive survey of the evidence. The dissenting report is a model in selective, contentious beat‐ups of the evidence. Indeed, it is hard to know how Senator Lees could claim to have any real knowledge of the evidence, having missed most phases of the committee's inquiry. She has joined with Senator Margetts in taking this grandstanding opportunity. If Senator Lees and Senator Margetts were, indeed, interested in health and safety matters once uranium leaves Australia, they should have raised it at meetings—in the event that they were there. I say again, the interest of these two senators is merely a grandstand interest; it is not a genuine interest.

A clear survey of the evidence presented to this committee does not support the minority report which they are tabling. They make much of the incidents at Ranger, but these are all set out in the committee's majority report and there is nothing new in the dissenting report. Significantly, the minority report has ignored the Supervising Scientist's view on these incidents. Again, these are set out in detail in the committee's report where the public can find out all about those; indeed they can find out the full story with regard to uranium mining, not the half of it which is told in the minority report.

Again, the minority report complains about the downgrading of the Supervising Scientist. But it does not show that the office has in fact been downgraded in its analysis. Of course its authors have not been honest because they are complaining about something that happened way back in 1993—again, an indication of the superficiality in that minority report. It mirrors what we have seen from the critics of uranium exports who try to claim that the tragedy of Chernobyl and the Three Mile Island incident call the findings of this report into question. Let me be quite clear about this: they certainly do not. No lives were lost at Three Mile Island. Chernobyl, in fact, underlines the meaning of the Fox recommendation. It was a run‐down, neglected reactor—which demonstrates the importance of strict supervision and proper maintenance of plant, which Chernobyl did not have. It was not a properly maintained reactor.

The contributions of the uranium mining doubters to this inquiry were decidedly lame. Their information is old and their thinking is stale. They work from preconceived opinion, through emotion, to arrive at prejudice. Their test of information and research is not its rigour but whether or not it harmonises with whatever fits their campaign of the moment. The Australian Conservation Foundation, for example, completely ignored Roxby Downs with regard to health and safety of employees, and their appraisal of Ranger ran out in 1986.
I want to express my thanks to the committee secretariat for their hard work in the preparation of this report and, indeed, my thanks to the members of the committee. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Those just listening to Senator Chapman will have a pretty clear idea of just what kind of respect was given to anybody involved in this inquiry who had a different opinion from that of the government, the coalition, and, it appears, the Labor Party—those who had a different opinion on the environmental aspects, health and safety, Aboriginal community concerns and the ethics of the international sale of uranium which could go into weapons of mass destruction.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have as a result of that attitude towards anybody with a differing opinion is a report which I think brings disgrace to the Senate. It does this because of the way people treated it in the process. It does this because of the way members of the committee and members of the community were treated, because of the way the views of scientists were treated and because of the way many, perhaps the majority of, people in Australia who want to see governments taking responsibility for the environment and issues such as nuclear waste were treated.

What is so sad about this process is that, on most occasions after spending a year in the reporting process, I would be standing and saying what a wonderful support base the secretariat has been in sorting out and treating fairly the people who have come to this process. This has not happened. I invite people to read for themselves—read whether it is just emotion, read whether it is lies, read whether there is some basis to what has been said by people who happen to have a differing opinion to those who want to make money and profits out of selling weapons of mass destruction, of destroying the lives of the people who work in the industry and the health of those people who live in and around uranium mines.

The Fox inquiry has been talked about. The Fox inquiry said, `Despite all these concerns, we believe the issues are such that we should go ahead and continue with uranium mining.' There are people from the Fox inquiry who have been forced to work because of different health standards which now would not be allowed. We are saying that the standards of the Fox inquiry which were specific to the Alligator Rivers region are okay for today. Well, they are not.

The chair said that it was a serious committee. It was seriously geared towards a specific outcome. The chair said that the committee's role was not to judge whether uranium mining should go ahead. But everything you will read in this disgraceful document will lead you to the impression that uranium mining is safe, that uranium mining is properly controlled, that uranium mining is not likely to have risks of being involved in unethical development of nuclear weapons, and that as a society we can close our eyes to those issues because they are not important, not relevant or not true.

Let us look at radioactive waste. Five decades have passed since the start of the nuclear age, and no solution has yet been found to nuclear waste. Every country which is involved in the nuclear industry is faced with a growing problem of what to do with it. Let us look at nuclear proliferation. Nuclear energy problems contribute to proliferation because they provide countries with the trained personnel, technical knowledge, equipment and raw materials to develop nuclear weapons.

International safeguards do not work because the International Atomic Energy Agency is underfunded. It has a conflict of interest in that it is also promoting nuclear technology. The safeguards do not cover the nuclear powers adequately, and the facilities can be used for both the weapons and energy cycles. The nuclear proliferation treaty is voluntary. Anyone can leave the NPT after giving three months notice.

The Australian public has been given to understand by successive governments that Australian uranium can only be used for peaceful purpose. Even the Safeguards Office has admitted that it does not know whether uranium mined in Australia was used in the last French tests. We were given the role of judging environmental performance. This report does not do that. It looks at what exists in terms of legislation, it looks at the processes companies are supposed to go through, and then it says, `That equals good environmental performance.' We have not done that.

As has been mentioned, there have been repeated incidents and accidents at Ranger. There has been a massive leak from the tailings dam at Olympic Dam. There has been a cost in properly cleaning up the older mines. We have a situation where the engineering standards for Ranger would not be accepted in any new mine. Even mine sites which may have been reasonably well rehabilitated, such as Nabarlek, will still need thousands of years of monitoring at public expense, if it happens.

We will have long-term damage to the delicate ecosystems at Kakadu, Mount Springs and the Rudall River National Park if that should go ahead. Jabiluka is a particular problem. You would think a responsible committee would indicate that there were so many problems that it is considered dangerous to be mined given the available technology. We are pushing to the limits and beyond what is considered to be an acceptable limit—which is not a safe limit because even health authorities indicate there is no such thing as a safe limit; only a limit over which they say people should not work.

Aboriginal communities have made it clear that the Ranger mine was forced on them. They never wanted it, and their lands were desecrated by it. Their senior traditional owner at Jabiluka has clearly indicated that she does not want a new mine to go ahead.

Realising that the government is hell bent on this particular direction, and realising as well that Labor are prepared to go along with this atrocious report, we have however made some recommendations. This would appear to indicate that the next Labor conference will be an interesting one at which to observe what happens to the three‐mine policy.

Senator Lees and I have made some recommendations that seek to: protect the right of Aboriginal communities to say no to uranium mining; address a wide range of concerns within Aboriginal communities about uranium mining; strengthen the Office of the Supervising Scientist and expand its role to cover all uranium mines; protect the environment; have worker dose limits reviewed in the light of the concerns brought to the attention of the committee—but conveniently forgotten; protect workers from attempts to subvert the Australian dose limits by introducing flexibility and exploring lifetime dose limits—that is, trying to share the risk amongst even more people; and to protect public health through longitudinal studies of the effects of low dose radiation. We have asked also for the strengthening of Australia's inadequate safeguards regime and for the promotion of sustainable energy.

We have serious doubts, in fact, about the setting up of a Commonwealth uranium authority. However, if it were to be set up properly, it might be something other than a toothless tiger. It is very sad for me to be in this situation of having to say that such a process was, in my opinion, a very sad thing for the Senate to be involved with.

TALK.START.PARA: —You set the terms of reference.
—Of course I set the terms of reference. However, I had no idea that such a process would occur in this way. In the end, those reading this report will judge for themselves. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments concerning the select committee report on uranium mining and milling in Australia. The report is the product of fairly intensive work by committee and the secretariat alike. The committee visited South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory for inspections of current mines and proposed mine sites. It received extensive and detailed evidence from a range of interested groups. Those groups included labour unions, green and conservation organisations, relevant companies, Commonwealth and state departments and, indeed, many community groups and individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party senators—indeed, most members of the committee—were acutely aware of the decision of the current government to ditch the three-mine policy of the previous government and, subject to relevant legislation, permit expansion of the uranium mining industry in Australia. Labor Party senators were also aware that this position was broadly in conformity with the policy of the Liberal Party prior to the last election. Labor Party senators—indeed, I think all committee members—realised that the terms of reference did not extend to making a decision as to whether the industry should contract or expand. The committee determined at the outset that:
This report is not about whether uranium should be mined and milled in Australia, either at existing or expanded levels.
That being the case, the committee really had little choice but to take note of the express intent of the government and pursue its deliberations accordingly.

If there is a consistent theme to this report, it is one of concern—concern about minimising the impact of mining on the environment; concern about ensuring that the health and safety of employees in the industry are protected; concern about the rights of adjacent communities; concern about establishing a mechanism to foster constructive relationships between mining companies and Aboriginal communities; concern about maintaining and enhancing international and Australian safeguards to ensure that Australia's mined uranium is only used for civil purposes in countries which are signatories to the nuclear non‐proliferation treaty.

Concern of itself is, of course, worthless. That is why the committee has recommended a new and enhanced regulatory framework to oversee the uranium industry in Australia. That regulatory structure advocates a three-tier approach.

Firstly, there is the expansion of the Office of the Supervising Scientist as the independent research arm of the Commonwealth in this industry. The OSS has carried out high quality research in the Alligator Rivers area of the Northern Territory over many years. It is highly regarded by both corporate interests and green and conservation groups, as evidenced by the fact that both sides of the debate constantly quoted findings and research of the OSS.

BREAK.PARA: The second tier of the committee's approach is the creation of a highly focused, strategically orientated entity to be known as the Commonwealth uranium authority. The CUA would maintain Commonwealth involvement in this critical industry and have coverage of uranium mining and milling in all states and territories. Its primary role would be to grant approvals to mine; to direct environmental impact statements; to supervise plans and programs to ensure that the impact of mines on the environment is minimised; to conduct triennial audits of environmental performance at mines; and to review, audit and evaluate health and safety measures at mines and other locations.

It is disappointing that government senators did not support this agency. And I suggest strong public interest and concern about all aspects of the uranium industry warrant ongoing Commonwealth regulation of this industry. There is no doubt in my mind that the high standards established and maintained by the ERA in the Northern Territory and also at Narbalek are assisted by the presence of the OSS and the strict regulatory role that the Commonwealth has established in that part of Australia.

The third and final leg of our approach is a recommendation for the creation of local committees at each mine site in Australia. This particular recommendation is a direct response from local communities, both Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal, for a direct say in matters that impact upon their lives. Whilst uranium mining might bring export dollars, earnings to shareholders and some development opportunities, it cannot be at the expense of local communities. Local communities have a legitimate interest in the environmental issues of uranium mining as they impact on both individuals and the broader physical environment.

This three-tier approach really establishes new oversight standards. The government in the past 14 months has retained ALP established controls and safeguards. They were acceptable minimums in the last 10 years. New work practices and new technologies are changing the nature of this industry. Public concern still exists about potential hazards.

This report recommends new oversight standards for the uranium industry and is a fine example of proactive public policy receptive to change but ensuring safety. A recurring feature of many submissions was the occupational health and safety of the work force. The committee has listened closely to those submissions and recommends a raft of major changes to guarantee a healthy and safe workplace.

In particular, it is critical that uniform measurement standards for data collection be established in the development of a national radiation dose register. Other recommenda tions go to research for appropriate career dose limits, a uniform method of measuring, calculating and recording dose limits and a full briefing of radiation and radiation hazards for all employees. This should be done regularly and in plain English. In this context, it is worthwhile to highlight a finding of the committee which was critical of the long, drawn out delay in the adoption of the latest international standards concerning radiation exposure. Seven years for development and implementation of standards is much too long.

The Senate committee was greatly assisted by the secretariat in its deliberations. It commissioned and received a number of research papers on international safeguards, worker health and safety, and the impact of uranium mining on Aboriginal communities. All papers were of a high quality. They were objective, accurately analysed all evidence and made cogent recommendations which greatly assisted the committee in its deliberations.

In particular, the paper by Dr Leigh on worker health and safety and the paper by Ms Irene Wilson from the Defence department were very helpful in guiding the committee in giving form to its recommendations. I wish to thank Mr John Nethercote, the secretary of the committee, for his assistance in planning and organising the work of the committee. He kept committee members up to date with correspondence reports and assisted in the deliberation process. His role was critical in the function of the committee, which addressed a delicate and divisive issue. I also wish to acknowledge the role of government senators—Senator Chapman, Senator Macdonald and Senator Ferguson—who indicated a willingness to negotiate around key issues.

In conclusion, the committee acknowledges that, while the past may have been okay, public interest demands a higher standard in the future. The possible expansion of the uranium industry is of concern to many. That expansion needs strong Commonwealth supervision and the three-tier approach suggested by the ALP to enable the creation of new oversight standards. This is the most critical aspect of the report. I commend it to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very little time to make a contribution to this committee report and the minority report. In the brief time that I have available, I would like to say something about Senator Margetts's contribution. Senator Margetts starts from the premise that to leave uranium in the ground is the only place for it—there is simply no room for discussion. To Senator Margetts, the Senate committee's deliberations were a waste of time.

SPEECH.PARA: In the brief time available to me I wish to make the point about the very low standard of submissions of the environmental groups that opposed the uranium industry in Australia. These groups make conclusions with no evidence—real or imagined—to support their views. They do not acknowledge the strict supervision of the whole nuclear industry, the unique level of the resource in Australia, the financial returns which allow for tight regulation—Ranger is probably the most highly and tightly regulated mine in the world—the advantages of the balance of trade from the development of the uranium industry, the safeguards that apply and, importantly, the contribution that nuclear energy has in addressing the greenhouse problem.

My advice to Senator Margetts and her supporters is to do some up-to-date research before hitting the campaign trail. She should try to develop arguments rather than using the tired, embarrassing, unfulfilled cliches of the 1960s and 1970s. I do not mean to offend Senator Margetts, but she is, unfortunately, typical of somebody who works from emotion and then seeks the evidence to support her opinion.

Time prevents me from telling a story or two of Senator Margetts's involvement in the committee work, but I cannot let the opportunity pass without mentioning a visit to Cotton Creek, which—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to speak for only three minutes, which is the time Senator Sandy Macdonald had, and that leaves another three minutes for Senator Ferguson.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some regret that I stand and speak today. I found the process on this committee the most stressful and the most difficult of any of the committees I have sat on in the last seven years. The process really was the worst that I have encountered, and I hope I never encounter anything like this again. I must, therefore, thank sincerely Mr Frank Nugent for his integrity, cooperation and supportive approach in helping us to go back through the evidence to try to balance the majority report.

BREAK.PARA: The majority report was finally signed off at only 3.15 p.m., so I have not read it. But the first draft, as I read through it, may as well have been written by the mining companies. I congratulate those senators opposite who managed to drag it back to what I saw, which was the draft before the last draft. There had certainly been some improvement.

For those government senators who suggest that our position is somehow extreme, I will, in my very brief time, read a couple of our recommendations. It is quite obvious, when you go through the evidence, that there is a negative impact on many Aboriginal people. Our recommendation No. 6 says:

At the time of the approval of any new mining operation, or the expansion of any existing mine, Commonwealth, State and Territory Governments should give a clear undertaking that the provision of government services to Aboriginal communities will not be reduced because of the payment of royalty equivalent or similar payments to those communities.

One of the areas that really concerned me, when I got that first draft of the majority report, related to the lack of safety precautions for workers. At Olympic Dam we met with some of those young workers, some of whom were only in their twenties and thirties, and, from what I have read of overseas experiences, I have genuine concern for those people in the industry. We have recommended:

As an interim measure Australia should adopt the dose limits accepted in the United Kingdom and refuse to approve new projects where workers might be expected to be exposed on a regular basis to the maximum dose.
How is that so extreme? We have looked at overseas evidence, and we have also recommended that:
Independent assessment of worker dose levels, including the use of urine and blood tests, should be mandatory on current and future uranium mining projects.
How is that so extreme? To make sure that workers understand the risks that they are exposed to, in recommendation No. 6 we say:
Individual workers should be given ready access to the information on their exposure levels contained in the national register.
What is so strange about that?

TALK.START.PARA: —It's in our report.
—I am very pleased to hear that that has actually crept into your report; it certainly was not there in the first place. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate notes the total failure of the Coalition Government's savings rebate plan, which only serves to:
(a) lower the level of national savings, which is not in the interests of Australian workers or Australian industry;
(b) decrease Australian workers' final superannuation retirement benefits so that they will not have a decent level of retirement income; and
(c) ensure that the savings rebate will be of maximum advantage to high wealth, high income individuals, who will be the only people able to take full advantage of the maximum $450 rebate.

The motion I have moved and which the Senate is considering this afternoon relates to the government's announcement in the budget of the so-called savings choice and initiative package. We have expressed three concerns in the motion that I move in the Senate today. The first goes to what we believe will be a lower level of national savings that will result from this particular package. The second is the decrease in Australian workers' final superannuation retirement benefits that will result. The third is the inequity of the so-called rebate proposal which in reality confers greatest advantage on higher income earners and makes it particularly difficult for lower and middle income earners to take advantage of.

It is all very well to offer choice. Four out of 10 workers in this country, who earn less than $35,000 a year, have a choice, but how many of those workers have a spare $60,000, when you earn less than $35,000, to put into a non-superannuation savings vehicle and receive back this magnificent $450 rebate? Very few workers, I suggest, are in that position.

Before I go onto the three issues I have outlined, I reiterate for the Senate that yesterday we had the spectacle of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) on the run, recognising the inequities of this $450 tax-free rebate, which he and everyone in this parliament would receive as a consequence of what is a very generous superannuation fund that we enjoy. The Prime Minister recognised the inequities of his own scheme and said, `I won't collect it.' If that is true, why didn't he say that in the cabinet room when this rebate system was being constructed? Why didn't he realise that it was fundamentally and in practical outcomes going to advantage higher income earners?

The Treasurer (Mr Costello) today made it even worse by attempting to throw back at Labor that our alternative, which he promised and committed himself to, of a three per cent government co-contribution would have meant an extra $1,250 a year for what was then our front bench. That was Mr Costello's allegation in question time today. But Mr Costello got it wrong.

The Treasurer does not understand much about superannuation. He is certainly too arrogant to listen to the broader community about the concepts of superannuation. But Mr Costello got it plain wrong when he claimed that our particular approach would have delivered three per cent, effectively, to higher income earners. Unlike the rebate system announced in the budget, ours was means tested. Our three per cent government contribution into superannuation did not apply to people earning more than $46,000.

So the Treasurer was just plain wrong in question time today. He scored a real own goal. In the process of getting his facts wrong and misleading the House of Representatives, deliberately or otherwise, he alleged that our frontbenchers could have received a benefit when they could not have received a benefit. All he did was provide the contrast between our approach and this new government's approach. Our approach was to direct the maximum benefit to lower and middle income earners to provide for their retirement. His approach is to direct the maximum benefit to higher income earners with no means testing.

What was Labor proposing? Labor proposed a three per cent government contribution. It was not just a Labor proposal. Mr Costello, in a speech just prior to the last election, said that he was accepting that. He was establish ing a bipartisan position on superannuation. During the election campaign, this three per cent contribution commitment was contained in the government's election promises. In last year's budget, Mr Costello put the estimated cost of this three per cent government co-contribution into the forward estimates. Mr Costello can rail all he likes about Labor's approach—and rail incorrectly and be factually incorrect—but on no less than three occasions he said that he would adopt that approach, and he has failed to deliver.

Labor's approach would have delivered by 2001 a level of contributions equivalent to 15 per cent for all Australian workers earning up to $46,000 a year. That is about, I think, 85 per cent of Australian workers. That was Labor's approach. That would have delivered at age 65, if it was converted into an annuity or a pension, a significantly greater annuity or pension than the current age pension, which is just over $8,300 a year, for the vast majority of people in this country.

In relation to the age pension, the Treasurer got it wrong again when at the Financial Review's function on the review of the budget he claimed that the single age pension was $9,000 a year. He should start getting his facts right in respect of superannuation, drop the arrogant pretence and the blustering that he goes on with in respect of this issue and start listening to a broader range of opinion concerning people who understand these issues.

This proposal is fundamentally unfair. I will illustrate some of the unfairness. How is a worker earning less than $35,000 going to get $60,000 to be entitled to the $450 rebate? How are they going to get $3,000 in superannuation contributions to receive the $450 rebate? Four out of 10 lower and middle income earners in this country do not save anything at all. That is a bad thing. The outcome of this policy will be a very little increase in savings from these people. They are more concerned about the day‐to‐day struggles with life. That is why Labor said the government should contribute its fair share of three per cent. On the way through Mr Costello has pocketed half the money. At least part of that money has gone off for this $1 billion centenary fund.

What are the priorities of this government? Should this government be delivering a decent, fair and improved retirement incomes policy for this country or should it be delivering $1 billion into a centenary fund or should it be delivering the more substantial benefits of this rebate system to higher income earners and not lower and middle income earners?

There is one other area I want to deal with and that concerns savings. There is one issue that we can all agree on. Private saving in this country is too low. I am not going to be as politically partisan to say that it is the Liberal government's fault. Because it is not and nor is it the previous Labor government's fault. Private saving in this country has been in steady decline for the last 20 years. Unfortunately, we share that common problem with every other advanced economy in the world, including Japan.

We share another very serious common problem. We have a rapidly ageing population. The budget papers mention this. They highlight the fact that just over one in 10 people in Australia are over the age of 65 at the moment. Within 45 years, one‐quarter of Australia's population is going to be over the age of 65. Again a common problem around the world is a decreasing work force supporting an increasing ageing population. How do you solve that problem? Do you create some sort of incentive package and on a wish and a hope give it a go as Senator Hill said today—`Give it a go. Let's see if it works.' We know this sort of incentive package has been tried and has largely failed around the world.

You need a decent level of compulsory—and people do not like the word `compulsory', but that is what funds the pension system at the moment, a compulsory tax—saving to fund the pension and retirement income. Effectively, we do that through the current pension system. A proportion of tax revenue funds the minimum pension. But do we want a pension of $8,300 a year? I would argue that most Australians want more. But we are going to struggle in the next 40 to 50 years to maintain that $8,300 a year.

In the next three years, the extra cost of pensions in the budget will be about $600 million, and it will go up. Labor's vision was to ensure that we have an intersection between a basic pension as well as superannuation income for workers' retirement. The earlier you start to approach the problem, the earlier you will solve the problem. The longer you leave it, the harder it becomes to save sufficiently for retirement incomes.

To briefly digress, Mr Costello has been fond of saying in the last few days, `These are fantastic incentives. This has never been done before.' It has. I will reflect on history very briefly. In 1949, just prior to the Labor government's defeat, the Labor government had established a national pension fund. What did the then Prime Minister, Mr Menzies, do? He scrapped that on coming into office. In its place he substituted an incentive scheme—a superannuation incentive scheme which said that you were effectively taxed at less than five per cent if you put money into superannuation. A great incentive. Not much different in its approach from what was in the Treasurer's contribution to savings in the budget. A massive incentive to private saving was introduced by Mr Menzies.

What happened? About four tenths of the population, less than half, took advantage of those massive incentives. Mr Costello rails against these so-called incentives for superannuation when it was Mr Menzies who introduced them. When Labor came into office in 1983 it said, `This is fundamentally unfair. Less than half the work force have superannuation. We have an ageing population.' Labor introduced the current pension—that is, 25 per cent of male average weekly earnings; $8,300 a year. Labor said, `We have a long-term problem. We have to address this problem. We have to apply some 20‐ or 30‐year vision to this serious problem.'

Labor's approach was that everyone gets superannuation. We increased the tax rate on superannuation to 30c in the dollar, so it is much fairer and more equitable, and introduced the superannuation guarantee of nine per cent. That is our record. We should go the next step. No-one will disagree that you need 15 per cent to provide a decent retirement income. We can disagree with the government about how you get there and the process but no-one will disagree about the level of contributions you need to provide that decent retirement income with an ageing population matched against increasing pressures on the budget to match and support the existing aged pension.

The reality is that these incentives do not work. If we get the equivalent of 15 per cent contributions into saving—whether it is superannuation or whatever—as a result of this measure, I will resign my position in the Senate. We know we will not get 15 per cent savings by every Australian as a consequence of this rebate measure.
Let me go to private saving. The budget statement is fascinating because it does talk about private saving and about the problem, but it then goes on to say:
. . . gross private saving remains relatively low at around 15 per cent of GDP compared with an average 16 per cent in the 1960s and 18 per cent of GDP in the 1970s.

They do not predict there will be any increase in private saving as a result of this initiative. The other budget papers raise a question mark about any increase in private saving at all. It is fascinating.
The Treasurer, amazingly honest for once, acknowledges the increase in saving as a result of our policy—our superannuation guarantee. It says:

. . . legislated prescribed schedule of SG contribution rates, are estimated to have a positive impact on national savings of 1.5 per cent of GDP in 2001-2002 rising to 3.6 per cent of GDP in 2019-2020.

The Treasurer admits how positive our approach has been in respect of compulsory saving in superannuation. If he accepts the logic of the nine per cent superannuation guarantee increasing private saving, he has to accept the logic that a three per cent government contribution for workers earning up to $46,000 a year, particularly for low and middle income earners, would have delivered an even more positive approach and better outcome on national private saving.

Why is saving so important for this country? As I referred to earlier, we face a common problem with every other advanced OECD country—that is, our saving levels are declining, particularly private saving. That is happening all around the world in every major advanced country. I suspect it is due to more than simply the various economic booms and busts we seem to go through. It is certainly related to economic growth, but I suspect a very deep cultural change has occurred in Australia. I contrast my and my son's attitude to saving with that of my father. My father went through wartime and the Depression. He had an absolute obsession with not going into debt. I suspect that has got a lot to do with the problem that Australia and other Western nations face.

Labor's approach was to try to address this problem, and it was succeeding. Saving is important because, if you want economic growth, investment and jobs, you have to have saving. No-one will disagree with that. If you want to buy back the farm, you have to improve Australians' level of saving; otherwise you have to import the capital. If you want to buy back the farm, you have to increase saving.

On three major counts this approach of the government and Mr Costello fails. It will fail to produce any sort of significant increase in retirement incomes for Australian workers, particularly low and middle income earners. It is inequitable. It will not increase our current low level of private national saving.

The related issue is, as the Prime Minister has discovered, it favours the wealthy. How many Australian workers can contribute $60,000 to non-superannuation? How many can contribute $3,000 to collect the $450 non-means tested rebate? Labor's approach will be that this particular rebate should not apply to high income earners. It only applies to us as politicians by virtue of our very generous superannuation fund. Is it moral for anyone in this place to accept that $450 rebate in those circumstances?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not often agree with Senator Sherry, but I have to agree with him when he said, `If you want economic growth, you have to improve saving.' It is a bit of the case of do as I say, not do as I do, because the Labor Party when it was in government did not save as a government. How could it ever expect individuals to save if the example it was setting was racking up foreign debt of approximately $10 billion or more a year? Senator Sherry has the gall to come in here and say, `If you want economic growth and if you want to be able to buy back the farm, you have to improve saving.' I think I will remind him of that over and over again.

SPEECH.PARA: The need to save is not only the need for individuals to save but the need for government to save. When Labor was in power—and I said this earlier this afternoon—it spent and it spent like there was no tomorrow, and Senator Sherry preached to us about wanting economic growth and to achieve economic growth we have to save! I say to him, `Go back and look at Labor's record, because it was abysmal.'

The budget Mr Costello brought down last Tuesday night gives Australians hope because it shows that this government is about not spending beyond our means, not leaving a debt to for the next generation that it cannot jump over, and doing something about the $180 billion that we owe the rest of the world, on which we pay $10 billion interest a year.

That is $10 billion we do not have to spend on carers programs, $10 billion we do not have to give incentives to people to make contributions to superannuation or to savings, $10 billion we do not have to spend on infrastructure, $10 billion we do not have to spend on hospitals, $10 billion we do not have to spend on all the other things people come into my office asking for because the former Labor government racked up an enormous amount of debt and took us from $23 billion when they first got into power to $180 billion worth of debt. So to come in here and preach to us about saving, I say to them, `Get your own house in order first before you tell us and the Australian community what to do.'

What this budget is doing is saying to Australians, `We are saving as a government to reduce our debt.' Another demonstration of that is in the partial sale of Telstra where, other than the money going to the natural heritage trust, the money will retire debt. What did the Labor Party do when they were in government? They sold the Commonwealth bank. They sold the first half and promised they would not sell the next half—and they sold it. They sold Qantas, and where did the money go? It went into a recurrent fund; it was just spent—no retirement of debt.

So the message the previous Labor government gave to Australians was: `Spend, spend, spend. Don't save, because we don't need to save as a nation. You don't need to save as an individual.' Private debt increased to record levels. Australians privately owed enormous amounts of money, just like the government did.

Encouraging people to save is central to the aim of our budget. It is estimated that 6 million will benefit from this scheme, and they will be dismayed, I guess, at Labor's criticism and negativity. But Labor demonstrated that it was out of touch, and the Australian public responded to that in the last election. We saw an overwhelming number of Liberals elected because Labor had got out of touch and because they do not understand what the Australian people want.

The Labor Party sucked $70 billion out of the national saving pool just in the last five years it was in office. It spent $70 billion more than we were getting in. We have said we will turn this around by responsible policies to boost public and private saving. It is not `Do as I say, not do as I do'; it is `Do as I say and do as I do' because we are demonstrating by our determination to reduce public debt that we are also in the business of saving.
Our measures in this budget, particularly the savings measure, have received widespread support. Before I go any further, let me read a couple of quotes from people. John Maroney from LISA said:

BREAK.PARA: LISA applauded the government's action to improve the retirement income system introducing greater freedom of choice, more realistic preservation requirements and pension take up deferral incentives—a move advocated by LISA members for the past decade. The integrity of the retirement income system is considerably bolstered by these measures with an added bonus of marked improvement in the national savings position in the long term.
Mark Patterson from the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry said:
The government has also turned the L‐A‐W taxed trust—
This is the l‐a‐w promises that the Labor Party was going to give but never gave; the promises kept disappearing out into the distance—
to good use in financing a series of savings measures . . . Greater savings will help finance the growth of investment and will repay this initial seed money many times over in the long term.
He goes on to say:

This is a very good Budget which will go a long way towards restoring growth and lowering unemployment. Its defining characteristic is stability. It maintains an even keel, while improving saving and building confidence.
Richard Gilbert, the Executive Director of the Investment Funds Association, said:

The Budget initiatives for investment and savings are closely aligned to the industry's position. The initiative to introduce across the board incentives for all savings vehicles, including managed investments . . . will receive wholesale support across the community. It is a clear signal that the Government wants all Australians to raise levels of saving and should help to turn around our savings culture.
Terry McCrann said:
Peter Costello has decisively buried the Keating legacy in more ways than one with a very good budget.

It consolidates the nation's finances around a smaller government dynamic—‐ importantly not a slash and burn and bash the poor smaller government but one that seeks to make government work better delivering the same services more efficiently and cheaply.

Terry McCrann says it has buried the Keating legacy. What was the Keating legacy? The Keating legacy was: a massive $10.3 million debt in that last year, which Australia could not afford; a foreign debt, as I said, of over $180 billion; interest loans that went up to 17½ per cent; the highest unemployment since the Great Depression, with nearly one million people out of work and reducing living standards.

The figures on living standards show that Australia fell from the 10th position in world rankings in 1983 to the 22nd position, so that when most of us here were leaving school the rest of the world owed us money; by 1983 we were 10th in the world rankings, and by the time Labor left office we had fallen to 22nd in world rankings in terms of living standards. The Keating budgets produced an increased tax burden on Australians, and we saw the increase in wholesale sales tax and all the sort of tax by stealth that went on Labor. The other thing that happened under Labor was that the rich got richer and the poor got poorer, and we saw 600,000 children under 14 years of age living in poverty. That was the legacy that Labor left us. That was the legacy of Keating.

As I said, Labor's record on national saving was absolutely abysmal. National savings in this country fell to the lowest share of GDP that we ever had, excluding the two world wars and the Great Depression. So the only other time that national savings had decreased to the level they were at under Labor was when our country was in dire straits—either facing a depression or either of the two world wars. That was the situation we were in under Labor in terms of savings.

The Labor Party has no credibility whatsoever in the savings debate. They had a plan to boost private savings but at an enormous cost to the public. We said that we were determined to turn around Labor's legacy of deficit, debt and low national saving.

Labor said that the key to boosting national saving was to get the budget back into surplus, but they could not do it. They tried and they pretended before the last election that they had. Then, after the election, it all came out. We were not able to get the figures but, as soon as the election was over, the figures came out and there we saw the debt that was left just from that last year. But they went to the election fooling the Australian public that they had managed to get a budget in balance, which they had not.

We are proud that we are succeeding where Labor failed. In two years we have managed it; they had 13 years and they could not do it. In broad terms, we are forecasting that the Commonwealth budget will contribute this year about $1.6 billion to the national saving pool in 1998‐99, compared to the $10.3 billion that the Labor government left us in debt in their last year in office.

We have been able to restore public saving and boost national savings. Labor never introduced any reward for people who saved. When Senator Sherry was speaking, he showed a degree of myopia or tunnel vision in this debate. Maybe, because he has been in this chamber on the superannuation debate for days, he can now focus only on those people who are saving for their retirement.

The method that the Labor Party was going to put into place to increase saving left many Australians out of the equation. Who did they leave out of the equation? They left out people who were out of the work force and retired people, who were not going to benefit from their measures. So there was no reward for those people who saved. The whole focus was on saving for retirement. That is absolutely vital and important, but there are also other people who can contribute to saving. They are people who are out of the work force—and there are some, albeit a small number—who can manage to save because of some other form of income; and there are older people. As Senator Sherry rightly said, older people have a culture and a tradition of saving—of not living on the never‐never plan, of not buying things on hire purchase or on credit cards. They also save but they were not going to benefit.

There are many Australians who would have got nothing, not a dollar of benefit from Labor's scheme. The plan that they had, the compulsory three per cent cut in disposable income, was going to be a problem for many workers as well. We believe that we have the balance right: higher public and national saving, and an affordable, fair and universal incentive for private saving. Our plan will provide higher national savings.

The claim that this scheme is discriminatory is not true. As I have indicated before, Labor's plan was totally discriminatory. There were people—poor, rich or in between—who could not get access to the scheme at all, whatever their income. They were left out because they were not in the paid work force. There is no limit to claiming this savings rebate: you can claim it on $1 or you can claim it on $100; if you want to put it into superannuation, you can claim it on $3,000 of superannuation contributions.

During their 13 years in government, Labor and their policies were discriminatory. They did not want to give the aged or parents looking after children the opportunity to save or the reward for saving. What the Labor Party was all about in relation to superannuation was not encouraging savings—that was not their motive. It was about delivering financial power to the trade union movement. All they ever cared about was locking up the funds in industry and occupational superannuation funds. It was discriminatory because, as I said, a large number of people were left out. The Labor Party has opposed retirement savings accounts. They opposed setting them up as an alternative to superannuation, especially for those people who could not access superannuation. They have opposed choice all the way along the line.

Our approach is totally different. Our government believes in choice, and we are giving people a choice in relation to superannuation. If you want to take the savings rebate on savings in banks, in building societies or in credit unions, you can do it; if you want to take the savings rebate in relation to equities, you can do it that way; and if you want to take the savings rebate in relation to superannuation, you can do that—it is your choice. This is an opportunity for all people to have choices in relation to savings and it is a breakthrough to encourage savings through the tax system. We have delivered that choice to the Australian people.

The Labor Party can sit here and be critical and negative, and say that it is not going to work and that it is going to be detrimental. I have to remind the Australian people again and again that we have a substantial savings problem. Mr FitzGerald, who was commissioned to write a report for the Labor Party when it was in government, outlined that Australia had a major savings problem. As I said, our savings rate has fallen as a proportion of GDP. It was 25 per cent of GDP in the 1960s and early 1970s, and has fallen to around 18½ per cent since 1983. So we have seen an enormous drop in our savings rate as a proportion of GDP.

What does that mean? It means that, when our savings drop, we have to rely on the savings of foreigners. We have to rely on borrowing money from overseas to pay for the things that we want. Whether businesses are buying other businesses or individuals are purchasing property, we actually have to go overseas for our savings. That makes us much more dependent on fluctuations in the world market and in world interest rates. We become victims of changes in our currency rate as well, because if our currency rate changes, our interest rates change.

In every single way, by increasing our private or public borrowings, we place Australia and our sovereignty at risk. When people walk around here worrying about the republic, for example—and there are even some on my side who do that—one of the things that I say to them is that our sovereignty is at risk if we keep borrowing, if we expose ourselves financially. That ought to be our first concern.

Our aim is to encourage and inculcate a concept of saving, both at a public level and a personal level. That is what this measure is all about. Increasing savings will bring important economic benefits for Australia. As I said, it will reduce our reliance on foreign debt and, with more saving, we can finance more of our own investment to bring economic growth and to provide jobs.

The savings rebate will benefit around six million taxpayers and the bulk of the benefit will flow to individuals with a taxable income under $40,000. As for the comments that were made by those on the other side, they are absolute furphies. It will benefit current savers and it will encourage others to start saving. As you move around the traps, how many of you have heard people say, `Why would I bother saving? They tax my income and then they tax the income I make on savings.' There is an incredible disincentive to save. So people say, `I may as well spend.' It is one of the issues that we will be proud of, that we will actually reward people for saving. That is an issue. Saving is a vital and important ingredient for Australia, for its growth and to maintain its independence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

SPEECH.PARA: This Budget is a confidence trick. It purports to be all about increasing national savings, but in fact it will reduce them.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say that.
—Yes, you did. You said that nothing they did added to national savings. You talked about their superannuation scheme.
—Go back and read the Hansard

—I do not agree with you on part of it, Senator Patterson. It is true that the super co‐contribution would have worsened the budget deficit, but it would have added to private savings because it is locked up in people's superannuation. Mr Costello's decision not to make a similarly neutral switch between public savings and private savings has no effect on national savings. The fact is that Mr Costello makes it even worse than that, because he had $4 billion worth of choices. What does he do? He decides to spend $2 billion on this and $2 billion on—
—And $2 billion on slush funds.
—I will take that interjection, `And $2 billion on slush funds.'
—Order! I remind Senator Conroy that interjections are disorderly, but they are even more disorderly when you are not in your own seat.

—I am happy to say it in my own words—$2 billion on what many editorialists have already identified as slush funds. The problem is that, when you take $2 billion out without increasing savings, you cannot claim that your savings measure, your budget centrepiece, is actually going to do what you said is the purpose of it, which is to increase national savings. Yes, we all agree that is a worthy goal.

SPEECH.PARA: Back in 1994, the OECD produced a major study on taxation of savings. It identified a range of criteria to assist nations in developing tightly targeted savings tax incentives. Senator Patterson and others accuse us of not wanting to give people incentives to save. We do not mind incentives. We just want you to get the design right so that you actually achieve the goals that you set for yourself. Having a set of criteria from the OECD, it is really interesting to see that the Peter Costello design, the rebate, fails to follow virtually every one of these criteria.

The Costello-Howard saving tax savings plan is not means tested. That is the first flaw. The second flaw is it applies to all savings, not just to new savings. The third flaw is it is not tied to medium-term savings to encourage people to put money away. The fourth flaw is it can be used in conjunction with a whole lot of other tax dodges available to the wealthy.

BREAK.PARA: That is not all: the more you earn, the bigger the rebate. To get the full rebate, you would need to be putting away about $50 a week into superannuation—and as we have pointed out, that is 10 per cent of the income of a middle income earner, which is an impossible task—or you have to have $60,000 already squirreled away in the bank. I know a lot of Australian battlers who have $60,000 who are going to be overjoyed that they can get a $450 rebate for that. The only people who have the savings ability to pick up the full rebate—whatever choice this government is giving them—are high income earners. I will just go through some more figures to substantiate this claim.

Forty-three per cent of low and middle income earning Australians have no savings at all but, suddenly, $60,000 would help them. Sixty-one per cent of low and middle income earners in Australia are not making personal contributions into superannuation. So that means that nearly half of all low income earners will not benefit from this rebate. You may have given them choice, but you have given them no incentive and no benefit.

I do not think you can ignore the impact of last year's budget on these people as well. When we try to look at why they have not been saving, I think it is instructive to remember that last year's budget cost the average Australian household $7 a week in higher charges. By contrast, over 70 per cent of high income earners are paying into superannuation an average of $80 a week, and over 75 per cent have large savings or share portfolios, an average of $84,000 each.

Yes, these people will all get the full rebate—$8.60 a week, $450 a year—but for doing something they are already doing, not for new savings. They will not have to save a single extra cent to pick up this new tax break. So when Senator Patterson and others say that there is no limit to claiming on what kind of savings you will have—$1, $60,000—that certainly helps this particular group of already comfortable Australians. It will be just money for jam for them.

Senator Patterson argued that because this savings plan is universal, it is non‐discrimina tory. But the fact is that over half of the $2 billion tax break will flow to high income earners. So I think it is certainly discriminatory in its impact. Last year's budget took $500 million from high income earners' superannuation tax breaks. This year's budget gives them a billion dollars back. What a rip off.

On that fundamental question: will it add to national savings, most of us doubt it. It is not just us here engaging in a political debate; those who have done the analysis doubt that it will add very much at all. Why is that the case? High income earners do not need any incentive to do what they have already been doing. They have the capacity and they will simply be rewarded for what they have been doing all along. Mr Vince FitzGerald, the author of the national savings report, predicts that this measure will actually reduce national savings because the tax break—$2 billion a year—will be more than any increase in national savings.

I saw what the coalition said they were going to do in their election campaign, and I cannot believe that they would change the design of that so fundamentally. In my view, to proceed with a savings rebate that is not targeted is a very silly thing to do. Tax breaks on savings also have to be means tested. Up until this week, as we know, the coalition had said that their plans involved such means testing. In fact, their particular election policy said that these tax breaks should apply only to those earning incomes below $35,000 a year and should be phased out for those on incomes up to $39,000 a year. I think that cost about $230 million, from memory. It was tightly targeted, not too costly, and it gave incentives.

In the election campaign we said, `We think this is a very reasonable thing to do and if they want to do this when they are in government they are likely to get our support because, yes, we do need to do something about incentives for savings.' But this billion dollars, this racket—money for jam for the already wealthy who are already saving—could have been spent on a lot of other more imaginative and constructive things for Aus tralia in this budget, things called j-o-b-s, jobs.

The cancellation of the l-a-w tax cuts—which we never supported because we thought at the time they were economic vandalism, and we still maintain that view, but the co‐contribution was slightly more responsible—gave Treasurer Costello a lot more leeway than he expected to have when framing this budget. I think most people support using $2 billion to retire debt; it is a necessary thing to do. Part of the other $2 billion could certainly have been used for a tightly targeted savings rebate. But some of the other $2 billion should certainly have been used to reduce unemployment.

The best, the fastest, the surest and the fairest way of increasing national savings is to cut unemployment. It raises national income, it reduces social security spending, it increases tax receipts. Most of all, it provides hope to the 803,200 Australians currently looking for work. I think there is a taxation statistics that needs to be shouted from the rooftops: a fall of one per cent in unemployment can provide a one and a half billion dollar boost to the budget bottom line. But, no, what do we see from this government? We see more and more cutting and we see an absolute waste of money in this badly targeted savings scheme.

A national savings plan without addressing unemployment is only half a national savings plan. A national savings plan that provides a huge and poorly targeted tax break, which actually reduces national savings, is not worth the paper it is written on. How could this government get it so wrong, given the starting point they had in their election documents? One can only speculate that this is some kind of cynical massaging of the damage done by the 15 per cent superannuation tax. I think the government has gone about that massaging in entirely the wrong way. Most Australians out there asking, `What does this mean for me?' have already got the message that it means practically nothing at all. It is so disappointing that you made this mistake, and that is why we support the motion moved by Senator Sherry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hogg, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion moved by Senator Sherry this evening and in doing so support the comments that he made. I am not going to traverse much of the ground that he has already covered in his address this afternoon. In particular, I am going to focus on the practicality of the decision of the government. Before doing so, I just want to state that the access to superannuation which was made available to the vast majority of people in the work force under occupational superannuation and also through the superannuation guarantee was a real boon for them and provided for them a real hope that they would be able to achieve a retirement with some dignity attached to it.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, the significance of superannuation was that it was always going to deliver something better than the age pension. It was never going to deliver the same quality of retirement as senior executives received and it was never designed to. Nonetheless, it was going to give something to people infinitely better and more desirable than the age pension. Of course to do that you had to have a proper base from which people could build their superannuation. While the superannuation guarantee was set at a level of nine per cent, as Senator Sherry said, it was never going to be sufficient. You always have to reach a higher level and that higher level—regardless of what the government might like to believe—has to be 15 per cent; otherwise you are going to underfund the retirement benefit of superannuation for people in the longer term.

Of course what we have seen from the government in the last couple of days is the wrecking of the hope of people of achieving reasonable superannuation in their retirement. Unfortunately, it has cut out those who need superannuation most; those who are in the low to middle income areas are going to be most affected by this decision because the rebate that has been offered by the government is illusory as those people just do not have the money to save.

BREAK.PARA: As I said, I would like to address some of the more practical issues, particularly the issue of choice, and it is here that I have some real experience because I was a trade union secretary at the time of the introduction of award superannuation. I saw how choice operated in that environment where employers, superannuation funds and the like fought like mad to get the business of those people that they thought were most susceptible—the workers who had little or no knowledge about how superannuation operated.

The particular experience I had was with one firm in Queensland which desperately, and in a paternalistic way, fought to keep its people out of bona fide recognised funds under the award. The firm kept on telling its employees, `Trust us', and shunted them into what ultimately ended up being a substandard fund. This was in spite of there existing, at that time, at least two reputable industry funds which they could have been signed up with. I had the task of challenging that employer and trying to put it to the employees that they were being led down the garden path. Of course, the employer fought tooth and nail to stop those people exercising a right of choice and getting themselves into a legitimate fund.

When I went to put to the employees the simple proposition that the fund that they had been shunted into was substandard, and was going to be detrimental to their long‐term benefit, I was called every name under the sun. As a matter of fact it was the only time that I have ever threatened anyone with defamation. But, as it turned out, I was prevented from telling those people of the alternative and we ended up in the Industrial Commission. After much bluster, we ended up with a settlement with the company where they finally agreed to pay new money into a then approved fund.

However, the old money was quarantined in an old fund and—not beyond the realms of possibility—what do you think happened? The company went broke, the fund went broke and so the savings that people had at that time went down the drain. The organisation that I was associated with, and still am associated with in an honorary capacity, the SDA, spent much time, effort and money pursuing that particular employer to recover from that defunct fund the assets that belonged to the employees. Whilst there are prudential activities in place now that will stop that happening, what we ended up with was a very sad and sorry sight of people losing money—losing their retirement benefit.

Of course that was principally brought about because, whilst theoretically the people had a choice of funds to go into, that choice was denied to them because of the attitude of the employer. Whilst there are prudential safeguards in place today, I have no doubt that under the proposition that the government has put forward employees will find themselves being put at risk again. Again, whilst their savings will not go completely down the drain, they will be put into substandard superannuation funds which will inhibit their opportunity of having a decent retirement.

So, if you look specifically at the propositions within this document, Savings: Choice and Incentive, you find that new employees are going to be given the opportunity of a choice from five or more superannuation funds, one of which must be a retirement savings account, which is a low return product; one must be a public offer; and then the others can be other funds. But those funds are to be chosen by the employer, not the employee. So, purely at the discretion of the employer, they are going to be offered five funds and all five of those funds could be absolutely and utterly no good, not acting in the best interests of those people for their retirement benefit.

One might say that that is not going to happen. Of course my experience tells me that the employer is not going to be necessarily sympathetic to the needs of the employee but will be sympathetic to what serves their own best interest and their vested purposes in this whole issue. Hence I believe that is one of the reasons why we have this proposition before us, because we see that there will be spin‐off benefits for the employer by offering substandard products and the employee having no choice but to pick from a range of bad products to start off with. That is a real possibility.

Another possibility is that of the employer getting it wrong. What happens if the employer picks products to offer their employees that are substandard? Where will the redress be? How will the employees right the wrong that has been done to them? There is no answer to that at this stage. Another practical problem that arises out of the employer having to provide five or more funds from which the employee must choose within 28 days is that administratively this will end up being a nightmare for small business. This government that so much claimed to protect small business has now foisted another burden upon them.

From the employee side, there are some real problems. Firstly, it will be understanding the propositions that have been put to them. If you have five superannuation packages to choose from, making that choice will not be easy, unless you are informed about superannuation. The average worker—and that is whom we are talking about—is not familiar with the superannuation industry and is not necessarily up to speed with what superannuation funds are good and what superannuation funds are not good. They are relying on the goodwill of the employer to give them some assistance in selecting the fund into which their retirement benefit will be placed.

The other real problem is that some of these employees will be pressured by the employer into accepting the fund which the employer feels most comfortable for them to go into. That has always been the unfortunate reality in the real world where these options and so-called choices are allowed for people. The choice, therefore, may end up being totally illusory and of no benefit to the employee whatsoever. At best, it might be that the person has to choose the worst out of five bad choices made by the employer. That is the situation facing new employees.

Existing employees will be able to make a choice within two years. The problem for both the new employees and existing employees is how they will be able to make an informed choice. If they cannot make an informed choice, their benefit or saving is possibly going to be placed at risk. The government should sit down and examine the fact that these people are not in positions of strength. They do not come from a position of power. They do not come from a position of knowledge; they come from a position of weakness. On that score alone, this proposition should not be entertained.

There will be no opportunity in either case that I have just spoken about for those having made a choice, if it turns out to be a bad choice, to choose again. That is not indicated in the document that has been presented to us so far. Once you are locked into a bad product, it seems that you have to stay there.

I want to make a few comments on the provision of opting out. This concept in the document undermines totally the strategy of universal superannuation. Invariably it will consign part-time workers who are mainly women to the pension. That, to me, is a retrograde step in our community. I came from an industry which was dominated by part-time women who had gained access to superannuation and who, over a long period of time, would have built up a reasonable benefit.
