The other problem with opting out is that, on the quiet, it is an extra tax grab. How do I arrive at that? If you look at the bracket within which opting out is allowed—that is, between $450 per month and $900 per month—under this proposal by the government people will be able to take out the difference between the award superannuation and the SG.

The example given in the book fixes that figure at this stage at four per cent—a four per cent difference. If the worker opts to take out that four per cent, which, on the $450 is $18, that money, if it were placed in the superannuation fund, would have been taxed at 15 per cent. However, because they take it as cash in the hand, it will be taxed at the marginal rate. Those people will be paying a higher rate of tax on the money that they have taken out.

The second thing about that money is that, in taking it out, it will not be used in savings. The reason that they would be taking it out would be to spend it on consumables; to spend it on their lifestyle. So money that would have otherwise been put into superannuation—into compulsory savings—would have been diverted to other purposes and would have defeated the very thing that we all seem to agree on: the fact that there is a low level of savings in this nation.

This package of opting out provides no discernible extra means of support for the employee. All it does is reduce their long-term benefit from superannuation, particularly when you consider that the SG will reach nine per cent and they have the chance to opt out up to six per cent—if three per cent is the award superannuation, which it is in many awards. What they are ultimately missing out on as a contribution to their retirement is double the award superannuation rate, which is a substantial amount of money indeed. So this leaves us in the long term with the problem of people being underfunded in their retirement.

If a person takes the option of opting out of the difference in the superannuation from the three per cent to the SG, that person undoubtedly will take the money to live on and they certainly will not save it. The money, in my mind, would be best left in the super fund, working for that person's retirement. But there are other problems and other questions.

If people opt out, who will monitor the compliance of what is happening? Currently, the SG is monitored by the Australian Tax Office; there is a guarantee that the SG is paid. But if people opt out and take the four per cent in cash, where will the proof be? Nowhere in this document is that explained. Also, will people who opt out, particularly the part-timers, lose a range of benefits, which are currently available to people in superannuation funds, because they are not full contributors to the funds? Will they find themselves denied access to death and disablement insurance? They might find themselves at some time in the future, depending on government policy, without access to low cost mortgages.

What about the part-timers with more than one job? It is wrong to believe that part-timers have only one job; in this day and age, they have more than one. What if they do have more than one job and earn over the $900 threshold? Those people may well opt out in one or both of the jobs, and yet that defeats the purpose of what the government has put to us in this document here.

What about in a wage negotiation situation? Who has the upper hand in negotiations as to whether the worker receives occupational superannuation or takes the wage increase? Last but not least, if the worker opts out at, let us say, the four per cent difference, will the opting out four per cent be raised as the SG is raised—to five per cent, to six per cent? Alternatively, will the worker forgo forever the additional amounts of money? That is, of course, what will happen if they settle by cashing out the four per cent.

I believe that there are many other problems, and I will not pursue them this evening but on other occasions. Tonight in this place I have heard some people quoted as authorities on this initiative of the government, but I think none can be better quoted than Max Walsh in his article today, where he said:
In fact, in terms of economic management the budget savings rebate scheme is a bit of a joke. It almost certainly will not make any significant addition to household savings.
(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hogg has spoken a great deal about choice in superannuation, and the way in which employees will be constrained from making any choices whatever. In answer to the point you raise, Senator Hogg, I would point out that the government has specifically stated that, if it exists, the employer must include the relevant industry fund, and the employer must also include at least one other public fund. It has also stated that employers will not be required to act on an employee's changed nomination of fund within 12 months of acting on a previous nomination; that is, employees will still be able to change funds at least once a year. Indeed, that is what the whole savings initiative is about—that of choice and that of incentive. You can either choose to save money yourself or you can contribute more to a superannuation fund.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party, as observed both during their time in government and during their time in opposition, are not exactly the best people to be talking about choice, incentive or, indeed, savings. There are about 70 billion reasons why Labor has no credibility in savings—and that is the $70 billion worth of deficits they ran up in their last five years in office. Now that they are in opposition, they are trying to stop us from fixing up their problem.

For instance, what have they done both in the last budget and during the 12 months we have seen them in opposition? They have voted against billions and billions of dollars worth of public saving measures. They have voted against research and development changes, worth $550 million in a full year; they have voted against HECS changes, worth $670 million in a full year; they have voted against migrant waiting period changes, worth $200 million in a full year; and they have effectively voted against the super surcharge, worth $500 million in 1998-99—and that is just while they are in opposition.

What did they do when they were in government? They contributed to one of the greatest blow‐outs in our general debt level ever seen in the history of our country. They were unable to raise public saving, and they were unable to keep the current account deficit under control. Australia's credit rating was twice downgraded under Labor, largely because of very high current account deficits. They left office with the budget in the worst position since at least 1960. As I said, they ran up $70 billion worth of deficits in their last five years. And their policies, as they enunciated them during the 1996 election campaign, would have kept Australia running big deficits right through this term of parliament.

My household budget and the household budget of many responsible citizens tells us that you simply cannot keep stacking things up on the bankcard and expecting to emerge at the end of it in a responsible financial position. One way or another, the debt has to be paid.

Prior to 1975, the Commonwealth government consistently ran underlying budget surpluses—that is, it contributed to national saving. Since 1975, the Commonwealth has run an average underlying deficit of around 1½ per cent of GDP. Commonwealth general government net debt has exploded from around four per cent in June 1990 to around 19 per cent today. The Labor Party is largely responsible for that.

As I have said, Labor has had a record both in opposition and in government of not attacking the deficit and not undertaking responsible measures to try to decrease our debt. In fact, their record on national saving is utterly abysmal. Under them, national savings in this country fell to their lowest share of GDP this century, excluding the two world wars and the Depression. So they have absolutely no credibility in the savings debate.

They had a plan to boost private saving but at an enormous cost to public saving. Their plan was never going to happen, simply because it is not affordable. I would like one Labor speaker on the other side to stand up and tell me in what year you delivered the l-a-w tax cuts. When was that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you know what `national savings' is?

—When we came to office we said we were determined to turn around Labor's legacy of deficit and debt and low national saving. You always said, Senator Conroy, that the key to boosting national saving was to get the budget back in surplus, but you could never do it. We are proud that we are taking measures to succeed where Labor failed. In broad terms, we are forecasting that the Commonwealth budget will contribute around $1.6 billion to the national saving pool in 1998‐99 compared with the $10.3 billion that your government sucked out of that pool in your last year of office.

SPEECH.PARA: We are proud that we are about to restore public saving and boost national saving while, at the same time, providing an equitable and universal incentive for all Australians to save. You never introduced any tax incentive for personal savings in your 13 years in office.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's because they're hand‐outs to the rich.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. Senator Conroy, under your never delivered l‐a‐w tax scheme, many Australians would have got nothing—not one dollar of benefits. What did your plan offer the workers? Your plan involved a compulsory three per cent cut in disposable income, something which Australian workers would not accept. We have the balance right. We are attempting to provide higher public and national saving and an affordable, fair and universal incentive for higher private saving.

SPEECH.PARA: Our plan will provide higher national saving. It will keep the pressure off interest rates, something which is absolutely necessary for an injection of economic power into small business and for the many farmers in this country who are suffering under very high interest rates. It will keep the pressure off taxes, it will encourage higher growth and it will create more jobs.

Private savings are not the problem. Private savings have remained pretty steady over the last three decades. Your government was unable to raise public saving and was unable to tame the current account deficit. You recognised this problem when you commissioned the FitzGerald report. That report stressed the need for the government to balance its books, but you were not up to the task, because you would not implement it. Instead of moving to surpluses and taking the very hard decisions that we have had to take since we came to government, you just kept running up big deficits. Instead of taking the pressure off interest rates, interest rates went up and they achieved very high levels.

We do have the answers to fix this problem. Instead of running up big deficits which suck out savings, we will be adding to the national savings pool. Rather than building up a huge debt stockpile, we will cut the debt stockpile by almost half as a share of GDP over the forward estimates. We will make structural gains on the current account. We will keep the pressure off interest rates and, by paying our way, we will not be letting the debt burden fall on our children.

Most national leaders always talk about the sort of vision that we hope to pass on to our children and the sort of country we want Australia to be in 10, 20 or 50 years time. The last thing I want for my children is for them to be under the burden of a national debt which only increased taxes and very high interest rates can go any way towards paying.

What have we decided to do? We are delivering an incentive for private saving, with the biggest incentive for saving via superannuation. Not only that, we are strengthening our retirement incomes policy, including changes to the preservation arrangements.

What would your l‐a‐w scheme have offered by comparison? It was not affordable and it involved wrecking public saving in an effort to provide an incentive for private saving. That does not really make sense. Your scheme meant compulsorily cutting three per cent of workers' disposable income. Many workers would simply not have been able to afford that.

If you thought your l‐a‐w tax cuts were such a great idea, why didn't you deliver them after the 1993 election? You were returned in the 1993 election, much to your surprise, and you then had another three years in which to move towards a much more successful scheme. Why didn't you do it? Perhaps one of your speakers would like to stand up and tell us that.

By and large, Labor would never have delivered. We are attempting to do so. Your scheme would not have boosted national savings because it was never going to be delivered and because it was going to cost too much. By the year 2000, it was going to be costing $4 billion a year. The cost would have kept on going up and up. We do not really accept the comparison as being valid. In any event, what is important is the level of national saving. We have the right balance between good levels of public saving and encouraging private saving.

The rebate will help six million Australians and the bulk of the benefits will flow to people earning less than $40,000 a year. It will help people who will not want to put money into super, such as those who are already retired. These people would have got nothing under the Labor Party. The rebate itself will help six million Australians and the bulk of the benefit, as I said, will flow to people earning less than $40,000 a year.

We need to make these longstanding improvements in the budget bottom line, and that means putting away surpluses in the good times. We all hope that with rising commodity prices Australia's agricultural exports will provide more to help reduce the national debt and to provide more income for those in rural and regional Australia. It also means that with a growing economy—and, faltering though they are, there are some signs of that—we will be able to put away surpluses in the good times. If we fail to get those surpluses in the good years when the terms of trade are running our way, when we are producing more and more exports and the economy is at last picking up, then the process of ever higher debt will continue. That simply means more debt for our children to repay.

Notwithstanding the progress that the government has projected in its budget estimates, government debt as a share of GDP will still be much higher by the end of the century than it was in the mid‐1970s. As I said, from the figures that I gave dating from 1960, the problem did not arise overnight and nor will it be solved overnight. This is the feature of this government: we take a look at the long‐term future of Australia and the way in which economic issues have to be resolved. It would be unrealistic to expect that a very high unemployment level will go away overnight. Nevertheless, on that front also we are adopting measures to move it.

Similarly, the mountain of national debt that I mentioned will not go away overnight either, and it will not be solved overnight. So we have to take a long‐term view. In this our second budget we are looking forward to putting these building blocks in place to build a very strong foundation for the way in which we will move.

No doubt some speakers will quote research which shows that tax breaks for private saving are generally ineffective. We have to start somewhere. If we do not provide incentives for people to save then there will be no incentive for them to save. They will simply spend their money on consumer goods and private saving is not boosted. We hope that the incentive that we have given will give people something to aim for. For instance, today I was talking to a representative of money markets and they were saying that in their opinion this at least gives people a goal and they know that they will get something back for every dollar that they invest.

Not only that; banks are extremely pleased because, with an incentive for people to save, they can see money flowing into them, and this will boost the amount of capital that is available for the vast infrastructure projects which we need to boost employment.

For many people the rebate will mean that investing a dollar in superannuation will only cost 85c. That is a pretty good deal and we are very pleased about it. For many who choose the other option it will mean a higher return on their bank and other savings accounts. Not only does that provide an incentive to increase saving; it will provide an incentive to redirect those savings into superannuation, which will mean higher retirement incomes.

The government would be deluding itself if it thought that this was the sole, or even the primary, answer to our inherited national saving problem. But we see it as one of the key solutions to the problem of restoring public saving.

We do need to make longstanding improvements in our budget bottom line. This means putting away the surpluses at the time that we need to. The main reason we want to boost saving is to boost growth. Until we get that, we cannot get a balanced budget and we cannot get surpluses to see us through the economic downturns which will certainly come. The fact that six million Australians will benefit from this rebate, the vast bulk of whom are low and middle income earners, is something that we take great pride in.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish; absolute rubbish, and you know it. It's a handout to the rich.

—If Senator Conroy had been so anxious to stop handouts to the rich and to stop us targeting some of our budget programs from last year and this year a lot better, the opposition would not have voted the way they have in the Senate and adopted such short‐sighted public economy programs.
—Why aren't you means testing this?

—You had 13 years to fix this problem. As I said to you before, I want one of your speakers to stand up and tell us when you ever delivered anything like this scheme to provide an incentive for people to save. You had 13 years. We have had 12 months. Both in the budget last year and the budget this year—
—You are taking money from the workers and giving it to the rich.

—We have started to move on this problem in a way that you never did. I could retail countless departments and portfolio areas in which you had 13 years to fix the problem and you simply never moved. Perhaps you got too used to being in government; perhaps you decided that your golden age was going to last for ever and that the voters would be absolutely deluded by the carrots that you held out in front of them. Remember the golden dawn was always going to be just above the horizon? For many Australians the sun simply never rose. The constitution, fortunately, gave them the ability to vote on 2 March 1996 and they rejected what you had put forward for 13 years and they voted for the coalition who were able to provide them with a much better incentive and a much better opportunity to actually make something of their lives and to use their incomes in the way in which they would want to.
—Order! The time for the debate on this motion has expired.
—by leave—On behalf of Senator Watson, I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, he will move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Select Committee on Superannuation be authorised to hold a public meeting during the sitting of the Senate on 26 May 1997, from 8 pm, to take evidence for the committee's inquiry into the appropriateness of current unfunded defined benefit superannuation schemes' application to judges and parliamentarians.

TITLE.XREF: NATURAL HERITAGE TRUST OF AUSTRALIA BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (21) Clause 44, page 24 (lines 10 to 11), omit the definition of natural resources management.

By explanation, we here object to the definition of natural resources management, dealt with earlier by the committee, which gives priority to economic and not environmental matters when the minister considers what projects he is going to fund out of this environmental fund in terms of natural resources management.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a consequential amendment, following the failure of Australian Greens' amendment No. 5, as I understand it. This amendment is one the opposition will also be opposing. It is seeking to delete the definition of natural resources management from the bill. It is an amendment, on this occasion, the opposition can see little merit in and will not be supporting.

—The point of it is that the natural resources management definition, if you look at the first component of section 16, is `any activity relating to the management of the use, development or conservation of one of the following natural resources: soil, water or vegetation'. That means it can be any activity relating to the management of the use or development of soil, water and vegetation. We have been through this before. That can include logging operations, mining operations—anything at all that is involved in use of natural resources. Therefore, its becomes a definition which is at best useless in terms of protecting the environment and at worst detrimental.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I fully supported Senator Brown's earlier amendment because it goes to the heart of the issue we discussed previously and the government's inability to understand some of the sovereignties it has got in this bill and the way in which they can be interpreted, but to take it out altogether causes us major problems. Indeed, going back to the Democrats' first batch of amendments, we also attempted to improve the definition, but to take it out altogether we have problems with. Unfortunately, I think it would cause more difficulties in the administration of the trust to take it out totally than would leaving in the inadequate definition.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Clause 44, page 25 (line 4), after "includes", insert "reduction of use,".

The popular saying is: reduce, re‐use, recycle. It is important that we recognise that waste minimisation does not just come out of recycling and re‐use but also out of minimising our use of natural resources in the first place.

We are in an age of gross materialism, consumption and extravagance. We know that in rich, developed countries like Australia we are part of the 20 per cent of the world's population using 80 per cent of the world's resources. We also know that if the rest of the world were to use resources at the rate we do, the planet simply could not stand it. It cannot stand the rate of average use that there is at the moment.

It is very incumbent upon Australians in particular to reduce the use of natural resources. If you are going to have waste minimisation, then the reduction in use of resources in the first place is going to greatly enhance that concept. We have to have a very clear understanding that waste minimisation is not just a matter of recycling. It is cutting down on the wasteful use of the resource in the first place. I think this may be one of those amendments that even good Senator Hill, as Minister for the Environment, could entertain.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We fully support this amendment. I hope the government can have a quick rethink about it and that it too will support what was probably another one of those oversights. I think it is essential that we actually encourage people to reduce the use of resources in a wide range of cases. I appeal to Senator Hill to have a rethink on this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will support this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to demonstrate how resilient we are, we will accept this amendment also. After the way in which we have been treated in this debate—we have been subject to the most unfair and inaccurate assertions for four days—the Greens hardly deserve anything. Nevertheless, because there is some merit in what Senator Brown has said in this instance, we support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry that Senator Harradine is not here to experience this spirit of goodwill with which we conclude, as far as the Greens are concerned, our series of amendments. I would like to thank and congratulate the minister for having accepted this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Preamble, page 1 (line 6), omit "decline in Australia's natural environment", substitute "current decline, and to prevent further decline, in the quality of Australia's natural environment".
(24) Preamble, page 2 (after line 2), after "resources.", insert:

PARA.TAB: There is a need for the Commonwealth to provide national leadership and work in partnership with all levels of government and the whole community, recognising, among other things, that many environmental issues and problems are not limited by State and Territory borders.

SPEECH.PARA: (25) Preamble, page 2 (line 4), omit "and sustainable development", substitute ", sustainable agriculture and natural resources management consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development".
(26) Preamble, page 2 (lines 5 to 7), omit the paragraph.
(27) Preamble, page 2 (after line 9), after"matters.", insert:

PARA.TAB: The Commonwealth Government should work co-operatively with State governments to achieve effective outcomes in matters relating to environmental protection, natural resources management and sustainable agriculture. Those co-operative working relationships should involve entering into inter-governmental agreements which reflect the support of the States for the purposes of the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Reserve and promote the development of complementary policies and programs.

SPEECH.PARA: (28) Preamble, page 2 (lines 10 to 12), omit the paragraph, substitute:

PARA.TAB: Australia's rural community should have a key role in the ecologically sustainable management of Australia's natural resources.

SPEECH.PARA: (29) Preamble, page 2 (lines 13 and 14), omit "Australia's natural environment is central to Australia's well-being and to Australia's future economic prosperity.", substitute "Australia's natural environment is central to Australia's and Australians' health and non-material well‐being and to Australia's present and future economic prosperity.".
These amendments cover a number of issues that we have discussed before.

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will be supporting these amendments.

—Thank you, Senator Hill. I note that the government will support these amendments to the preamble. They are not as strong as we would have liked, but they do cover some of the issues. For example, one issue relating to resource management was picked up by Senator Brown two amendments ago—that is, that it has to be consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development. I recommend these amendments to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition does not have to be forced to accept these amendments. We are accepting them on merit, even though they could be stronger. I appreciate the difficulties Senator Lees has had in working with this recalcitrant minister and in coming to arrangements on these matters. Regardless, and in the same spirit that other senators, with the exception of Senator Hill, are applying to the debate, we will support these amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens also support these amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to proceed with opposition amendment No. 9 standing in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (30) Preamble, page 2 (after line 16), after "environment.", insert:

PARA.TAB: Australia is part of the global community and, accordingly, needs to contribute responsibly to international treaties, conventions and actions to protect the environment and promote ecologically sustainable development.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment refers to Australia's global responsibilities, or what I would hope the minister would consider to be our global responsibilities. It is just asking this government to think again about the role we should be playing. Just as our responsibilities do not stop at state borders, they do not stop at international borders. Hopefully the government will have had another look at this amendment and will be more comfortable with it now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally support Senator Lees and the Democrats on this amendment. I will use as an example native vegetation clearance. We know from scientific studies that that is one of the biggest contributors to the global warming phenomenon.

SPEECH.PARA: Even at this late hour an amendment like this which might stimulate some extra thought in the mind of the minister or his department about their responsibilities in terms of using the moneys from this legislation to get recal citrant state governments like Queensland to, in particular, stop the destruction of native vegetation cover has, besides the local benefits to the nation of stopping the loss of biodiversity, for example, the global of advantage of reducing our untoward contribution to the greenhouse gas emissions in this country which are way beyond the pale when it comes to good management. We have a commitment to the livelihoods of future generations and to the environment that they are going to inherit to consider our current activities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to this amendment. It is gratuitous and unnecessary. We do not need to be told by legislation that we need to comply with our international treaty obligations. We enter into treaties in the spirit of intending to comply with our obligations otherwise we would not sign up. This would be an odd piece of drafting to appear in any Commonwealth act and therefore we do not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very disappointed to hear the contribution from Senator Hill, but I cannot say that I am particularly surprised as the government lurches towards the conclusion of, without any doubt, the worst week it has had since its election. We now have Senator Hill and the government announce they are opposed, in effect, to motherhood. That is what you are saying, Senator Hill. This is a most extraordinary statement on your behalf.

SPEECH.PARA: I think we have just heard the words of an embittered man. He wants to get away to his dinner break I suspect. I am disappointed that you are opposed to motherhood. But, as I say, after your and Mr Howard's performance this week, I am not at all surprised—others may be. To all those listening to this debate I think it probably says it all—a most churlish final contribution from Senator Hill, and he stands condemned for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —What is more, Senator Hill is an active participant in breaching Australia's international heritage obligations. Let me give you some examples. Firstly, he has been giving the go‐ahead for the mega‐resort of Mr Williams at Hinchinbrook which breaches our obligation to properly present and protect areas of world heritage value. In this case, two world heritage areas—the wet tropics and the Great Barrier Reef—are being impacted upon by a project for which he gave the go‐ahead.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, there are forests in Tasmania of world heritage value that should be in the world heritage area, including tall eucalypts and rainforests. This minister has given the go‐ahead for their destruction by the woodchip industry.

Thirdly, he is in the process of devolving all responsibility for world heritage nominations and listings to state governments. State governments do not have these international obligations on their shoulders; the minister and the government do. Flaunting obligations to the World Heritage Convention has become the norm rather than the exception as far as Senator Hill is concerned. No wonder he does not want to have this clause put into the legislation.
Amendment negatived.
Bill, as amended, agreed to, subject to requests.
Bill reported with amendments and requests; report adopted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended from 6.18 p.m. to 7.30 p.m.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That the Senate take note of the Budget statement and documents.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —After 15 months Australians have begun asking: what has their Prime Minister been doing? What does he stand for? After seeing this budget, they have a right to ask: where are we going? What has all the pain been for?

BREAK.PARA: If there is one word to describe this budget and this government, it is `directionless'. This is a budget that ignores the central problems facing this nation: jobs and job security.

This government was elected under the slogan `For All of Us'—a promise that a Prime Minister Howard would provide leadership and that we could face the future `relaxed and comfortable'. But this is not a budget for all of us; it is a budget for some of us—not for the many, but the few. Indeed, it is not even for the few, rather it is for the very few:
This is a budget of `them and us':
. A budget that does not even know its own mind.
. A budget of which Mr Costello is smugly proud and of which the Prime Minister is selectively ashamed.
. A budget that shows the fudge, indecision and economic shallowness along with the instinctive cruelty of a government bereft of vision and purpose.
Last election the Prime Minister told us he had a plan for Australia. Well, where is the plan? Surely it cannot be this budget. Surely it was not the things this government has achieved so far:
. a slowdown in economic growth;
. slow and faltering growth in jobs, and an increase in unemployment;
. withdrawal of federal government services from regional and rural Australia—closure of Medicare, social security, CES and tax offices around the country;
. abolition of industry assistance programs;
. abolition of labour market programs for the long term unemployed;
. introduction of punishing up‐front fees for older Australians entering nursing homes; and higher fees for parents needing to use child care;
. introduction of $100,000 university degrees so that the rich can get in ahead of the poor and bright.
And the sorry list goes on.

Last year we had the perverted morality of core promises and non‐core promises. Behind this cloak, the Howard government dodged and weaved its way through its election promises, picking and choosing as it went. `Be relaxed and comfortable', we were told. `Trust me', he said. How can Australians trust the Prime Minister or feel secure or confident about their future if they cannot be confident about their present circumstances? What this country has is a poll driven Prime Minister, a Prime Minister who will not make a move until the polls tell him to move, and tell him which way to move. We cannot afford a Prime Minister like that.

Australians were promised certainty, security and, most importantly, leadership. The government has not delivered on any of these. Rather, they have delivered uncertainty, insecurity and indecisiveness: and across the country a mood of quiet anger and frustration.

Mr Howard struggled so hard and so long to be Prime Minister of our country. Now he occupies that office, he is like a rabbit caught in a spotlight: stunned and uncertain which way to turn. This budget just confirms the narrowness of his vision.

A budget should, at the very least, be good economics. Labor has always agreed that Australia will benefit from bringing the federal budget into balance. But it has questioned the methods of achieving that goal, and the timetable.

We have argued that it should be achieved without destroying valuable public programs, without slowing the economy, without destroying services in rural and regional Australia, and without budget tricks.

The budget relies on stealing $3.7 billion from workers' superannuation plans in four years. These super co‐contributions, which were promised, and which were funded in last year's budget, have now been struck out, and the stolen $3.7 billion used to prop up the bottom line.

It relies on an optimistic unemployment forecast so that the bottom line looks better. Worst of all, this budget rips off low income and middle income workers to fund the coalition's extravagances and indulgences. How else can you describe the federation slush fund? People should realise that this slush fund is being paid for by their stolen $3.7 billion super co‐contributions and by increased charges they will be paying at the chemist and for child care. No money for old people's proper medicine but a billion dollars for obelisks, fireworks and centennial champagne. This budget is about the welfare of the Liberal Party and not the welfare of ordinary Australians.

On this criterion, the second Howard budget confirms the government's dismal first year record on the key issues of jobs and economic growth. As a result of its first budget last year, which saw the economy slow to a crawl, the government has now been forced to revise down its forecast for growth in the current year to 3¼ per cent. With the world economy growing healthily, the strong foundations of the economy they inherited, and the housing cycle recovering, this government can surely do better than the 3¾ per cent forecast for next year. Even the Reserve Bank governor thinks that Australia can sustain four per cent growth, without creating inflationary problems.

Without another period of sustained growth around the four per cent mark like that achieved in Labor's last term in office, we cannot reduce unemployment. Under Treasury's economic growth projections, the unemployment rate will still be above 7½ per cent by the end of this century.

When the government talks about jobs growth and job security, the only solution it can offer is more changes to the industrial relations system. No wonder workers feel uncertain about their futures. It is a dismal economic outlook from a government that has nothing to offer on jobs and growth. Jobs growth has stalled. The latest labour force figures for April show that trend employment growth is dead flat—exactly 0.0 per cent.

In the January mid‐year economic review the government revised up its forecast for unemployment from 8¼ per cent to 8½ per cent, a change the Treasurer described at the time as being mainly due to `rounding'. What a great relief that must be to the 23,000 extra unemployed people! `Oh, we're not unem ployed, we're just rounded!' So much for `rounding': the forecast unemployment rate for the June quarter 1997 has now been increased again, to 8¾ per cent.

Since the coalition has been in office, virtually no extra full‐time jobs have been created. The number of unemployed people has risen by 31,500. Long‐term unemployment is at its highest level for two years. Even if the stronger growth forecast for next year is achieved, unemployment will be higher than it should and could have been. Claims of better economic prospects next year do not change the fact that the government has caused the economy to grow too slowly and, as a result, thousands of Australians are needlessly unemployed.

The government's dismal record in office does not generate confidence that it can deliver on the slightly stronger growth forecasts in this budget. Jobs growth and job security are the No. 1 issues in Australia. Labor has said this over and over again. Nothing is as important to the economic and social future of the Australian community as generating new jobs. In doing that we can start to make an impact on our unacceptable levels of unemployment and, at the same time, provide people currently in work with some sense of security about their employment futures.

But the Howard government has been fudging on the jobs issue since it was elected. In the election Mr Howard told us he had a plan to reduce unemployment. Where is that plan? Did it ever exist? Then at the start of this year the government told us to judge their employment record after they had been in office for 12 months. Well, 12 months are up. Fifteen months are up. We can now judge the performance of a government which is not even game enough to set itself a jobs target, and bothers to mention unemployment only once in its budget speech.

When you look at the government's performance you can understand why. In Labor's last year in office total employment grew by 176,000; in the first Howard year, total employment grew by 89,000—by half that amount. Male full‐time employment, in our last year in office, grew by 57,000; in Prime Minister Howard's first year in office, it fell by 12,600. And the number of long-term unemployed fell by 45,000 in our last year in office; in Mr Howard's first year in office, it rose by 44,000. That is the record on which he wanted himself judged. I leave it to all Australians to make their own judgments.

Now, the government says that it hopes that the unemployment rate will fall to eight per cent, but can we be confident? Last year the government loudly forecast the unemployment rate would fall to 8.25 per cent, but it is stuck at 8.7 per cent. There are 31,500 more unemployed Australians now than there were when the coalition came to office. The reason? The government in last year's budget axed government jobs, abolished jobs programs, cut skills training, slashed industry programs and deserted regional Australia. So what does it do in this year's budget in response to the rise in unemployment? More of the same. There are nearly 90,000 young unemployed Australians, and there are more than 700,000 older unemployed Australians. We all know that thousands of workers in their 40s and 50s will lose their jobs in Newcastle, while this government sits idly by. The numbers of unemployed will continue to mount up during the next year. Let us be clear about this. As the federal government retreats towards Sydney and Melbourne, most of the job losses are going to be in regional towns.

While the National Party is lost in action, the federal government is pulling the rug out from centres like Cairns, Townsville, Orange, Ballarat, Bendigo, Whyalla and Launceston. As the Howard government closes its CES, Social Security, Medicare and tax offices, 16,500 more public service jobs will be lost mainly in rural and regional Australia. This follows the 12,600 already gone. And you can add some 4,000 private sector jobs that will go as these offices close. In addition, more than 20,000 jobs are to be lost from Telstra; and the government's defence efficiency review will mean the loss of a further 8,000 defence jobs, many in regional Australia.

So what is the government doing about jobs? Virtually nothing. The government has admitted that its work for the dole scheme will do nothing whatsoever to reduce Australia's high and rising youth unemployment rate. The announcement of the new federation slush fund will do nothing to `generate jobs' quickly. It doesn't even begin until July 1998. Meanwhile, vocational education and training funds have been cut for the second year running. And, sadly, even the number of apprenticeships fell in 1996‐97, as did the growth rate of traineeships. That is what happens when a Prime Minister and his government just don't care.

Yesterday at the National Press Club the Treasurer nominated national savings as the government's most important economic objective. The government's decision to scrap the superannuation co‐contributions policy is a huge blow to national saving. Let us remind ourselves where the $3.7 billion stolen from workers' super plans was going. It was going—all of it plus as much again in individual workers' contributions—straight onto the bottom line of private saving. That $3.7 billion has now been pinched to pay for a re‐election slush fund. There is a savings plan that only the most well off can really benefit from.

The effect on national saving can only be negative. It frightens me to see just how negative. The three plus three per cent co‐contribution scheme alone would have contributed an extra $400 billion to the national savings pool by the year 2020. The coalition just knocked it off. Let us not be fooled about what is happening when the coalition puts the torch to national savings. They are re‐distributing national savings as income, and they are re‐distributing the income. Workers now in their mid‐30s on average weekly earnings will each lose around $110,000 from the lump sum they would have received on retirement under Labor's plan.

But where does this money go? I will tell you where the maximum benefit does not go. It does not go to the three million taxpayers who have no interest income to declare. It does not go to the 42 per cent of taxpayers on below average weekly earnings who do not receive any interest. It does not go to 1.3 million full‐rate age and service pensioners. It does not go to 800,000 unemployed who would be lucky to have anything in the bank.

So where does it go? It definitely goes to the 463 people declaring incomes over $1 million a year, who earn an average of $52,000 a year in interest. It goes in multiples to members of wealthy families who split their savings income using trusts or other arrangements. It goes to big shareholders like the industry minister.

Let me give you a symbol of how this budget divides Australian society. On the day BHP announced the closure of the Newcastle steelworks, the price of BHP shares went up 50c. If you were a senior BHP manager with share options worth $110,000, your decision to close the steelworks would have made you a $3,000 capital gain overnight. Under the scheme announced in this budget, that $3,000 would also have entitled you to the full $450 savings rebate. But, if you were a steelworker, you lost your job.

The vandalising of health care continues in this budget. On health and other social services, the government's intentions over the past two budgets have been absolutely clear. As far as it can, it has walked away from its fundamental responsibility to provide a safety net of service to Australian families—families that have the right to expect their government to help see them through times of stress and vulnerability.

This is not what the Prime Minister promised in his third so‐called headland speech to ACOSS in October 1995. In that speech he gave eight ironclad guarantees. Guarantee No. 8 was that `there is no secret plan to slash $10 billion from social welfare'. At last count on Tuesday night, he had only a few hundred thousand dollars to go.

Senators will also remember his promise to preserve Medicare. He has hung on to the name and some of its main features, but he has also quietly but effectively undermined it in the meantime. Doctors' payments for home visits have been reduced. Eventually it will be impossible to get a doctor to call at your home, no matter how sick you are.

There is nothing in the budget for a public hospital system starved by the cumulative effects of funding cuts from Commonwealth and state governments. Hospital waiting times get longer and facilities continue to deterio rate. Having taken $500 million out of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in the last budget, the government has cut it by another $700 million this time. This is the budget measure with the cute title of the `therapeutic group premiums'. This is actually the `new drugs tax'. It means that Australians will pay more for the latest, safest and best medication for such conditions as high blood pressure, depression, cholesterol and ulcers.

Under the new drugs tax, the government will only provide a full subsidy for the cheapest drug in each of the six groups of drugs. If patients require one of the more expensive drugs, they will have to pay the difference. So choose your illness carefully, with an eye to market values. For if your doctor prescribes a new drug which has fewer side effects and is more effective, you will pay up to $20 a script more. None of the new drugs tax will count towards the safety net threshold.

This new drugs tax will establish a two‐tiered health system: one tier for the rich who can afford the newest, safest and most effective drugs; the other for battling Australians who will have to make do with the cheaper, less effective and less safe drugs. It means that pensioners and families who are doing it tough will be forced to choose between what they need and what they can afford.

There is more. A number of medications will be removed from the PBS scheme altogether. They include treatments for stomach problems, diarrhoea, muscle pain and anti‐fungal medicines. Pensioners and other concession card holders now pay $3.20 for these drugs. From next year, they will pay up to $9.

In the usual sneaky way of this government, the new drugs tax will not count towards the safety net threshold. Over the last two years, the government has found ways to strip between $300 million and $400 million out of schooling, more than $250 million out of vocational education, nearly $900 million out of the university system and nearly $2 billion out of labour market programs—many of them provided through TAFE colleges.

It has gone to enormous lengths to wheedle dollars and cents out of working families by forcing increases in HECs charges, by forcing students to start repaying HECS debts before they are earning a halfway decent wage, and by squeezing the Austudy and Abstudy schemes until they scream.

Nearly a third of all the cuts in the last two budgets have been at the expense of help for families on low incomes. Let me give instances of the injury done to women and older family members. Child care is enormously significant for women, for example. It can decide whether or not a woman can go out to work. Yet this government has ripped more than $820 million out of child care in less than a year.

Older people—having worked and paid taxes all their lives—are another group which has been treated savagely by the government. It cut $500 million from aged care services in its first budget alone. It followed this up with one of the most cynical and callous laws ever seen in this parliament: the one that means that older people needing nursing home care, when at their most vulnerable, would have to sell their homes to get that care. So much for being a caring government.

Politics might be becoming an increasingly technical discipline nowadays, and increasingly difficult for the majority of voters to identify with. So the government can fiddle with means‐testing, indexation, cut‐offs and the like, in the hope that their real agenda can be obscured behind technicalities. They might even succeed from time to time. But I will tell you where they stand naked before the Australian people—where all the fudges and the statistics cannot protect them. It is when people lose their jobs. It is when the BHP board comes out and says that 2,700 workers are going to lose their jobs when the steel plant closes down in Newcastle. Then you are exposed if you are a government that relies on a simplistic economics textbook to deliver jobs and job security.

When Australians discover that their elected government is always the one turning up to the funeral of a steel plant with a bunch of wilted flowers, rather than being the plan to save it before it dies, then they have a right to be angry. They have a right to demand a better alternative. Well, they do have an alternative, and if they cast their minds back they might remember how that alternative dealt with exactly the same problem in 1983.

In response to BHP's intention to pull out of steel making in Newcastle, the Labor government implemented a steel plan: a plan which everyone, including the Prime Minister, who said he agreed it saved the steel industry in this country and that he would—and I quote—`not be stingy about giving credit to Senator Button for what he was able to do in relation to that'.

Fourteen years later, the industry minister is out at a long lunch when BHP announces its intention to pull out of steel making in Newcastle. When a crisis meeting of Newcastle steelworkers was held, the Minister was donning his black tie for a cocktail party at the Crown Casino opening in Melbourne. Our shadow industry minister was there, in Newcastle, listening to people's concerns.
Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise has become too loud.

—Now another big decision is looming. While the federal coalition government dithers over the Productivity Commission's final recommendations on the future of Australia's car industry, whole towns and suburbs wait in limbo, as do thousands of workers, hundreds of suppliers and service providers, as well as the managers and owners of companies in the industry—large and small.

BREAK.PARA: Nearly two months ago, Kim Beazley launched Labor's car plan. Our plan aims to give security to those employed in the car industry while improving competitiveness and quality and increasing our exports. Kim Beazley invited the Howard government to take up our ideas for the future of Australia's car and car component industries. Let's just see if they decide to do something, or just to order the white carnations for another funeral.

In two budgets now, the coalition has steadily surrendered or reduced activities that have been accepted for generations, by Australians of all political colours, as core responsibilities of service to the community. These responsibilities are the heart of the mutual exchange of obligation which takes place between good government and the well‐governed. But this government chooses to renounce them, doing damage to individual people and the community at large that will take years to repair.
It is this attitude to government and to national leadership that has produced this year's budget where:
. if you are rich enough to privately insure your health and attend private hospitals, the Howard government will support you;
. if you are rich enough, you will go to university under a Howard government, no matter how bright you are;
. if you are rich enough to save, the Howard government will reward you with tax rebates;
. if you are rich enough and healthy enough to defer your age pension, the Howard government will support you;
. if you are rich enough, you can have the best medicines, if you're not, it's `no frills' medicines for you;
. if you are rich enough, you can get nursing home care without having to sell your home.

This is a winner takes all budget, intent on creating division in our society. The wealthy walk away happy. The government's motto is, `Ask only what you can do for yourself.' For the rest of us, it will not help if we are threatened by job loss, a crippling disease or growing old. It fails the true test of leadership. It does not bring `all of us together' for the common good.
Recently we have had one State budget described as a Robin Hood budget. This is a Sheriff of Nottingham budget—a budget for the few, and for the very few.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot, Sen Cheryl

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Eight months ago the Democrats said the coalition's first budget was built on the backs of the unemployed, and we were right. Eight months down the track, if you were giving the 1997 budget a score out of 10, you would have to rate it minus 46,000, because that is how many Australians by which the government has missed its target on reducing unemployment. If you asked your average Australian family to rate last year's budget, they would give it a score of minus seven, because that is by how many dollars a week each Australian family was worse off as a result of last year's budget. John Howard tells us every day how much he cares about Australian families and coalition MPs and senators come in here every day and tell us how much they care about Australian families. But the fact is this: the coalition's first budget hurt Australian families and hurt them badly.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier this year, a highly reputable study found that the 1996 budget left Australian families worse off by $7 a week in disposable income and subsidised services. Sole parent families were worse off by nearly $11 a week. Families whose main income was the disability support pension were worse off by $21 a week. But the figure that really gives the lie to all this professed concern for Australian families is this one: unemployed households were worse off by a massive $38 a week. That is $2,000 a year. That is what the Howard government's first budget did to unemployed Australians: it took $2,000 out of their pockets—not very fair, not very generous and not very family‐friendly. But the story does not end there; it does not stop with the coalition's first budget. On Tuesday the Treasurer delivered the second chapter, the second instalment in the ongoing coalition saga of talking big about unemployment while doing practically nothing.

I think most Australians are sick and tired of this hypocrisy—all talk and no action. We talk about how the reputation of politicians has sunk to an all‐time low and we carry on about what we need to do restore that reputation and to restore respect for parliament and the democratic processes. One way to do it is to start matching all the cant about caring for Australian families, and all the cant about caring about unemployment, with some genuine action because ordinary working Australians are hurting. They are feeling the cold winds of global change right here and now in their lives.

In the last few months I have been out and about talking to people about unemployment. I have been out in the suburbs of Melbourne and Sydney and Adelaide because I want to know how unemployment is affecting people. I want to ask them what they really think about it, how it is affecting their lives and what they think the solutions might be. But the overwhelming message I am getting from them is that they are feeling incredibly insecure about their own future and about their capacity to provide for their families. People come up to me and say: `Look at BHP—3,000 Australians who are going to lose their jobs in the next two years.' They say, `Look at the Public Service and Telstra—30,000 people who have lost their jobs.' They say every day they open up the paper and read of jobs being lost, of people being retrenched and of companies moving offshore. If they are unemployed they tell me they are worried about ever finding a job, and if they have got a job they are worried about keeping it, and they are worried about their kids getting a job. That is the climate out there; that is how people feel out there in the so‐called real world we are often told to go out and find out about.

I know many coalition backbenchers are genuinely concerned about the popularity of Pauline Hanson. But it is time they faced the fact: they are part of the problem. When they come in here and defend last year's budget, when they come in here and defend this year's budget, they are colluding in the creation of a climate that is fertile ground for extremists. In their obsession with economics before all else—an economics that creates benefits for the few and losses for the many—they are colluding, as did their Labor Party predecessors, in the creation of a climate that is not dissimilar to that which developed in Europe in the inter‐war years and which led to the rise of fascism. I do not think that is too long a bow to draw. Robert Manne, one of this country's greatest and clearest conservative thinkers, had this to say earlier this week in The Australian:

. . . inter‐war fascism was described as the mobilisation of those who felt themselves as the losers in the processes of modernisation. For its part, contemporary right‐wing populism might be described rather similarly as the mobilisation of those for whom the era of globalisation has offered, thus far, not prosperity or hope but anxiety, meaninglessness and fear.
Anxiety, meaninglessness and fear—that is what is out there; that is what people are feeling. And that is what this budget does absolutely nothing to fix.

For a start, this budget completely fails the test on jobs. Australians wanted to see the Howard government do something about jobs. A poll in last week's Sydney Morning Herald showed that 67 per cent of Australians felt that reducing unemployment was the most important issue for the budget to address. Only 18 per cent wanted a tax cut instead, so Peter Costello got that choice wrong. That poll simply reinforces the fact that, despite 24 quarters of growth, most Australians do not feel comfortable and relaxed about unemployment. There is certainly nothing in this budget to reassure them. In the 12 pages and 20 minutes or so of Peter Costello's budget speech, unemployed Australians scored only three mentions: once at the beginning to raise our expectations, once at the end to pretend that something had been done, and once in the announcement of the Federation Fund.

That Federation Fund—John Howard's grand plan to build unspecified projects of national significance, preferably during an election year—is a total sham and I think the government knows it. For a start, its funding does not kick in for another two years. Even then, the $1 billion is stretched out over five years. How many jobs will it create? Maybe 2,000 a year if we are lucky. That is not now—that is 2,000 new jobs in two or three years time. I bet that is overwhelmingly good news to the 803,200 Australians who are out of work.

But the big story in this budget when it comes to infrastructure projects is not the Federation Fund. The big story when you read the fine print in this budget is the massive decline in infrastructure funding planned for this year. This year the Howard government will spend $948 million—almost a billion dollars—less on infrastructure than it spent last year. That is a billion dollars less for public works, for roads, for schools, for hospitals, for public housing, for railways and for water supplies. According to the National Institute of Economic Research, $1 billion worth of infrastructure spending has the potential to generate 18,000 jobs across the public and private sectors. So this budget will actually cost 18,000 jobs in infrastructure alone, with maybe 2,000 new jobs to be restored through the Federation Fund—but not yet, in two or three years time.

That sums up the fundamental dishonesty which underpins both this budget and the comments of the Prime Minister about it doing something for jobs. Let me spell it out: this budget does nothing for jobs. This budget costs jobs. Make no mistake about it: this budget's black hole on jobs will hit hardest in the regions. That massive decline in infrastructure spending—the lowest level of infrastructure spending by a federal government since World War II—is really going to bite out there in the regions, out there in those areas about which the coalition, particularly the National Party, profess to be so concerned.

There are no jobs for regional Australia, regrettably, in this budget. Local government grants—that is, money for council works and roads—fall by $200 million over four years. That is a loss of around 1,000 jobs in itself, most of them in country areas. The Public Service loses another 4,300 jobs, on top of the 5,600 jobs lost last year, on top of the 22,000 jobs lost from Telstra plus the 700 announced from the ABC just this evening. That also means a big loss of jobs in regional areas, as does the $200 million cut to public housing.

The abolition of the regional environment employment program and the LEAP program—two worthy jobs initiatives by the Labor Party—over the past year saw 25,000 jobs program places go, again mostly in regional Australia. Those places are replaced by a scant 240 places in the green corps this year and 10,000 work for the dole places next year. And they are not jobs.

The Prime Minister tells us that the Natural Heritage Trust Fund is about jobs in regional Australia, but what this budget does is cheat regional Australia by stretching out the trust fund's funding over six years instead of five. That means this year the government will spend $36 million less on the environment than it promised in the last election. Fortunately, the majority of the Senate has joined with the Democrats today to reject this funding fiddle.

While on the environment, it must not go unremarked that this budget confirms Australia's position as an international pariah on greenhouse gas reduction. Spending on energy research and conservation has once again been slashed—falling from $42 million last year to a mere $3 million in two years time with the abolition of the Energy Research and Development Corporation. That is $3 million to improve energy efficiency, as against $3 billion in tax breaks and subsidies to the mining industry. Fairly obviously, the pleas of President Clinton, Prime Minister Hashimoto and Chancellor Kohl for Australia to get serious about greenhouse gas issues have fallen on deaf ears.

The failure to invest in alternative and renewable energy sources is yet another example of a missed opportunity to generate jobs through investing in new and growing industries. In the last few days we have seen the Prime Minister dragging out his hoary old chestnut of a solution for unemployment—that chestnut called getting rid of Laurie Brereton's unfair dismissal laws. But we have already done that. We have already passed his so‐called `fair go all round' unfair dismissal laws last year. In fact, the Minister for Industrial Relations, Peter Reith, was crowing only last month about how well the new laws are working, with applications to the federal Industrial Relations Commission down 50 per cent on last year.

But today—after his budget is roundly criticised for doing nothing about unemployment and almost nothing for small business—the Prime Minister wants to have another go at denying workers employed by small business the right to challenge an unfair dismissal. That is John Howard's solution to unemployment. Slash infrastructure spending to a 50‐year low and deny 1.3 million Australian workers employed in small business the basic right to challenge their unfair dismissal.

Let us be clear about this: denying employees in small businesses their basic rights will not create one single new job. What every small business person I talk to wants—and what every poll of small business opinions consistently nominates as the No. 1 condition to employ more staff—is an improvement in the economy. This budget does nothing to give business and the economy a shot in the arm. Our depressed manufacturing sector—the big losers in last year's budget—get nothing out of this budget. Fifty‐five thousand workers have been retrenched from manufacturing over the past two years, and another 3,000 will lose their jobs when BHP closes its Newcastle plant. An imaginative government, a government firmly focused on getting the economy going again, would have included a shot in the arm for industry in this budget.

An in‐touch government would have responded to the pain and the anger of those workers in Newcastle with an anticipatory economic stimulus package—not an after the event, hastily cobbled together stimulus package—with things like an incentive for another steel maker to take over the Newcastle plant and reduce BHP's domestic monopoly; or an infrastructure package to upgrade Williamtown airport as an alternative domestic airport to complement Sydney; or a project to repair 100 years' worth of environmental degradation in the Hunter Valley; or a research and development package to use the University of Newcastle and the skilled labour force of the Hunter as the nucleus of a new high‐tech industry zone.

They are the sorts of imaginative ideas which we think are needed in response to the problems facing Australia. That is what is needed to get unemployment down. That is what Australians want to see. And that is what is missing from this budget.

Families really are not offered very much in this budget either. The 235,000 families on the public housing waiting lists can expect to wait a lot longer. Forty‐four thousand people in public housing are left up to $40 a week worse off because of the loss of rental assistance. Let me give you one example of how this particularly nasty little measure will work.

A woman rang my office yesterday to tell us that she lives in public housing with her adult son who has a mild intellectual disability. She is on the age pension and her son is receiving unemployment benefits. His income is taken into account in determining the rent—in fact, 20 percent of his income is taken out for rent—and he gets a few extra dollars a week in rent assistance. What this woman said was, `Look, it's not a lot of money, but it's just a little bit of extra assistance which helps us get by. We have nothing. We don't own our own home. We don't have a good income and now the government wants to take those few extra dollars a week off us.'

They are the sorts of people or the sorts of families that Treasurer Costello is referring to when he refers to this rent assistance payment as `a rort'. That is who is rorting the system—an aged pensioner and her disabled son. No wonder that male talkback caller said to the Deputy Prime Minister, `This budget's been constructed by those who have never known what it's like to be poor.' If the Treasurer really wants to talk about rorts, then he need look no further than the centrepiece of his budget—the savings tax rebate.

Treasurer Costello tells us that families will benefit from the savings tax rebate, and yes, that is true—not by very much though. Based on current savings and superannuation patterns, the benefit to a worker on a middle income of around $30,000 will be just $3.60 a week.

Low income earners cannot afford to put $58 a week into a superannuation fund to get the full benefit of that rebate. They do not have the $60,000 in savings in the bank that is necessary for the full rebate either. In fact, 43 per cent of low and middle income earners have no savings at all; and less than 40 per cent are currently making personal contributions into superannuation.

By contrast, over 70 per cent of high income earners are paying into superannuation an average of $80 a week, and they have an average of $84,000 in bank savings and shares. These are the people who will all get the full rebate—$8.60 a week, $450 a year—not for new savings, but for doing what they are already doing. They will not have to save a single extra cent to pick up this new tax break. For the rich in this country, that is just money for jam—and it is an awful lot of jam. In fact, over half of this $2 billion tax break is going to flow to high income earners. So much for the government's argument that this rebate is non‐discriminatory; it is highly discriminatory in its impact.

We welcome your attempt to give tax relief on savings. But we have always said that any tax break needs to be tightly targeted to encourage new savings. We have always said that any tax break has to be means tested—and up until this week, what was printed in coalition policy agreed with us. Their election policy said that a tax break on savings should apply to incomes below $35,000 and be phased out on incomes up to $39,000 a year. That sort of targeting would address the concerns of savings experts like Vince Fitzgerald and the warnings from the OECD about the need to ensure that any tax break creates new savings.

But that is the sort of targeting that is missing from this budget. I said on budget night that the coalition should stick to its election promise and means test the savings rebate—and I confirm tonight that the Democrats will move to means test the savings rebate on incomes above $35,000. Not only is that fair, but it would free up $1 billion a year which the government could spend on other measures to increase national savings and national investment.

The Democrats acknowledge that there are some positives in this budget. There are some good initiatives in health—and we have particularly welcomed the commitments in palliative care and mental health. We have welcomed the long‐overdue move to set up a national planning system in child care. We are pleased at last to see some assistance for rural families receiving Austudy.

We have some concerns about the changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme and to child care—although I think the government has largely come up with measures which are fair and reasonable in both areas. And I have to say that it is breathtaking hypocrisy on the part of the opposition to be carrying on about these changes, given their own record in government in these two particular areas.

BREAK.PARA: Overall, Australians will probably breathe a sigh of relief that John Howard's political jitters won out over Peter Costello's zealotry, resulting in a lot less slashing and burning than might have been expected. Of course, much of the damage was done in last year's budget—damage to public hospitals, to state schools, to public dental services, to universities, to labour market programs.

The great disappointment in this budget is that, with $4 billion to spend, John Howard and Peter Costello did not choose to use any of that money to repair some of the damage they did last year. They chose instead to put half of it into retiring debt—and that is a decision of which we approve. But they chose to put the other half—the $2 billion worth—into a faulty savings rebate.

They had choices. They did not choose to put the money into public hospitals. They did not choose to put the money into investment in infrastructure. They did not choose to invest in education or housing or transport. They did not choose to invest in getting Australia back to work. They chose to give a $1 billion tax break to high income earners.

That is what coalition backbenchers have to live with. That is what they have to go out and sell in their electorates—that very poor choice which has resulted in a budget which does nothing for jobs, does very little for families or the regions and which does nothing to dispel that climate of anxiety and fear which is slowly but surely taking over this country. Let me finish by saying thank you very much to those five other senators, apart from the Democrats, who have shown the courtesy of staying to listen to this budget‐in‐reply speech from the Democrats tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I seek leave to respond to the budget for a maximum of 30 minutes.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This is not an equitable budget. The fact that it is not recognised as such says more about the collapse of political debate in this nation than it does about this budget. It is a budget totally committed to one form of political economy—that of the global `free market', where subservience to the needs of vast corporations and currency speculators is accepted as the norm.

SPEECH.PARA: This a long way from Adam Smith's `invisible hand' of the market. Ironically, Australia was settled by many of the victims of the free market—the white settlers, that is. Peasants pushed off the land had to beg for a job in cities. Whole families—men, women and children over eight—had to work 12 hours a day to make enough to survive, live 10 to a room and dress in rags. Those less lucky turned to theft and prostitution and faced horrific penalties for crimes such as stealing bread to eat. These penalties included transportation to Australia. Over time, ordinary people, protesting the injustice of the social order, won certain basic rights—the right to a minimum wage, education, the eight‐hour day and child labour laws.

In the 1930s it became patently obvious that the economy by itself could not self‐regulate against social destruction. In the later part of this century, it is also obvious that the market is not capable of self‐regulating for ecological sustainability. Progress on social justice and environmental sustainability has been hard won.

The parties in government are now attempting to wind that back and return to the blind belief in the free market. They demand business `certainty' but remove regulation from industry. They are busy dismantling those aspects of government that serve an agenda of social development. The promise of a level playing field sounds so fair and equitable. Everyone is in conflict and contest with everyone else. It is dog eat dog and survival of the strongest. That sounds fair, kind of, though not very pleasant.

The problem is that there is no level playing field, and the more market access is opened internationally, the less fair the market becomes. The strongest can exploit or swallow others and make themselves stronger still. They can simply skew the system so that the competition is between those who are equally strong—does it sound familiar in relation to media?—and they build their strength on the exploitation of those weaker than they, like workers. The government then punishes the unemployed.

This budget increases the ability of those who already have a lot of power to compete in an unregulated, `equal' fashion with those who have little power. It requires wealth to access many of the `benefits to all' that the government talks about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Plenty of unemployed to punish.
—That's right. There are few choices for the jobless and few for the lower paid, unless you call giving up employer superannuation contributions to prop up extremely low wages `choice'.

SPEECH.PARA: The savings scheme will provide a substantial benefit for those who have the capital to save or invest. It creates options for those who can choose the best vehicle to optimise their investments. It does nothing for those who must spend what they earn on necessities. It will do nothing for those who, instead of saving, invest in their own house, though it will go to those who can invest in rental properties.

It will allow a deduction for earnings by sole ownership companies and partnerships, which will help those who attempt to get a small business off the ground, if they make enough profit in early years for a tax rebate to help.
