It will also help doctors, lawyers and any wealthy person who wishes to set up such a structure. It will allow those with stocks to reap the rebate for investment in shares. It will allow those with income from big family trusts the full rebate. It will allow those with a lot of spare money to invest to get the full rebate for income from bonuses from life insurance or from attributed foreign income.

This is not a progressive measure. It is regressive precisely because it is a reward for surplus income. It ignores the lack of ability for most people to invest at the level required to get the full rebate. It optimises choice so that every rich person should be able to get full benefit, but the poor are prevented from getting benefit by their poverty. The very reliance on `private choice', on `the market', without acknowledging differences in circumstance and need make this regressive.

BREAK.PARA: It would also, unless the Senate can stop it, allow wealthy families to hold a number of such accounts in the names of various people, each attracting such a subsidy. Of course, the poor are equally free to open accounts of $60,000 for each family member, buy houses to rent out, or have large shareholdings, big family trusts or foreign income in order to maximise their benefits. The market fundamentalists simply refuse to see that freedom does not create capacity, and real choice depends as much on capacity as on freedom.

The Wallis report recommended that bank fees and charges should not be regulated. Perhaps that is for more certainty. Fees will have a major impact on small account holders who make little income, and tax breaks on earnings from interest will be minimal for people who often do not pay tax and whose interest on small passbook accounts that are deep cycled are virtually nil. Deregulation of bank ownership gives no certainty except the certainty of corporate self‐interest.

This is a replacement for the superannuation contribution matching where government would match employee contributions. That scheme was odious in that it used taxpayers' money collected from all to fund retirement incomes on the basis that those who have shall receive more and those that have little will receive little. But the potential benefit of the Keating‐Willis plan for ordinary workers was worth nearly seven times the benefit of the Costello plan. It would also have applied to all workers.

This is a saving of $2 billion gained primarily through cheating the poor. It is a handout to the rich. It replaces a contribution to superannuation matched dollar for dollar with a promise of a 15c in the dollar rebate on superannuation contributions. It is a reduction of benefit of 85 per cent. Under the Keating‐Willis scheme, a worker contribution to superannuation of $1,000 would have seen government give that worker an additional $1,000. Under the Costello scheme, a worker who can invest $1,000 in superannuation will get a $150 tax rebate.

The full $450 rebate can be obtained by anyone who can afford to put an extra $3,000 per year into superannuation, which is an additional contribution of nine per cent or more of their salary. This is the best chance for ordinary workers to get this rebate. This contribution must be made each year to be of benefit, unlike earnings from investment income, which do not need to be increased. Those workers who can afford to reduce their earnings by 10 per cent of pre‐tax income will get the same benefits as every rich person. And this is supposed to be progressive?

The Senate may have been misled during debate on the retirement savings accounts legislation. A minor but significant part of the favouritism of banks is found on page 145 of budget paper No. 2. This says that the tax office superannuation holding reserve—which honourable senators will remember I asked quite a few questions about—which is designed to consolidate and assure charge free administration of small superannuation accounts will be phased out and the money put in retirement savings accounts or given to contributors.

There is no regulation of RSA charges and fees, and they are low return. There is no regime for allowing for the consolidation of small RSA accounts, similar to that of small superannuation accounts. I specifically did ask questions about treatment of the ATO holding reserve on Monday, and was met with reassurances, where I was not met with incomprehension. Perhaps Senator Kemp simply did not understand or, as Assistant Treasurer, was not told about these changes.

The government has yet another measure to erode the position of the poor. To `improve flexibility' workers will now be able to allow employers to pay extra cash rather than make employer superannuation contributions. Employers will simply offer lower wages and offer to top up incomes by giving up superannuation entitlements. It is the same type of calculation that sees employers offering sub‐living wages with a promise of enough guaranteed overtime to bring the take‐home pay to a living wage level. In other words, it is a subsidy to the employers, once again.

The government will offer this to people with no money and no power in a situation where hundreds of other unemployed people compete for the most miserable jobs. It does so with the government threat of the `work for your poverty' dole scheme behind it. It will offer this to people knowing that in most jobs their security and rights have been eroded by the government's industrial relations bills.

Another element of inequity disguised as choice is the deferred pension plan, which is likely to be of benefit to executives, academics and upper income headworkers rather than to older labourers, lower to middle level white‐collar workers or technical specialists such as engineers.

Unemployment falls unevenly on the old, but there are patterns of distribution by job type. Most commonly, those made redundant after 50 find it extremely difficult to get employment. These people are further penalised by changes announced in the last budget which demand that they use their superannuation assets before receiving the pension. They are therefore penalised for being old and unemployed while those in positions where they have the option to keep working will be rewarded. Where is the justice here? This is also a savings measure.

Guaranteeing pensions at a quarter of average weekly earnings, or AWE, has to be seen in context. One‐quarter of the current average weekly ordinary full‐time adult wage for the March quarter is $173.75 and the current single pension rate is $173.20. The pension has been kept roughly equal to 25 per cent of the average weekly earnings for some time. The pension rate is currently set according to the average wage, although not in legislation. So this is really not so special, although it is good for pensioners to have this protection in law.

There is also no surety that once in law it will remain in law even though pensions will continue—we hope. The `sunset clause' put on maintaining pensions at 25 per cent of average weekly ordinary time earnings found in the two bills, the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (1996‐97 Budget and Other Measures) Bill 1996 and Social Security and Veterans Affairs' Legislation Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1997, now before the Senate, is an indication of this.

It seems that in pushing for self‐funding for retirement and for a higher age of payment, and referring to the pension as a `safety net', the government is setting the stage to move to a two‐tiered system, with a charity payment as a safety net for those without sufficient income based, self‐funded retirement income. Perhaps we will have `work for your pension'.

Other measures will depend on the detail as to their actual impact. We have seen how the so‐called `tax on the superannuation rorts of the rich' contains elements that actually impact on many low and middle income earners and negatively affects all superannuation holders. Measures like the superannuation preservation changes or means tested retirement products are likely to present similar problems.

The savings scheme was supposed to be the sweetener. On the cut side there are $1.75 billion—about 1.25 per cent of outlays—in savings for the 1998‐99 year from so‐called `efficiency' in the Public Service. This is a highly dubious figure unless they plan to sack a whole lot of people. Outsourcing seems to be a big element of it. To put the 1.25 per cent of outlays savings figure in perspective, the general administration cost of Social Security is in total about 3.7 per cent while the percentage going to total general administration in Health is about 1.2 per cent. These are among the departments with the highest administration costs.

There is also the plan to sell off assets and government properties and move to outsourcing and basically eliminate most functions and staff of the Department of Administrative Services. The loss of jobs in information technology outsourcing itself will be well above the loss of jobs with the BHP closure or the Mitsubishi closure, without even looking at the results of putting confidential information of virtually all Australian citizens into the private sector—possibly offshore where there would be no commitment ethically or otherwise to Australian privacy laws.

The evidence from Victoria is also that there are few economic benefits from outsourcing, and substantial drawbacks in terms of degradation of service quality. There are effectively three global information technology firms. Their record of staying on budget and of service provision is not good. We will be shifting information technology costs from public employment of Australians to international employment of transnational employees.

The announced `family' program, mainly about home care of the severely disabled, is effectively a con. While there are real winners as well as losers, this is overall an area of cuts, not new expenditure. It also should be seen in the context of moving responsibility for the old and disabled off government and onto families. This is really about facilitating getting these people out of hospitals and nursing homes. It is along the same lines as turning the mentally disturbed onto the streets and calling it integration into the community. It is not about proper alternatives to institutionalisation; it is about shifting costs onto families, charities and the community.

The rural and regional measures are a ruse. There is an announcement of plans to make Austudy more available to people with two children or more away at school. It may allow richer people, whether or not they are farmers, to get Austudy benefits if their children are boarding. It does nothing to address the more fundamental problem of assets tests, which disqualify many farmers from a range of benefits and I assume will still apply. This may be more of a benefit to the rich than a help to struggling farmers.

There is an announcement of a new, four‐year rural package. The $200 million for this is pretty neatly offset by the elimination of the $196 million for the rural adjustment scheme. If one then counts the reduction in the rural communities access program—that is, minus $2.4 million—then the total new funding is really only $1.6 million. This is not a big new program and there are other cuts that will impact the rural sector, such as the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation and the fisheries resources research fund, an environmental fund. There is also the decline of $20.6 million over four years in funding for natural resource management.

Additional quarantine funding around fish imports will hopefully improve the situation many senators have complained about, though what is really required is a less complacent attitude towards imports of potentially problematic food products in response to the free trade agenda. It appears that, instead, it may be a plan to open to imports and pay for some of the inevitable damage to industry. A big part of the increase will not be an improvement in quarantine. It will go for redundancy payments for 700 sacked AQIS inspectors.

The changes to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme are a questionable measure. Where there are generic drugs available, it may make sense to ask that they be used, rather than supporting big drug transnational corporations; however, the use of a price representing the lowest cost generic drug of `similar clinical effect' ignores real differences between drugs, particularly in relation to potential side effects, drug intolerance and so on. In situations of heart and circulatory problems or cancers, it is common to have to try a variety of drugs to find the ones that cause least upset, particularly if used in conjunction with other drugs. Here is yet another example where the government has avoided bringing in a change of regulation for a better treatment of patients. Rather, it has put the cost onto the community, those least able to make those changes.

A fundamental area of injustice is that doctors prescribe and pharmacists fill prescriptions, but it is the patient who will pay. Those least able or likely to fight for lower cost options are the elderly, the less educated, those who are recent migrants or those who are otherwise socially `shy'. Those most likely to argue could be university graduates and those who feel confident in their social right to question and object. In other words, this is another area where the pre‐existing inequities already in the community will be allowed to exacerbate those inequities in future.

A wide number of drugs for common, non‐serious ailments, including non‐prescription drugs, will be cut and, hence, rise substantially in price. Will it cover such things as ventolin for asthmatics? Asthma is a very common ailment in Australia, which has the highest incidence in the world. Asthma can be life threatening but is rarely so. This is the sort of thing I imagine may be cut.

There is a huge range of other cuts in this budget: child care, energy, foreign aid, legal aid, the Human Rights Commission, the ABC and SBS, Abstudy, higher education, social security, health and labour market programs. The social infrastructure areas remain targets. This is a budget designed to give to the rich and call it a benefit to the battlers. This is a budget designed to give equal opportunities that only the wealthy can access. This is an attack on ordinary people.
Debate (on motion by Senator Kemp) adjourned.

That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Heffernan, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring the attention of this place to political correctness gone mad.

SPEECH.PARA: For three years, students at the two‐teacher, 38‐student Monteagle Public School near Young in my state of New South Wales have been performing an ecumenical pageant at Easter, a passion play. This calendar event is looked forward to by students, their parents and the local community. It is a highlight of the Easter ceremonies.

Following the passion play this year, under the guidance of the new principal, Miss Julie Newbury, the Labor government supported a decision to ban the scripture teachers from producing the play in its present form because of the explicit nature of the violence portrayed. I would like to read the script of the play, taken directly from the Bible. It states:
After Jesus had been arrested . . . the chief priests and the whole council wanted to put Jesus to death . . .
The high priest tore Jesus' robe and said, `This man claims to be God! We don't need any more witnesses! You've heard what he said. What do you think?'
They answered, `He is guilty and deserves to die!' Then they spat in his face and hit him with their fists. Others slapped him.
Early the next morning all the chief priests and the nation's leaders met and decided that Jesus should be put to death. They tied him up and led him away to Pilate, the Governor.
Pilate asked of them, `What am I to do with Jesus?'
They all yelled, `Nail him to a cross!'
Pilate answered, `But what crime has he done?'
`Nail him to a cross!' they yelled even louder.
Pilate ordered his soldiers to beat Jesus with a whip and nail him to a cross.

The Governor's soldiers led Jesus into the fortress and brought him together with the rests of the troops. They stripped off Jesus' clothes and put a scarlet robe around him. They made a crown out of thorny branches and placed it on his head. They spat on him. They took the stick from him and beat him over the head with it.

I have not read from the script used by the students, but from the Bible which I used to make my oath to this parliament and from where the script is taken. Are we to assume then that the Labor government in New South Wales is once again trying to rewrite a history which is fundamental to many Australians—a history which teaches peace and tolerance towards others, a history which does not condone violence, the history of a man who was perceived, as one parent said, to be `the prince of peace'.

Are we to expect that this book from which I have just read is to be banned from our school libraries because of the explicit violence it describes throughout, not just in Matthew chapter 26? Today's Sydney Morning Herald reported on this passion play ban and in the adjoining column on another decision by the New South Wales government with the headline `Classes to learn gay tolerance'. The latter article reports on the new program designed to stop gay vilification, requiring students to study in state schools gay positive theatre and fiction text that normalise gay lifestyles. I wish to highlight the irony of the New South Wales state government's involvement in the proposal to introduce a program to teach tolerance and in the same breath supporting the ban of a school play which depicts a story from Chris tianity, a religion which has as its tenet, `Do unto others as you wish them to do unto you.'

My support and congratulations tonight go to the parents and the children of the Monteagle school for their determination not to be bluffed out of the mainstream of Australia by some weirdo politically correct double standards of the New South Wales government and a decision which has ruled that the 2,000‐years old Easter ceremonies are dangerous and unfit for our school children.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I rise once again to raise the concerns of hundreds of thousands of people in southern Sydney regarding the plan by the coalition government to give them an airport at Holsworthy—an airport that they do not want; an airport that represents a most deceitful and dishonest decision by this coalition government to inflict great pain and suffering on the people of that region. As honourable senators know, I have made many speeches in this chamber regarding this issue. Indeed, the minister on duty tonight, the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer, is well aware of this as a couple of years ago we both served on a committee that looked at the issue of aircraft noise in Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure Senator Parer would agree with me that when we sat on that committee—and they were in opposition and we were in government—at no stage was any mention made of the possibility of an airport at Holsworthy. When one group decided it wanted to tell the committee its ideas about how you solve Sydney's airport problems by building an airport at Holsworthy, the committee regarded that as a bit of a joke and did not support that in any way. We know that at the last election the current government, the then opposition, said to the people of Sydney that the second airport for Sydney would be built at Badgerys Creek. They supported the policy of the then Labor government.

Tonight I want to outline further facts about this most disgraceful matter because it is becoming increasingly clear that this government really do want to put an airport at Holsworthy. They just do not have the courage to tell the people that is what their plans are. The people of the Sutherland shire, the Hughes electorate and the Liverpool, Wattle Grove and Campbelltown communities know what the real agenda of this government is and they do not like it. They do not trust this government because they do not believe them. They have been deceived. Increasingly, they are venting their outrage and their opposition to this crazy proposal.

Of course they are right to do so because how can you believe a government that have deceived the people in this way. They failed to tell the electorate what their real intentions were. It is becoming worse because all the time the minister keeps saying that the government still has as its priority Badgerys Creek. It is my belief—and it is the belief of hundreds of thousands of people in the community—that that is not the case. Whilst the minister says that, the member for North Sydney says, `No, you are going to have an airport in Holsworthy.'

Unfortunately, this tendency to deceive and mislead has now even struck the member for the electorate in which I live, the member for Hughes, Mrs Danna Vale. Mrs Vale recently sent a letter to thousands of homes in the community of Engadine. I and many others have received a letter which is clearly a form letter—sent out by a direct mail service no doubt. I want to quote from that letter. I have provided copies to the minister on duty because I will be seeking leave to table them later. This letter is addressed to Mr and Mrs Forshaw who live in Yarrawarrah, which is North Engadine for those who do not know the location as well as I do. The letter starts off:
Dear Mr and Mrs Forshaw
I regret I was unable to join those constituents at the meeting held at Engadine on 30th April 1997.

I interpose to advise the Senate that a large public meeting was held at Engadine on 30 April. I spoke at that meeting and the local state member, Mr McManus, also spoke. Mrs Vale was unable to attend. Her representative, a local Liberal councillor, spoke at the meeting. He apologised for Mrs Vale's non‐attendance and stated that she had a prior engage ment at a function in another suburb within the electorate.

There were over 2,000 people at that meeting—that is not a rugby league game estimate; that is a real figure. The hall was overflowing and there were people on the footpaths and on the streets outside. There was a huge crowd peacefully expressing their anger and their disgust at this government's attitude. It was unfortunate that the local member was unable to attend.
I go back to the letter that the member has written, obviously because she has become concerned about the strength of the opposition coming from the community in her electorate. It reads:
I regret I was unable to join those constituents at the meeting held at Engadine on 30th April 1997.

Unfortunately I was not invited to the meeting and I first found out about it when I read it in the "Leader" the week before. I had a commitment of long standing to host the Youth Forum in Menai that night, which placed me in a dilemma.

The people at the meeting that night were not happy that Mrs Vale was not at that meeting, but they accepted that she had a prior commitment. Mrs Vale in that letter that I have just read from says that she was not invited to the meeting and that she only heard about it when she read it in the local newspaper the week before—the local newspaper being the St George and Sutherland Shire Leader .

I want to refer to another letter that Mrs Vale has written. This time it is a letter to the local state member Mr McManus, the member for Bulli. A large part of his electorate covers the same area. It was Mr McManus who was involved in organising that public meeting. The letter is addressed to Mr McManus and says:
Dear Ian
Thank you for your kind invitation to attend the public meeting on Wednesday 30th April regarding the proposed Holsworthy Airport.
While I support your endeavours to stop the airport I will be unable to attend due to a conflicting community engagement of long standing. I am to speak at The Youth Forum at Menai.

It is abundantly clear that Mrs Vale is deceiving and misleading thousands upon thousands of residents of the region because the letter that she sent to Mr McManus indicating that she was unable to accept his invitation and acknowledging that she was invited to the meeting was sent on 24 April—a week before the public meeting. Yet Mrs Vale's letter, sent to all the constituents of the area—I might say that this letter has on the back of it a survey form seeking certain information from constituents—tells people that she was never invited to the meeting and that she only heard about it in a local newspaper.

I know what the people out there in the community would say about this, and I know what a court of law would say about this, when you have evidence, on the one hand, of a letter sent to the state member a week before the meeting saying, `Thank you for your invitation. I am sorry I cannot attend because I have got a prior engagement'—not an unusual thing to happen to local members—and, on the other hand, of the letter I received this week in my letter box and that was received in other letter boxes right around the electorate saying, `I was never invited': the member is trying to mislead and weasel her way out of this issue.
I finish by quoting further from the letter that she has sent to the constituents. In the third paragraph, she says:
I have been fighting this airport proposal right from the 21st May 1996—as a lone voice in the wilderness to begin with . . .

As anybody in this parliament knows, I have from the very outset been standing up in this parliament on behalf of the people of that area opposing this airport. It is completely false for her to claim that she is the only voice doing that. In the fifth paragraph, she says:
I am often asked at meetings why I do not resign.
Given the deceit that is involved in the correspondence that has been sent to the electors of Hughes clearly to mislead and, in my view, to lie to the people of that area, she should resign.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Forshaw, I would ask you to withdraw the expression that she is lying because you are reflecting on a member of another place.
—I do withdraw. I understand that is unparliamentary.
—Senator Forshaw, I am sorry to have to inform you that your time has expired.
—I seek leave to tender the documents, which I have provided copies of to the minister.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke last night about the reluctance of this government to seriously address the question of public health risks associated with telecommunications equipment and in particular about the question of adopting the precautionary principle. I will resume that speech this evening.

SPEECH.PARA: I spoke about the contradictions inherent in the statements made by the Department of Communications and the Arts and their so-called fact sheets, the facts available to us in the research available, particularly from recent studies, and the uncertainty to which the government departments admit.

On the one hand, Senator Alston's department is stipulating that adoption of the precautionary principle is based upon knowledge of a potential effect and that it has not been adopted because there are no potential effects. On the other hand, members of the Department of Communications and the Arts EME team are making public statements that there may indeed be such effects.

These last statements are supported by the contents of this department's discussion paper that was made available to the public when it was calling for submissions on research strategies. This paper outlines much of the emerging data on how low radio and microwave frequency may potentially be the cause of health effects. For example, on page three, it says:

Of interest are the studies suggesting the possibility of hazards resulting from low-level environmental fields . . . these may be roughly divided into two categories: general health surveys and cancer studies. The first group have not established any clear evidence of adverse health effects, with the exception of some studies that reported an excess of some autonomic and central nervous system complaints and symptoms generally consistent with those of mild depression. Nevertheless, the possibility of a true association between exposure to RFR and psycho‐physiologic nervous system reaction cannot be ruled out.
And turning the page, one reads:
Athermal effects are not well established, that is, very few studies have been replicated, and currently do not form a scientifically acceptable basis for restricting human exposure to RFR.

It is my understanding of the precautionary principle that if there is any evidence at all of a threat to public health from an environmental contaminant or indeed anything that is newly introduced as an emission into the environment then it is commonsense, if not an obligation, on the part of authorities to adopt that precautionary principle.

I was told recently by a member of one of the television crews here in Canberra that technicians working in an outside broadcast van suffered from testicular cancer. These technicians operate controls from a seat at the rear of the van, under which is located the transmitter and batteries. Their employer concluded that there was a likely cause and effect and chose to adopt the precautionary principal. That is, the television station did not ask, `Where is the substantiated evidence that electromagnetic radiation is causing this cancer?' They simply took measures to shield the equipment. No doubt they were worried about law suits as well as the health of their employees but the point is that they took the initiative. Of course, avoiding this risk is somewhat easier than, for instance, removing the risk for 4½ million users of mobile phones.

It is a responsible course of action to warn consumers that certain products may harm their health, just as we do on cigarette packs. It is a responsible course of action to protect employees from harm occasioned by occupational hazards. We warn people about the dangers of drink driving and we impose heavy penalties for those who drink and drive.

In every case I can think of, where there is a possibility of health risk, governments at least take steps to educate or regulate. Some risks will be much more obvious than others. Some risks, like those associated with electromagnetic radiation, are not immediately apparent. It is a substance which cannot be touched, cannot be seen and cannot be felt. If the risk is not particularly high, society accepts that it will be, generally speaking, a matter for individual choice. But to not have an informed choice is not to have choice at all.We hear a lot about choice from this government but information of the factual sort is a lot harder to extract.

I suggest to senators in this place that the government has been wrong-footed by the demands of the industry in this respect and that oft repeated phrases trotted out by Senator Alston's department and the industry, such as `there are no substantiated health effects from exposure to mobile phone towers', presumably have their origins in the public relations firm used by the industry and bear little resemblance to the real situation.

I also remind senators that it was not necessary for the government to have the health effects of tobacco use substantiated before finally adopting a precautionary approach. It is surely obvious and logical that according to all definitions of precaution it is not necessary for evidence of health effects to be unequivocally proven before precautionary measures are implemented. It is quite wrong, in my opinion, to demand absolute proof of health effects when current research clearly suggests that future generations may be at risk of gradual cellular mutation from accumulated low-level microwave irradiation.
Even the ESAA formally adopted the precautionary principle in 1991, which was then endorsed by the government in 1996. The ESAA states that:
The overriding purpose of the precautionary principle is to eventually reduce exposure to magnetic fields in our surroundings.

Given that Swedish government authorities have also issued policy guidance to help decision makers consider the EMR and public health effects issue, one has to ask: why can such good sense not prevail in the wireless debate? According to the Swedish brochure, the principle for initiating the effort was that:
There are no research findings to justify Limit Values, but there is reason to he cautious.

I am also advised that around three‐quarters of the world's top bio‐electromagnetic scientists advocate prudent avoidance—and that perhaps half of these believe that the public exposure standard should be about one tenth of what it is today.

In fact, the Woollahra council has recently banned mobile phone towers from being installed within a four kilometre radius of homes, schools, hospitals, child‐care centres and aged‐care centres. That is a clear indication, I think, of public feeling on the matter.One strategy for implementation of precaution could be a reduction in the public exposure standard.

I hope I have been able to make it clear tonight and yesterday that the government has not only attempted to deceive the Australian public—probably by using a public relations firm to gloss over and suppress the emergence of very important research information—but that it is also reluctant to concede there might

BREAK.PARA: be a case for introducing the precautionary principle, as this may force the government to face unpleasant facts regarding previous irresponsible policies on public health and democratic process.

Senator Alston's department has severely mismanaged the EMR and public health debate and earned himself nil credibility in the eyes of the public. Thousands of petitioners who put forward this view to my office are testimony to this.

In view of this situation, I believe there is a case for requesting that responsibility for electromagnetic radiation and public health ought to be shifted from the Department of Communications and the Arts, from telecommunications, to the health department. I urge senators here and the government to immediately review the public exposure standard and to adopt policies that reflect this precautionary approach.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 2 May 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) receive any private funding in the 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years; if so: (a) from whom, and (b) what were the funds used for.

(2) Does ABARE have any written protocols, guidelines or policies for the acceptance of private sector funding and contracts, if so, could a copy of these protocols, guidelines or policies be provided.

(3) With reference to the MEGABARE model: (a) what were the terms of reference for the development of the model; and (b) can details of the financial contributors to the development of the model, including a breakdown of the financial payments made by different parties, be provided.

(4) With reference to the GIGABARE model: (a) what were the terms of reference for the development of the model; and (b) can details of the financial contributors to the development of the model, including a breakdown of the financial payments made by different parties, be provided.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) implements a charging for services policy in order to implement the Commonwealth government policy on partial cost recovery. To answer your question I have provided information at attachment 1 on the receipt of fees for the 1994-95, 1995-96 and 1996-97 financial years.
The information I have supplied does not include details on miscellaneous revenue such as the sale of publications etc.

(2) ABARE implements a set of charging guidelines that address issues such as reason for charging, accounting arrangements, costing etc but does not seek to identify or define specific protocols regarding the acceptance of private sector funding.
